X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re: Why energy seems missing

	It would be ridiculous to say the rave scene declined all because of 
rent control. However I think rent control has (ironically) over the 
long haul contributed to driving up rents in the city, and to the 
extent that people have to spend more of their time working to pay for 
the cost of housing, that does negatively affect the scene.

	The population trends in San Francisco versus the U.S. over the past 
forty years certainly do not disprove this hypothesis. If anything, the 
fact that SF lost population while the country gained it would be more 
compatible with a scenario in which something about SF was causing the 
city to be out of sync with the national trend. For instance, lack of 
affordable housing due to a decreasing or barely increasing supply. Nor 
does comparing how much Gavin Newsom and Matt Gonzalez spent per vote 
have much relevance, since both of them favor rent control. I voted for 
Gonzalez, by the way.

								<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Register to vote

You can go here to fill out a form online to register to vote or change
your name/address or party affiliation: (there's background music, btw)
https://secure5.ctsg.com/rtv/ovr/indexNoPop.asp

It would also be wise to apply for permanent absentee ballot status.
You do that with your county registrar, and you can find their info (for
California) here:
http://www.ss.ca.gov/elections/elections_d.htm

-- 
What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] Planet New Years 2004 REVIEW

Last night was too sick and twisted. Planet B did one of the best sets I've ever seen... The audio and graphics where clean, thanks Cool World for this event... 

I'd give a 99% rating for the night... However, when we where standing in line to get searched, the rent-a-cop took all my glowing flashing lights, my gum, and bottle of water. I was rather upset over this. Only because I had spent $40.00 on them.. (was not cheap) 

I was proud of myself though, for taking 2 non-techno-goers out to a massive "rave" event... I felt like I had total control of the night. Your party was well organized...... 
I loved how the clock counted down to midnight. The Luniz did a sick ass hip-hop show, damn did they get down...

The speark sound system was fucking great... I swear.. I felt the music FLOW...
---- "Here's to the night"  
Thanks Guys-----
Warren L Shafor

-- 
What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 19346 invoked from network); 2 Jan 2004 21:41:09 -0000
Date: Fri, 2 Jan 2004 13:41:05 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v553)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
From: Philip.X.Diaz <st_indigo@earthlink.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-Id: <5E3ADA14-3D6C-11D8-8C9A-0003937E2222@earthlink.net>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] anyone alive out there? / NYE wrap up

so, how was NYE for you all?

araya and i went to Wish @ Otherworld. i give it a 9 out of 10. they 
had an excellent breaks lineup in the 2nd room, and trapeze 
performances by Kiran and Sandy. oh yeah, and DDR played too. ;-)

after leaving Wish (at 6 am or so), i dropped Araya and our friends 
Sara and Rick off at the house, then went over to SomArts for the 
after-hours action. i showed up thinking it would be breaks playing, 
but i was there early enough to catch the end of the psy-trance (which 
i like, but am not totally crazy about). but then, a great thing 
happened - a guy going by J-Flea started laying down records, going 
smoothly from Dr. Spook's last record into 135 bpm funky, dark breaks. 
all of a sudden, all the trance kids were grooving to breaks, and they 
just kept on going. :-)

I left SomArts around noon, woke all the kids up and made them get 
dressed (which took the better part of 4 hours), and then we all headed 
to Cafe Cocomo for Stompy Stomp. after about 2 hours, we decided to go 
back home to eat, and then come back later. when we got back, the place 
was PACKED, and Galen was rocking the place. what a scene! people 
dressed to the nines - wigs, platforms, costumes... we stayed until i 
literally could not dance anymore, which endded up being 10 pm.

24 hours straight.  today, i pay for it. :-)

hope you all had fun too.

-philip-

Thursday, January 8, 2004 ** Believe **

Featuring Drum And Bass; Open Decks; Open Promoters Meeting.  Sebastian,
T.E.C., Dj Butter, Night Ryder. 9p-2a. 18+ No dress code; Free before 10,
$5 thereafter (with flyer, guestlist, or e-mail). This event was founded
on the concept of growing the electronic music scene individual by
individual, creating a root source of creative energy. There are so many
talented DJs out there, and so many have yet to play out for the first
time. They can here. There are many DJs who have worked hard, year after
year to build their career who need a place to play to all of their
friends and fans. They can here. As we did once, we continue, we believe
that there is a place for electronic music. and that it starts with the
individual. Located @ Bassmint, 200 East Redwood St.

Saturday, January 10, 2004 ** Capricorn presented by Elektrosorcery **

Capricorn, whose constellation is known as Capricornus, is one of the
oldest of the astrological interpretations. Ruled by Saturn, its symbol is
the goat. This is sometimes depicted as a sea borne hybrid or Dolphin. The
image is often an animal with the body of a goat and the tail of a fish.
In one tradition the image represents the god Pan transforming into a sea
creature. A representation, perhaps, of the extremities found within this
Astrological sign. The Capricornian is generally a serious character
possessing a wry sense of humor. Independent, steady as a rock, Capricorn
reflects earthy qualities that range from clever to vacuous. Mostly
cautious, confident, strong willed, reasonable and hard working,
Capricorns are a rock upon which to build.They are capable of great
endurance; a whatever it takes, for as long as it takes persistence.
Reliable in any profession they undertake, but lacking in originality,
they usually excel in following up on what someone else has started. With
Capricorn DJs: DYLOOT, UPHONIC, COVERT, SUNDANCE KID, and more to be
announced. $10 presale $15 at the door.
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1013 S=
F
Bay California, USA

Saturday, January 17, 2004 ** Cold Phusion Winter Music Festival by BR
Productions, Next Level Promotions, and KCRH 89.9FM **

 he COLD PHUSION Winter Music Festival! Line-up TEASER!!! COLD PHUSION
will feature over 40+ Artists performing on 4 MASSIVE stages of sound! THE
WARP BROS: The legendary Warp Brothers - DJ's Oliver Goedicke and J=FCrgen
Dohr. It did not take a long time and their first single Phatt Bass hit
the German market and made it to the top 3 in the dance charts! Shortly
after this they entered the Sales-Charts Europe wide up to the #2! No
wonder that they draw the music business attention, with placing a solid
techno-track in the sales-charts.Shortly after their uplifting style
flooded Europe, the wave swept over to the US, Canada, Australia and
Japan. You might somehow compare the style of the Warp Brothers to Prodigy
or Chemical Brothers but the truth is that they created their own creative
and unique sound, like you can read in an article of the Face magazine.
Although the Warp Brothers are friendly people - they are in possession of
a lethal weapon, which is called Harder House. Remarkable is their success
in the UK sales-charts #9 and Top 10 positions in several Sales -Charts.In
Denmark they were rewarded with gold. Undoubted the Warpies as they are
keenly called by their fans turn it up on stage! DJ DRC: San Francisco's
Pioneer DJ DRC has relocated to New York City and is geared up to take the
Electronic Music Industry by storm. With her Mixed Album "UNDEFINED" in
the works and a list of releases on IMIX, Vision Music, Off World, Merge,
Twin Soul and her own label Undefined Musik, DRC equivocates the
expeditious pace of her new stomping grounds. Her original music is also
featured in two movies, "Vision of Vibe" with Carl Cox and "Intellect"
being released this February 2003, featuring Paul Van Dyk and many others.
DRC's latest single SEEKER can be heard on the SPANKEE clothing line
websight. With all this under her belt and more, it is obvious DRC has
already had her finger on the pulse of the Big Apple/ Manhattan. DRC
Returns to S.F. for a special set at COLD PHUSION! PLUS MORE CALIFORNIA
SUPERSTARS.... DJ JMARR (BR Productions/Liquid Vinyl DJs), FELIPE AVELAR
(BR Productions/ djfelipeavelar.com / bigfloor traxx), THE DOCTOR (BR
Productions/ Liquid Vinyl DJs) w/ MC FADER (Gravity Crew), DJ ORIONZ (BR
Productions / NextLevelPromotions.net), DOCTOR ROSS (BR Productions/KCRH
89.9FM/M.I.M.E. Recordings) *CD Release Party for Doctor Ross's new CD
"Open Heart Surgery" On M.I.M.E. Recordings!, VALERIE SPARKS (BR
Productions), CARLOS ALFONZO (BR Productions/ YuccaTribe / Deciblast),
JAMES DUB (BR Productions/ Space Monkey), DJ GIRLIE (BR Productions/
lovetribe.net / space monkey / ultrasounz), DJ DOZA (BR Productions/ The
Bounce / KCRH 89.9 FM), CRIS ROX (BR Productions/ M.I.M.E Recordings),
RECLIPSE (BR Productions/ Deciblast), DJ RYAN (Nextlevelpromotions.net)
*CD Release!, OSHY (BR Productions), & DOZENS MORE TO BE ANNOUNCED! PLUS:
Arena 4: Outdoor open air Rock/Alternative/Funk Stage! Outdoor Music Ends
@ 11pm SPECIAL EVENT FEATURES: - 4 Arenas Of Banging Sound! - 40+ DJs &
LIVE Acts! - Amazing Lighting! - Winter Themed Decorations! - Multiple
Stages! - Large Capacity VIRGIN Location! THIS IS A BENEFIT EVENT!! KCRH
89.9FM (College Radio) has launched the careers of many of todays hottest
radio DJs! - but California's budget crisis has hurt this renowned radio
station. Equipment repairs, new equipment, and much more is badly needed.
Profits from Cold Phusion go towards supporting this amazing radio
station, which has stood by the dance and rock scene from the beginning!
KCRH 89.9 is currently home to two of the Bay's most respected DJ Mix
Shows - BR Radio & The Bounce - which plays every Wed Night from
8pm-Midnight! ADDITIONAL INFO: 18+ With Valid ID. Zero Tolerance for
Weapons/Drugs/Alcohol. Tickets Go On Sale SOON - Stay Tuned for more info
TBA! We'll see you all @ COLD PHUSION!!!

Friday, January 23, 2004 ** SOMA Sessions w/Marcus Intalex **

SOMA Sessions Fourth Fridays @ AsiaSF

For the inaugural session we bring you, all the way from Manchester UK,
the sounds of:

MARCUS INTALEX (Soul:r, MIST - UK)  Marcus Intalex is known across the
globe for his infectious, smooth style of Drum 'n Bass. Only a few years
after his first production efforts in 1995 on Flex and his own Intalex
Productions imprint came anthems such as "How You Make Me Feel," "Love &
Happiness" and "Universe," which firmly positioned Marcus as one of the
world's top D&B personalities. Today, Marcus and longtime studio partner,
S.T. Files continue to blaze trails as M.I.S.T. with their wildly popular
Soul:r label. With over a decade of experience on the decks, SOMA Sessions
is proud to welcome back to San Francisco one of the UK's most in-demand
Drum 'n Bass DJs.

METHOD ONE (Cov.Ops, method-one.com)  By 1994 Method One was both an
acclaimed DJ and and experienced rave promoter in Philly. By 1996 he was
also an established producer. Recording with partner Kaos as Atlantiq,
Method One signed tunes to labels like Good Looking and True Intent while
holding down DJ residencies at Konkrete Jungle and Dieselboy's Platinum.
Since relocating to the Bay, Jason continues to wreck dancefloors with his
diverse DJ sets and release top-shelf tunes on labels such as ASC's Covert
Operations.

Resident Support:  DJ M SOUND:BOY

10:30pm - 3am For discount presale tickets, mailing list and more
information visit http://somasessions.com
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D958 Sa=

January 30, 2004.  Tribal Flux by Raw Heaven

FLUX. if you went to any of our free full moon gatherings over the past
year, you know what we're about.  This winter, we decided to take things
indoors. Our goal is to create the same feeling we all felt dancing under
the full moon and the stars. Also, we want to bring you a full season of
free outdoor next year on a more bangin sound system. There will be two
rooms of music, plus an ambient chill room.

Saturday, January 31, 2004 ** Winter! **

Surreal Entertainment and SFBang! productions proudly present!

Winter!  January 31st 2004!!!  A mini massive to start the year off with a
BANG!! and what better way than the joining of 2 crews to mix their magic
and make your wildest dreams come true. Surreal Entertainment (Known for
their yearly Earthdance,Liquid lotus festival,Refliections and their Club
Further) branching out all the way from Arizona to join forces with SF's
newest and quickly growing production company SFBang!, they brought you
GhettoTechnoSuperCaliExtraBootyLicious and if you attended that you know
the vibe and you know the rukus and a rocking time to look forward to!

WINTER is going to be SF's First EVER snow party!  dance the night away in
the falling snowflakes with 2 brand new artificial snow machines! You all
are encouraged to wear stylish winter themed costumes. The Surreal girls
will be there in full effect dressed as sexy snow bunnies and snow
angels!!! Feel free to join them on the fun!

This party will have somthing for everyone including House, Trance,
Breaks, Drum and Bass, and some good old fashioned HARDCORE!

a night of Winter time fun and excitement but please be aware ** This will
be a ZERO tolerance event!** no drugs or weapons of any sort will be
allowed to enter the venue.  For those of you 21+ there will be several
Full bars for your drinking pleasure.

Winter will have a 2000 person limited capacity so get your spot in the
snow while you can!  Ticket Outlets:  Skills (Berkeley) 510.704.9876 F-8
(SF) 415.221.4142 Solid Grooves (Santa Clara) 408.248.6399

Friday, February 6, 2004 ** *Oneiromancy* presented by Oneiromancy **

Doing things different from other crews, admission to this event will be
free of charge. We are working on the lineup, but as with all our events,
we want to extend a special invite to all the new DJs who have never
played an event. We are setting aside a number of timeslots, in various
genres, so if you are dying to get out there to play, email me at
wavelength_sf@yahoo.com, with the subject "Oneiromancy" Be sure to include
contact info, links to demos (if you have one), and genre. I know everyone
plays every genre, but if you could limit it to one, that would help. I'm
going to randomly draw names to play for each genre, so DJs who play a
genre that is under-represented will have a better shot. Its all random: I
dont care if we are friends, enemies, whatever. I'll post the list the day
after christmas, so thats the deadline. Oh yes, and unlike other times,
hardcore DJs will definatly get slots at this party. Hope to see you guys
there. (look for the full lineup the day after christmas. ) More info TBA.
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1017 S=

Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or
sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Thursday, January 8, 2004 ** Believe **

T.E.C., Dj Butter, Night Ryder. 9p-2a. 18+ No dress code; Free before 10,
$5 thereafter (with flyer, guestlist, or e-mail). This event was founded
on the concept of growing the electronic music scene individual by
individual, creating a root source of creative energy. There are so many
talented DJs out there, and so many have yet to play out for the first
time. They can here. There are many DJs who have worked hard, year after
year to build their career who need a place to play to all of their
friends and fans. They can here. As we did once, we continue, we believe
that there is a place for electronic music. and that it starts with the
individual. Located @ Bassmint, 200 East Redwood St.

Saturday, January 10, 2004 ** Capricorn presented by Elektrosorcery **

Capricorn, whose constellation is known as Capricornus, is one of the
oldest of the astrological interpretations. Ruled by Saturn, its symbol is
the goat. This is sometimes depicted as a sea borne hybrid or Dolphin. The
image is often an animal with the body of a goat and the tail of a fish.
In one tradition the image represents the god Pan transforming into a sea
creature. A representation, perhaps, of the extremities found within this
Astrological sign. The Capricornian is generally a serious character
possessing a wry sense of humor. Independent, steady as a rock, Capricorn
reflects earthy qualities that range from clever to vacuous. Mostly
cautious, confident, strong willed, reasonable and hard working,
Capricorns are a rock upon which to build.They are capable of great
endurance; a whatever it takes, for as long as it takes persistence.
Reliable in any profession they undertake, but lacking in originality,
they usually excel in following up on what someone else has started. With
Capricorn DJs: DYLOOT, UPHONIC, COVERT, SUNDANCE KID, and more to be
announced. $10 presale $15 at the door.
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1013 S=
F
Bay California, USA

Saturday, January 17, 2004 ** Cold Phusion Winter Music Festival by BR
Productions, Next Level Promotions, and KCRH 89.9FM **

 he COLD PHUSION Winter Music Festival! Line-up TEASER!!! COLD PHUSION
will feature over 40+ Artists performing on 4 MASSIVE stages of sound! THE
WARP BROS: The legendary Warp Brothers - DJ's Oliver Goedicke and J=FCrgen
Dohr. It did not take a long time and their first single Phatt Bass hit
the German market and made it to the top 3 in the dance charts! Shortly
after this they entered the Sales-Charts Europe wide up to the #2! No
wonder that they draw the music business attention, with placing a solid
techno-track in the sales-charts.Shortly after their uplifting style
flooded Europe, the wave swept over to the US, Canada, Australia and
Japan. You might somehow compare the style of the Warp Brothers to Prodigy
or Chemical Brothers but the truth is that they created their own creative
and unique sound, like you can read in an article of the Face magazine.
Although the Warp Brothers are friendly people - they are in possession of
a lethal weapon, which is called Harder House. Remarkable is their success
in the UK sales-charts #9 and Top 10 positions in several Sales -Charts.In
Denmark they were rewarded with gold. Undoubted the Warpies as they are
keenly called by their fans turn it up on stage! DJ DRC: San Francisco's
Pioneer DJ DRC has relocated to New York City and is geared up to take the
Electronic Music Industry by storm. With her Mixed Album "UNDEFINED" in
the works and a list of releases on IMIX, Vision Music, Off World, Merge,
Twin Soul and her own label Undefined Musik, DRC equivocates the
expeditious pace of her new stomping grounds. Her original music is also
featured in two movies, "Vision of Vibe" with Carl Cox and "Intellect"
being released this February 2003, featuring Paul Van Dyk and many others.
DRC's latest single SEEKER can be heard on the SPANKEE clothing line
websight. With all this under her belt and more, it is obvious DRC has
already had her finger on the pulse of the Big Apple/ Manhattan. DRC
Returns to S.F. for a special set at COLD PHUSION! PLUS MORE CALIFORNIA
SUPERSTARS.... DJ JMARR (BR Productions/Liquid Vinyl DJs), FELIPE AVELAR
(BR Productions/ djfelipeavelar.com / bigfloor traxx), THE DOCTOR (BR
Productions/ Liquid Vinyl DJs) w/ MC FADER (Gravity Crew), DJ ORIONZ (BR
Productions / NextLevelPromotions.net), DOCTOR ROSS (BR Productions/KCRH
89.9FM/M.I.M.E. Recordings) *CD Release Party for Doctor Ross's new CD
"Open Heart Surgery" On M.I.M.E. Recordings!, VALERIE SPARKS (BR
Productions), CARLOS ALFONZO (BR Productions/ YuccaTribe / Deciblast),
JAMES DUB (BR Productions/ Space Monkey), DJ GIRLIE (BR Productions/
lovetribe.net / space monkey / ultrasounz), DJ DOZA (BR Productions/ The
Bounce / KCRH 89.9 FM), CRIS ROX (BR Productions/ M.I.M.E Recordings),
RECLIPSE (BR Productions/ Deciblast), DJ RYAN (Nextlevelpromotions.net)
*CD Release!, OSHY (BR Productions), & DOZENS MORE TO BE ANNOUNCED! PLUS:
Arena 4: Outdoor open air Rock/Alternative/Funk Stage! Outdoor Music Ends
@ 11pm SPECIAL EVENT FEATURES: - 4 Arenas Of Banging Sound! - 40+ DJs &
LIVE Acts! - Amazing Lighting! - Winter Themed Decorations! - Multiple
Stages! - Large Capacity VIRGIN Location! THIS IS A BENEFIT EVENT!! KCRH
89.9FM (College Radio) has launched the careers of many of todays hottest
radio DJs! - but California's budget crisis has hurt this renowned radio
station. Equipment repairs, new equipment, and much more is badly needed.
Profits from Cold Phusion go towards supporting this amazing radio
station, which has stood by the dance and rock scene from the beginning!
KCRH 89.9 is currently home to two of the Bay's most respected DJ Mix
Shows - BR Radio & The Bounce - which plays every Wed Night from
8pm-Midnight! ADDITIONAL INFO: 18+ With Valid ID. Zero Tolerance for
Weapons/Drugs/Alcohol. Tickets Go On Sale SOON - Stay Tuned for more info

Friday, January 23, 2004 ** SOMA Sessions w/Marcus Intalex **

SOMA Sessions Fourth Fridays @ AsiaSF

For the inaugural session we bring you, all the way from Manchester UK,
the sounds of:

MARCUS INTALEX (Soul:r, MIST - UK)  Marcus Intalex is known across the
globe for his infectious, smooth style of Drum 'n Bass. Only a few years
after his first production efforts in 1995 on Flex and his own Intalex
Productions imprint came anthems such as "How You Make Me Feel," "Love &
Happiness" and "Universe," which firmly positioned Marcus as one of the
world's top D&B personalities. Today, Marcus and longtime studio partner,
S.T. Files continue to blaze trails as M.I.S.T. with their wildly popular
Soul:r label. With over a decade of experience on the decks, SOMA Sessions
is proud to welcome back to San Francisco one of the UK's most in-demand
Drum 'n Bass DJs.

METHOD ONE (Cov.Ops, method-one.com)  By 1994 Method One was both an
acclaimed DJ and and experienced rave promoter in Philly. By 1996 he was
also an established producer. Recording with partner Kaos as Atlantiq,
Method One signed tunes to labels like Good Looking and True Intent while
holding down DJ residencies at Konkrete Jungle and Dieselboy's Platinum.
Since relocating to the Bay, Jason continues to wreck dancefloors with his
diverse DJ sets and release top-shelf tunes on labels such as ASC's Covert
Operations.

Resident Support:  DJ M SOUND:BOY

10:30pm - 3am For discount presale tickets, mailing list and more
information visit http://somasessions.com
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D958 Sa=

Subject: [sfraves] From NYC 2 SF 2 LA?!?! Read up..

Ok,

So I've been really hating on cali nightlife. So far, SF began looking a
little dindgy, but the Richie Hawtin @ MEzzanine night was hot. As time
went on, I realized SF is one of the electronic music capitals of this
country still, werd. Still can't touch NYC, but its not far off.
Seriously, a few more weeklies, get ruby skye to ditch the dress code or
another club to book their djs, and you're a few steps closer. Anyways, I
just moved to L.A. Man, this club was so fucking tacky tonight. God. I
wanted to puke! It was full of beautiful socal girls, but I could barely
talk to them knowing that they were at that horrible club on their own
free will? Someone please tell me Avalon/Giant is at least ok? They get
some descent talen now and again, but whats it like?!?! Ahh, this will be
one of my last threads, so uhhh, if any of you know me keep in touch via
this email, otherwise, enjoy SF Nightlife!

Subject: [sfraves] Gatekeeper's Conference Now Going On

My shuttle arrived safely at SFO around 9:30 pm on January 1st.  We are 
currently having a Gatekeeper's Conference down in Santa Cruz, and I 
will be shifting operations to the Berkeley area Monday or Tuesday.

My preliminary inspection of the city on Thursday night was that 
everything seems to still be intact and as I left it before, but I'm a 
little concerned about Geri's postings, they seem to be making a little 
too much sense, when we've gotten accustomed to the incessant 
non-sensicle babble over the years.  Now it's possible that's just a 
phase, but we're not ruling out the possibility the real Geri Dahl was 
kidnapped by para-military right-wing demagogues and replaced her with 
someone else.  Other than that, though, the streets seem full of the 
usual annoying riff-raff, and I guess, for now, that's "normal".

But anyway, if anyone would like to report any suspicious activities, 
either contact me, or Osby, the current gatekeeper on duty.

-d

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Club 6 Fifth Anniversary Party Tonight

--=====================_13706789==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


6ix-One,The Five year Anniversary of Club Six.

For the first time ever. Marshall Jefferson-Chicago(The
Godfather Of House Music), Lenny Fontana(NYC House
Legend), Chip E.(Chicago House Icon) with Jonah
Sharp(Reflective Records), Said(Atmosfere/Chez
Music/Wave Music), Rebecca Watkins(Get
Underground/Primal Records), Dusty Crates(Electic
Soul).

  Marshall Jefferson(Chicago)-"The Godfather Of
House"(Producer/Artist/DJ)is the Creator of the House
Music Anthem "Move your Body". Marshall Jefferson has
for 20 years defined House Music. In 1986 he changed
dance music forever with the release of "Move your
Body". Marshall's music credits appear on hundreds of
recordings and he has launch the successful careers of
Ten City, Kim Mazelle and CeCe Rogers just to name a
few. His Legendary DJ sets have been applauded
worldwide.

  Lenny Fontana(NYC)is Internationally known
for his house music productions, remixes and DJ sets.
Since the mid 1980s Lenny has help shape the scope of
dance music. Lenny's catalogue includes classics like
"I Got What You Need, "Light my Fire", "Chocolate
Sensation", just to name a few. This is a rare SF
appearance. Chip E.(Artist/Producer/Remixer/DJ)In the
80's Chip E's released two of House Music greatest
Hits,"Like This" and Time to Jack. Chip Co-produced
Frankie Knuckle's first record "You Can't Hide".
Chip's influence was so big that he was and still is
still the only artist to be in regular rotation on all
3 major Chicago radio Stations. This is the first
time ever these 3 Legends will play together!

As a very special thank you to all of our wonderful
patron over the years, Club Six will host a FREE
screening of the World premiere of "Unusual
Suspects-The Story of House Music". This is be far the
most compelling and accurate story of House Music.
You can view it before it hits the film festival
circuit. The screening starts at 8pm Sharp. Once you
have viewed this incredible film, you're invited to
stay for Marshall Jefferson, Lenny Fontana, Chip E.,
Jonah Sharp, Said, Rebecca Watkins and Dusty Crates.
Remember, if you are there for the screening, you're
in for FREE!



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_28599013==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] New Year's Eve at False Prophet

--=====================_28599013==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

We have two traditions in my family for New Year's Eve.  The first involves 
placing coins outside on the doorstep or other nearby location to assure 
one has money for food and shelter for the coming year.  We also believe 
that the vibe experienced on NYE will continue throughout the year.  Well, 
if the extraordinary vibes I felt at the False Prophet NYE party were 
prophetic this is going to be one fine new year.

This was one of the best undergrounds I've been to all year long.  The 
theme was "Two Thousand Fourest: Winter Kingdom," and costumes were 
encouraged.  I've become somewhat cynical about wearing costumes to parties 
lately because, invariably, if I show up in gear I am one of a handful of 
people thus attired.  But I decided to do what the party givers requested 
and showed up dressed as a woodland creature:  a spotted leopard.  Seems 
people are getting creative again, because the warehouse was filled with 
pans, faeries, hunters and other foresty types.

For a free, invitation only party the production values were very 
high.  The downstairs dance area was filled with amazing electronic trees 
and other visual delights.  Upstairs there was a chill area constructed to 
look like a cave.  It was multilevel and quite realistic.  Much attention 
to detail everywhere.  The countdown to the New Year was illustrated by 
photos projected on the wall of people forming the numbers.  All of it was 
a true labor of love, and I really appreciate the care with which this 
non-commercial party was thrown.

Music.  Really rocked.  Booty shaking breaks and drum 'n' bass delivered by 
Ben, Sheztek, Jauncey and Smooch among others.  Everyone on that floor 
danced and danced to the end.

I knew very few people at this event so it was a chance to meet new dancers 
and sample the vibe of yet another of the diverse dance communities in this 
town.  Wasn't a person there I didn't like.  Much respect, love and 
sensuality in that group.  Left the party and walked into the drenching 
rain feeling refreshed, reborn and reinvigorated.  Can't ask for more.

Thank you 43 House for this wondrous beginning to the new year.  The 
underground is indeed quite alive and better than ever.

Happy New Year All.

Love,

Apollo





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"  
--=====================_28599013==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] .: Dirtbox Radio is ON LINE (finally) : Agent Sunshine, Davey A,

Wassup peoples!  Dirtbox Radio got off to a late start this evening, as I
was out on a mission with the one like Joe Migraine to purchase top secret
VW parts.  Agent Sunshine is on teh decks currently, and Davey A and
myself will be goin on the late slot after him, 'round 11ish.  Big shout
to Joe for holdin down the pre-show show!

To link up, simply go to http://dirtboxradio.com/listen.html and hit up ze
links.  The webcam is currently flaking out on me, and 7 hours of car
travel has weakened my drive to give a flying fuck.  So, no staring at our
sexy asses this week :)

this week!

Boh,
Jackson (ODJ)

On the basis of research conducted since the 1989 Loma Prieta =

rapidly growing region. This emphasizes the urgency for all communities =

Here, here! I totally agree with you. I remember the last minor quake, a few
months ago, and I was outside, in the park, walking the dog. Didn't really
notice much except a slight sense of dizziness.

But when I got home, I heard the whole story from my roommate--he said it
felt like a truck hit the building.

Now imagine a huge one hitting, when people are crowded in a non-permitted
warehouse. That could be a real catastrophe, don't even want to think about
it.

Long live outdoor parties! They are great when the rainy season ends!

greg

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] frustrated rave planner

Hey,

I've been a subscriber for awhile now and I've come to find myself in a bit 
of a dilemma. I've wanted to go to a rave since I was in high school (I'm 
now in college) but I live in a small town in Montana and I have very little 
hope now that I will just find one to go to. I've come to the realization 
that if I want it to happen, then I have to take matters into my own hands 
and plan it myself. Seeing as how I've never been to a rave, I thought that 
I would turn to all of you for advice.

My first problem is location. My friend tells me that he knows of a 
warehouse, and I know of a couple too, but I'm not sure if they would be 
ideal. The other option that I see at this time is a local art gallery. I 
know the owner, who's a rather eccentric gentleman, and he throws crazy 
parties all the time, but nothing quite up to rave caliber. Aside from me 
just knowing the owner, my friend is the events manager, so there's a very 
good chance that we would be able to use the space. It's not huge, but I'd 
rather that it be packed than have people huddled in the corner of a 
warehouse. There're also the obvious issues, if we use a warehouse, of 
heating and electricity. These things would be guaranteed if we used the 
gallery. It's a very well known place, though, so I'm not sure if it's a 
good idea. This is where I need the help: is it better to have it in an 
almost completely unknown place, or somewhere more promising but very well 
known??

My second problem is music. I know that there are a couple local djs who 
would be more than happy to spin for us, but I'm definitely a perfectionist 
and I'm not sure that they have the experience to live up to my standards. 
If I'm going to plan this I want it to be good. The other option is to find 
a dj from somewhere else and bring them here. This is unquestionably the 
more expensive option, but I think that it would probably be worth it in the 
long run.

Any kind of feedback would be awesome. I'm lost without it.

Thank you,
Ryan

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 57912 invoked from network); 5 Jan 2004 10:35:57 -0000
Message-ID: <20040105103552.56951.qmail@web80604.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 5 Jan 2004 02:35:52 -0800 (PST)
From: FireKid <blueflamedj@sbcglobal.net>
To: ryan cote <starryeyedorion@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-F32iyAphwFutJL000048d1@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-268951506-1073298952=:52380"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] frustrated rave planner

--0-268951506-1073298952=:52380
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

well, in the many years of partying, some of my most memorable parties were in either warehouses in the middle of bfe, or out in the woods.  and if you get a bunch of people going, once people start dancing, heat is not an issue.  ive spent all nights at parties out in the snow all night and been fine.  dancing produces a massive amount of body heat, and after an hour, the place will be warm.
 
as for the dj's, the final decision ends up coming down to the money you are willing to spend.  be aware that with dj's outside of the area you normally have to cover airfare, transportation from the airport, hotel plus dj costs...
 
and one more bit of advice, before throwing a party, you should really think about trying to find a couple to go to.  it is possible to throw em, but there are a ton of little things that you don't really think about unless you've experienced it.
 
hope this helps a bit ;)

ryan cote <starryeyedorion@hotmail.com> wrote:
Hey,

I've been a subscriber for awhile now and I've come to find myself in a bit 
of a dilemma. I've wanted to go to a rave since I was in high school (I'm 
now in college) but I live in a small town in Montana and I have very little 
hope now that I will just find one to go to. I've come to the realization 
that if I want it to happen, then I have to take matters into my own hands 
and plan it myself. Seeing as how I've never been to a rave, I thought that 
I would turn to all of you for advice.

My first problem is location. My friend tells me that he knows of a 
warehouse, and I know of a couple too, but I'm not sure if they would be 
ideal. The other option that I see at this time is a local art gallery. I 
know the owner, who's a rather eccentric gentleman, and he throws crazy 
parties all the time, but nothing quite up to rave caliber. Aside from me 
just knowing the owner, my friend is the events manager, so there's a very 
good chance that we would be able to use the space. It's not huge, but I'd 
rather that it be packed than have people huddled in the corner of a 
warehouse. There're also the obvious issues, if we use a warehouse, of 
heating and electricity. These things would be guaranteed if we used the 
gallery. It's a very well known place, though, so I'm not sure if it's a 
good idea. This is where I need the help: is it better to have it in an 
almost completely unknown place, or somewhere more promising but very well 
known??

My second problem is music. I know that there are a couple local djs who 
would be more than happy to spin for us, but I'm definitely a perfectionist 
and I'm not sure that they have the experience to live up to my standards. 
If I'm going to plan this I want it to be good. The other option is to find 
a dj from somewhere else and bring them here. This is unquestionably the 
more expensive option, but I think that it would probably be worth it in the 
long run.

Any kind of feedback would be awesome. I'm lost without it.

Thank you,
Ryan

_________________________________________________________________

time only! http://join.msn.com/?page=dept/dialup

Subject: Re: [sfraves] frustrated rave planner

i'd be concerned about how bustable the party could potentially be, or=20=

really, how easily the cops would find out you're throwing a party,=20
unless you're getting a permit from them or something, and what they're=20=

likely to do if they find you, and find a bunch of kids there they=20
think might be doing drugs.  have you thought about any of that?  if=20
not, *that* could potentially be your biggest concern!

as far as the music goes, once a perfectionist is maybe always one, but=20=

i encourage you to just try to have fun throwing this first party, try=20=

not to spend too much money on stuff, and just generally make it=20
something that is a trial period to see if you might like throwing more=20=

in the future.

-d


On Jan 5, 2004, at 2:35 AM, FireKid wrote:

> well, in the many years of partying, some of my most memorable parties=20=

> were in either warehouses in the middle of bfe, or out in the woods. =20=

> and if you get a bunch of people going, once people start dancing,=20
> heat is not an issue.  ive spent all nights at parties out in the snow=20=

> all night and been fine.  dancing produces a massive amount of body=20
> heat, and after an hour, the place will be warm.
>
> as for the dj's, the final decision ends up coming down to the money=20=

> you are willing to spend.  be aware that with dj's outside of the area=20=

> you normally have to cover airfare, transportation from the airport,=20=

> hotel plus dj costs...
>
> and one more bit of advice, before throwing a party, you should really=20=

> think about trying to find a couple to go to.  it is possible to throw=20=

> em, but there are a ton of little things that you don't really think=20=

> about unless you've experienced it.
>
> hope this helps a bit ;)
>

On 4 January 2004, Bryan Oley wrote:

> On the basis of research conducted since the 1989 Loma Prieta
> earthquake, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and other scientists
> conclude that there is a 62% probability of at least one magnitude 6.7
> or greater quake, capable of causing widespread damage, striking the
> San Francisco Bay region before 2032. Major quakes may occur in any

> all communities in the Bay region to continue preparing for
> earthquakes.

-- 
What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of

Subject: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Tracks of Yesteryear

I'm building a track listing of favorite tracks from yesteryear and beyond
for the Spirit of Raving Archives.

Q: What are your favorite artist/DJ tracks of yesteryear?

Here's the list so far: (will be sorted and alphabetized later)

Intelligent communication (FSOL) - Principles of Motion ep
Looney Toons (Frankie Bones & Lenny Dee)
808 State - 808-90
A Guy Called Gerald - Juice Box #9
Program 2 - Omen (Beltram Rmx)
2 for Joy - In a state
AON - Shades of Paranoia (Carl Cox rmx)
Shades of Rhythm - Getting Away
XL Recordings - The American Chapter
SL2 - DJ's Take Control

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 05 Jan 2004 19:52:19.0514 (UTC) FILETIME=[6D7889A0:01C3D3C5]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] frustrated rave planner

Hmmm.. you might think about throwing a house party. Not necessarily a 
'house music' party, but more like just a party in a house type thing.. I'd 
lose the word RAVE in your vocabulary altogether, the word comes with an 
incredible amount of fear to those that only know about it thru the media.

I'd definately include all the "rave" elements if you can.. DJs, a sound 
system of sorts, and maybe some sort of visual stimulation, nag champa.. 
lol. Just be different than your run-of-the-mill college kegger parties..

I'd start small and try to gain some experience with throwing parties and 
the things that potentially can happen. Then if you like what's going on, 
you can build.

just my two bits..

-Justin Hale





Secret Society -- The South Bay's Greatest Monday Night Bash
The Legendary Club Savoy
3546 Flora Vista Avenue
Santa Clara, CA 95051
408.244.6909
Secret Society continues in loving memory of Chris "Laffy" Taflanidis. We 
miss you brother. ESCT





>From: "ryan cote" <starryeyedorion@hotmail.com>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] frustrated rave planner
>Date: Mon, 05 Jan 2004 03:26:10 -0700
>
>Hey,
>
>I've been a subscriber for awhile now and I've come to find myself in a bit 
>of a dilemma. I've wanted to go to a rave since I was in high school (I'm 
>now in college) but I live in a small town in Montana and I have very 
>little hope now that I will just find one to go to. I've come to the 
>realization that if I want it to happen, then I have to take matters into 
>my own hands and plan it myself. Seeing as how I've never been to a rave, I 
>thought that I would turn to all of you for advice.
>
>My first problem is location. My friend tells me that he knows of a 
>warehouse, and I know of a couple too, but I'm not sure if they would be 
>ideal. The other option that I see at this time is a local art gallery. I 
>know the owner, who's a rather eccentric gentleman, and he throws crazy 
>parties all the time, but nothing quite up to rave caliber. Aside from me 
>just knowing the owner, my friend is the events manager, so there's a very 
>good chance that we would be able to use the space. It's not huge, but I'd 
>rather that it be packed than have people huddled in the corner of a 
>warehouse. There're also the obvious issues, if we use a warehouse, of 
>heating and electricity. These things would be guaranteed if we used the 
>gallery. It's a very well known place, though, so I'm not sure if it's a 
>good idea. This is where I need the help: is it better to have it in an 
>almost completely unknown place, or somewhere more promising but very well 
>known??
>
>My second problem is music. I know that there are a couple local djs who 
>would be more than happy to spin for us, but I'm definitely a perfectionist 
>and I'm not sure that they have the experience to live up to my standards. 
>If I'm going to plan this I want it to be good. The other option is to find 
>a dj from somewhere else and bring them here. This is unquestionably the 
>more expensive option, but I think that it would probably be worth it in 
>the long run.
>
>Any kind of feedback would be awesome. I'm lost without it.
>
>Thank you,
>Ryan
>

>Enjoy a special introductory offer for dial-up Internet access  limited 
>time only! http://join.msn.com/?page=dept/dialup

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (Review) Anon Salon 

     A few weeks ago at Sticky I met a girl who told me about a band called
Sound Tribe Sector Nine (www.sts9.com) who would be headlining an Anon Salon
party on New Year's Eve called Sea of Dreams
(http://www.anonsalon.com/seaofdreams04/index.html) The party was fairly
expensive, but I was excited to go to a new place to hear new bands and djs,
and party with people who don't know me at all.
     To sum up this party, I can only say "Hello 2Day!!! OMG So Dope!!!" I
would describe my night as a magical, spiritual experience. I got my palms
read by a man who was missing several fingers. I met many, many people who
had traveled from far away for this party. I danced and danced and danced. I
spun my poi, and figured out several moves that had been eluding me. I
connected with many people who have their eyes open, such as the little girl
with the long red tail who helped me fetch water for a couple that was
rolling hard on the floor. I can remember one point when I was in the middle
of the dance floor, and I looked around me at all the shining, happy faces,
the lights, the colors, the hypnotic music that STS9 was creating, and
couldn't imagine life being any better. I resolved that this year I will
make more of an effort to seek out new crews, new parties, new scenes. It
was so easy for me last year to go to parties like Sticky where I knew at
least 1/3 of the people there, but I always have a blast when I leave my
friends behind, go exploring and make new friends.
     I would highly recommend checking out anything that Anon Salon or STS9
does, and I will be sure to post any info that I get.

Happy New Year everyone!

Happy  :-)
www.happycandykid.com/mixes

"A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (Review) Anon Salon

I went to STS9 a few months back with my gf. If there had been more people
there and more energy (LOL - yes I know it's a BIG stoner group) it would
have been really cool. Regardless I perched myself in the balcony to the
left of the stage so I could see what the group did on stage. They like
Reason a lot. Ran into Boomerang and Leslie there. My gf went to the NYE
party last year and has always said it was pretty amazing. If it was the
Avalon Ball Room again this year then the location is equally beautiful on
its own.

Do you get the feeling that a lot of us are just tired of our same circles
and the same people? Seems that a lot of people are going seperate ways and
looking for something new. The scene that a lot of us knew is gone and a lot
of the faces with its passing.

:: r ::

     A few weeks ago at Sticky I met a girl who told me about a band called
Sound Tribe Sector Nine (www.sts9.com) who would be headlining an Anon Salon
party on New Year's Eve called Sea of Dreams
(http://www.anonsalon.com/seaofdreams04/index.html) The party was fairly
expensive, but I was excited to go to a new place to hear new bands and djs,
and party with people who don't know me at all.
     To sum up this party, I can only say "Hello 2Day!!! OMG So Dope!!!" I
would describe my night as a magical, spiritual experience. I got my palms
read by a man who was missing several fingers. I met many, many people who
had traveled from far away for this party. I danced and danced and danced. I
spun my poi, and figured out several moves that had been eluding me. I
connected with many people who have their eyes open, such as the little girl
with the long red tail who helped me fetch water for a couple that was
rolling hard on the floor. I can remember one point when I was in the middle
of the dance floor, and I looked around me at all the shining, happy faces,
the lights, the colors, the hypnotic music that STS9 was creating, and
couldn't imagine life being any better. I resolved that this year I will
make more of an effort to seek out new crews, new parties, new scenes. It
was so easy for me last year to go to parties like Sticky where I knew at
least 1/3 of the people there, but I always have a blast when I leave my
friends behind, go exploring and make new friends.
     I would highly recommend checking out anything that Anon Salon or STS9
does, and I will be sure to post any info that I get.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (Review) Anon Salon

It was at the Avalon Ballroom and the adjacent Regency Center Ballrooms. And
yes, I have been tired of the same old thing. I realized on NYE that I don't
dance enough anymore, and the reason is that I haven't been going to places
that uplift me and make me move. I go to places where I know lots of people,
and have fun hanging out, but I don't spend much time in the middle of the
dance floor with my eyes closed, giving myself up to the music. There are so
many circles in this tiny Bay Area, and we are mostly unaware of each other,
but there are amazing people everywhere if you leap outside your comfort
zone and seek them out. And when you find something new that rejuvenates
your spirit, bring your friends with you that they might find that spark in
their lives again too!

Happy  :-)

Received: (qmail 69436 invoked from network); 6 Jan 2004 01:46:41 -0000
Date: Mon, 05 Jan 2004 20:46:31 -0500
From: JonnyR@aol.com
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Message-ID: <1D334B43.5D771AA8.0004D974@aol.com>
X-Mailer: Atlas Mailer 2.0
X-AOL-IP: 68.166.191.98
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] post-New Year's Eve wrapup: Richard Humpty Vission & Planet NY

Hi, I've noticed a tendency on SF Raves for people to argue or debate about things at upcoming massives, but then the event passes without anybody mentioning a word. We were going on and on about whether Karl Bartos could represent himself as "Kraftwerk" at Cyberfest in July, but there was not one mention after the party that he didn't even appear at all! So, our debate was for naught. (I don't know why not, maybe the poor ticket sales led to Coolworld asking him not to come after all?)

We recently had a thread about whether Richard Humpty Vission was a worthy headliner for a New Year's Eve event. I remember he was not at the top of the lineup at Cyberfest a few years back in Fresno, so maybe Coolworld doesn't see him as a headliner, but perhaps lower anticipated ticket sales kept them from booking a bigger name (like Paul Van Dyk at Planet NY a year ago -- even though he played only 30 minutes!!!). 

Anyhow ... I thought Richard Humpty Vission was supposed to be on for the countdown, but he didn't arrive until much later, and there were a lot of equipment problems. I believe that St John was spinning during the countdown to midnight. There were people just marking time on stage, trying to rev up the audience, while he got set up. I'm not even sure if he spun at all, because I got restless and went to another room. 

So ... I don't think anybody really had a chance to see if he was a worthy headliner. hrmphh. 
I think the "coolworld sucks" mantra seems to be catching on, because each of their parties seems to attract fewer people than the one before. 
yeah i know, i should have gone to "Wish" or something else. Next year. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 02:54 PM 1/5/2004, innocentchild wrote:


>Do you get the feeling that a lot of us are just tired of our same circles
>and the same people? Seems that a lot of people are going seperate ways and
>looking for something new. The scene that a lot of us knew is gone and a lot
>of the faces with its passing.
>
>:: r ::

I felt much personal loss when the old school house community I loved 
pretty much disappeared in the last couple of years.  Come-Unity was an 
island of sanity and comfort for me each month and a place where I could 
see people I've known for ten years.  The Gathering is gone.  Wicked, it 
seems to me, is on its last beats as a collective.

Change is inevitable, however.  I've been around for a long time in the 
dance community and I've observed death and rebirth every five or so 
years.  Thus I've learned not to be too attached to any scene or genre, and 
really try to keep my mind open to the new and the flow of life.

If nothing would ever change we would all be bored as hell.  When change 
comes it may initially make us uncomfortable or sad.  People do 
leave.  Music changes.  But the underlying vibe, I think, has been pretty 
consistent over the years.  Dancers from each generation, I've found, are 
lovely people:)

It is a new year, and there are new people and energies in the 
community:  a time to meet new friends;  explore diverse dance scenes;  and 
fall in love with the community once again.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"  
--=====================_1280981==.ALT--

Yes, and I think it's a constant thing: Those people six years in
or so will feel jaded and tired. The new batch of ravers seems
as enthusiastic as we did back then. Of course they're not as
*relevant* as they haven't yet made a zillion friends or bought
gear. But give them time... and they will be running the place
:).

Sean

quoth JonnyR@aol.com:
> Hi, I've noticed a tendency on SF Raves for people to argue or debate
> about things at upcoming massives, but then the event passes without
> anybody mentioning a word.

Mmy guess is that the events just weren't good enough to merit any
rave reviews (*chuckle*). I could be wrong though.

> We were going on and on about whether Karl Bartos could represent
> himself as "Kraftwerk" at Cyberfest in July, but there was not one
> mention after the party that he didn't even appear at all!

Are you really that surprised? :)

> So, our debate was for naught. (I don't know why not, maybe the poor
> ticket sales led to Coolworld asking him not to come after all?)

I wouldn't say it was for naught. I hope enough people followed the
discussion long enough to make an informed decision about whether or not
to go based on the promoter's marketing practices. People that decided
not to might feel a lot better knowing that Bartos didn't even show.

Billing Karl Bartos as "Kraftwerk" was bad enough. That he didn't even
show should really make people think twice about going to massives
because of a single act. But where they lack in quality, I suppose those
events certainly excel in quantity...

Cheers,

>of a cardboard box, he is approached by someone asking if he had any Keoki 
>mix tapes, the guy selling the mix tapes says "No, Keokis ego is too big 
>for my little box" the guy yells at the person selling tapes "IM KEOKI!" 
>and aparently it was.
>
>Bwahahaha, so has anyone else ever heard that? I love it!
>
>AUDiOTACTiX
>
>

Provocative Technology. Featuring Trance, House and other Funky stuff,
also Feat. Jungle-n-Drum-n-Bass in your face.

415 Westside weekly rotating DJ's: Mars >
Mystre > Dyloot > Tom Slik >St. John > Bicolus > B-dub > Dos > Lady Ms .B
> Denise > Telene > Icon> Luke > Delphis > Joey Mazolla > Charlie > Huey >

Now every Tuesday there's a place for you to shake your bootay and hang
out  at 1751 Fulton @ Masonic, the old Storyville.
Located in the Haight  Ashbury district of San Francisco, near the
Panhandle.

Doors open at 9pm, 'til 2am and if you're too tired to cook after a long
day at workand want to have a nice dinner, come by earlier. The food is
soooo good!.
Plus,there's unlimited parking  across the street in a new secure lot, what
more can you ask for, especially in the city?

*** Admission is Free.***

Hey and it's free so bring all your homies, dancing shoes, and a killer
vibe!!!!

Subject: [sfraves] (bsp) SOMA Sessions - Fri 1/23 - D&B w/Marcus Intalex

SOMA Sessions 

Drum 'n Bass >> Fourth Fridays @ AsiaSF 

Friday January 23, 2004 

For the inaugural session we bring you, all the way
from Manchester UK, the sounds of: 
 
MARCUS INTALEX (Soul:r, MIST - UK) 
Marcus Intalex is known across the globe for his
infectious, smooth style of Drum 'n Bass. Only a few
years after his first production efforts in 1995 on
Flex and his own Intalex Productions imprint came
anthems such as "How You Make Me Feel," "Love &
Happiness" and "Universe," which firmly positioned
Marcus as one of the world's top D&B personalities.
Today, Marcus and longtime studio partner, S.T. Files
continue to blaze trails as M.I.S.T. with their wildly
popular Soul:r label. With over a decade of experience
on the decks, SOMA Sessions is proud to welcome back
to San Francisco one of the UK's most in-demand Drum
'n Bass DJs. 

METHOD ONE (Cov.Ops, method-one.com) 
By 1994 Method One was both an acclaimed DJ and and
experienced rave promoter in Philly. By 1996 he was
also an established producer. Recording with partner
Kaos as Atlantiq, Method One signed tunes to labels
like Good Looking and True Intent while holding down
DJ residencies at Konkrete Jungle and Dieselboy's
Platinum. Since relocating to the Bay, Jason continues
to wreck dancefloors with his diverse DJ sets and
release top-shelf tunes on labels such as ASC's Covert
Operations. 

Resident Support: 

DJ M 

SOUND:BOY 


10:30pm - 3am | 21+ | $10 presale, $15 door 

To buy discount presale tickets or join our mailing
list, visit our website:
http://somasessions.com 


AsiaSF 
201 Ninth Street at Howard St 
San Francisco, California 94103 
415.255.ASIA(2742)
http://www.asiasf.com/
Map: http://maps.yahoo.com/maps_result?ed=RxPMR.p_0TouRY0V11560D0BB_xV85Q-&csz=94103&country=us

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (Review) Anon Salon 

Happy wrote:
I resolved that this year I will make more of an
effort to seek out new crews, new parties, new scenes.
It was so easy for me last year to go to parties like
Sticky where I knew at least 1/3 of the people there,
but I always have a blast when I leave my friends
behind, go exploring and make new friends.
- - - - - - - --- - - - - -- - -- - - -- - -- - - -

I always have a different word on my cell phone,
reminding me what kind of "mood" I am in.  No more
than three weeks ago the word for at least six weeks
or so was, "diversify."  I think if we all try this a
litle more often,we would be amazed at how much more
variety life has to offer us than we give it credit
for.  Stepping onto different dancefloors hasn't been
easy; but, I am certainly glad that I have, and will
continue to do so until my botty can shake no more.

Love,
Karyna

Just in case you're wondering the new word is
"Evolve." 
--- Happy <happy@happycandykid.com> wrote:
>      A few weeks ago at Sticky I met a girl who told
> me about a band called
> Sound Tribe Sector Nine (www.sts9.com) who would be
> headlining an Anon Salon
> party on New Year's Eve called Sea of Dreams
> (http://www.anonsalon.com/seaofdreams04/index.html)
> The party was fairly
> expensive, but I was excited to go to a new place to
> hear new bands and djs,
> and party with people who don't know me at all.
>      To sum up this party, I can only say "Hello
> 2Day!!! OMG So Dope!!!" I
> would describe my night as a magical, spiritual
> experience. I got my palms
> read by a man who was missing several fingers. I met
> many, many people who
> had traveled from far away for this party. I danced
> and danced and danced. I
> spun my poi, and figured out several moves that had
> been eluding me. I
> connected with many people who have their eyes open,
> such as the little girl
> with the long red tail who helped me fetch water for
> a couple that was
> rolling hard on the floor. I can remember one point
> when I was in the middle
> of the dance floor, and I looked around me at all
> the shining, happy faces,
> the lights, the colors, the hypnotic music that STS9
> was creating, and
> couldn't imagine life being any better. I resolved
> that this year I will
> make more of an effort to seek out new crews, new
> parties, new scenes. It
> was so easy for me last year to go to parties like
> Sticky where I knew at
> least 1/3 of the people there, but I always have a
> blast when I leave my
> friends behind, go exploring and make new friends.
>      I would highly recommend checking out anything
> that Anon Salon or STS9
> does, and I will be sure to post any info that I
> get.
> 
> Happy New Year everyone!
>

7-8:30pm Open Decks, feat. 2 guest DJs
8:30-10pm  Konkers (urban Wasteland, infinite beat)
10pm-11:15  Indigo (AM breaks, Urban Wasteland)
11:15-12:30 AndyW (mutorsoundsystem, resource records, refined music, 
viberation)
12:30-close Amber (SisterSF)

Bassment hosted by AuraSF...
Iyad (AuraSF, hosstribe)
Koroma (AuraSF)
Floorcraft (AuraSF, hosstribe)
JC (AuraSF)

See you all there, have a great new year!!!
(and drive carefully please :P)
Your friend,
Danny Picard

-The Swedish Chef

From sfraves-return-109262-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Jan 06 23:14:50 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-109262-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 27052 invoked by uid 1103); 6 Jan 2004 23:14:50 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 27038 invoked from network); 6 Jan 2004 23:14:49 -0000
From: JBlaze112@aol.com
Message-ID: <89.c60983.2d2c9b63@aol.com>
Date: Tue, 6 Jan 2004 18:14:43 EST
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="part1_89.c60983.2d2c9b63_boundary"
X-Mailer: Thunderbird - Mac OS X sub 206
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Matrix Revelry Review

--part1_89.c60983.2d2c9b63_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

U know I have to admit, when i first got the flier to this party i had a bit 
of that... *rolls eyes* feeling. like o my god matrix revelry oookkkk because 
i remember sugesting to someone who was planing a party to make it matrix but 
then we decided it was too cliche and people wouldn't like it. because a lot 
of people didn't like the last two movies and what not. Anyhoo, out of a string 
of bizare coincidences my friends and i (including Osby!) ended up attending 
this party. & of course we showed up in costume and got in for $10, there's no 
way were gonna pay $20 for that bush and van ness venue. so we show up at the 
party, & low & behold... it actually kicked ass. The decorations were bad 
ass, they had a projector in one chill room playing all the matrix movies with 
sound and everything, i enjoyed that. In another room all of the walls were 
compleately decked up in matrix code, which was just awsome. and all the other 
rooms were just all black and with everyone in costume and what not they managed 
to give a matrix feel all night long. I'm not big into DJ's per se, i just 
like good music so i couldn't tell you who's sets were good that night but i do 
remember Tamim's set was off the hook. and it was impressive to see micheal lui 
once again. I have to mention that none of us ingested a single drug and we 
had a blast, we even went to an after party in emeryville and met a lots of 
cool people. I'm taking this party as a sign that the scene is back in effect. 
Granted, yes people do not as often come up and give you hugs and let u play 
with their lil fuzzy toys while they express how much they love you. Granted yes 
you may catch a few mean mugs from some thugs or get bumbed into by a group of 
rambunctious pre-teens while you're trying to dance, but all & all the music 
is still good, it's still fun to dance, still meeting lots of cool people & 
we're still on the edge of something very different than what everyone else does 
on their fri-sat nights. i'm proud of all the old school heads i keep running 
into since the 90's, all the people who just keep going, who've endured 
through all the talk of "the scene is dying/dead" and what not. Anyways... not to 
keep ranting, this is just my review for the party. Good job guys... whoever 
threw this party i already forgot their crew's name, elektro... something er 
other, u know who u r. 
     moral of the story is don't doubt a party that seems "cliche" at first 
because it just might actually kick ass in the end. - Jaze

--part1_89.c60983.2d2c9b63_boundary--

----- Message from DJBigDaddyG@aol.com on Mon, 5 Jan 2004 18:37:21 EST

      To: sfraves@hyperreal.org        
                                       
 Subject: Looking To Buy [DJ Keoki     
          Records]                     
                                       

I have been having the most hardest time trying to buy DJ Keoki's music on
Records, I have been up and down on many online record stores and still I
find
no luck with his music being online.

Here is a list of online stores that I have checked so far.

http://www.satelliterecords.com
www.virtualvinyl.com

-i need more online shops also i really am dyeing for keoki records-


I coming asking the people of SFraves for help. Hoping that someone might
have his wax for sale or even know where I might be able to buy it at
online. I
trust online record buying more then going to a store just because the fact
I
know it will be in good shape :-) also I am willing to drive if you might
of
saw his music at a store.

Well, thanks a lot.

-warren
DJ Daddy G
www.positiveflowca.tk

----- Message from "AUDiOTACTiX" <audiotactix@hotmail.com> on Mon, 5 Jan
2004 19:09:43 -0800 -----
                                                 
      To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>                
                                                 
 Subject: Re: [sfraves] Looking To Buy [DJ Keoki

Is this your first day on the internet? for fook sakes dude,

Searched the web for DJ Keoki 12".  Results about 5,610. Search took 0.16
seconds.

http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&q=DJ+Keoki+12%22&btnG=Google+Search


http://edenscrush17.tripod.com/housemusic/id88.html

http://www.top-music.info/10C1R16-11_Dance-And-DJ-Trance.html


Its the internet, learn to use it!

on that note, I heard a funny story years ago and this is the palce to see
if anyone knows it to be true...

Back in the day, there was a party in Golden Gate Park, djs and what not.
At this party there was a guy walking around with a selling mix tapes out
of a cardboard box, he is approached by someone asking if he had any Keoki
mix tapes, the guy selling the mix tapes says "No, Keokis ego is too big
for my little box" the guy yells at the person selling tapes "IM KEOKI!"
and aparently it was.

Bwahahaha, so has anyone else ever heard that? I love it!

AUDiOTACTiX

>

>on that note, I heard a funny story years ago and this is the palce to see

>if anyone knows it to be true...
>
>Back in the day, there was a party in Golden Gate Park, djs and what not.
>At this party there was a guy walking around with a selling mix tapes out
>of a cardboard box, he is approached by someone asking if he had any Keoki

>mix tapes, the guy selling the mix tapes says "No, Keokis ego is too big
>for my little box" the guy yells at the person selling tapes "IM KEOKI!"
>and aparently it was.
>
>Bwahahaha, so has anyone else ever heard that? I love it!

>From: JBlaze112@aol.com
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] Matrix Revelry Review
>Date: Tue, 6 Jan 2004 18:14:43 EST
>
>U know I have to admit, when i first got the flier to this party i had a 
>bit
>of that... *rolls eyes* feeling. like o my god matrix revelry oookkkk 
>because
>i remember sugesting to someone who was planing a party to make it matrix 
>but
>then we decided it was too cliche and people wouldn't like it. because a 
>lot
>of people didn't like the last two movies and what not. Anyhoo, out of a 
>string
>of bizare coincidences my friends and i (including Osby!) ended up 
>attending
>this party. & of course we showed up in costume and got in for $10, there's 
>no
>way were gonna pay $20 for that bush and van ness venue. so we show up at 
>the
>party, & low & behold... it actually kicked ass. The decorations were bad
>ass, they had a projector in one chill room playing all the matrix movies 
>with
>sound and everything, i enjoyed that. In another room all of the walls were
>compleately decked up in matrix code, which was just awsome. and all the 
>other
>rooms were just all black and with everyone in costume and what not they 
>managed
>to give a matrix feel all night long. I'm not big into DJ's per se, i just
>like good music so i couldn't tell you who's sets were good that night but 
>i do
>remember Tamim's set was off the hook. and it was impressive to see micheal 
>lui
>once again. I have to mention that none of us ingested a single drug and we
>had a blast, we even went to an after party in emeryville and met a lots of
>cool people. I'm taking this party as a sign that the scene is back in 
>effect.
>Granted, yes people do not as often come up and give you hugs and let u 
>play
>with their lil fuzzy toys while they express how much they love you. 
>Granted yes
>you may catch a few mean mugs from some thugs or get bumbed into by a group 
>of
>rambunctious pre-teens while you're trying to dance, but all & all the 
>music
>is still good, it's still fun to dance, still meeting lots of cool people &
>we're still on the edge of something very different than what everyone else 
>does
>on their fri-sat nights. i'm proud of all the old school heads i keep 
>running
>into since the 90's, all the people who just keep going, who've endured
>through all the talk of "the scene is dying/dead" and what not. Anyways... 
>not to
>keep ranting, this is just my review for the party. Good job guys... 
>whoever
>threw this party i already forgot their crew's name, elektro... something 
>er
>other, u know who u r.
>      moral of the story is don't doubt a party that seems "cliche" at 
>first
>because it just might actually kick ass in the end. - Jaze

I had more fun at that party than I've had out in a long time... the decor
and the abundance of costumes really did it for me.  I was a bit hesitant

now, but no rips or stains.  =P

Subject: [sfraves] nrr:  records for sale (old school)

Gettin rid of more records!  Heres a small batch of some old school stuff. 
  Selling each record for $3 (or $4 for the 2x12).  You can either pick it 
up from me in SF or Ill be at Uplift at the Sublounge on Thursday night and 
you can grab it there.

fyi, ive got more records im clearing out of my collection.  more lists to 
come.


Cyclotron - Hypnottised
Hypnotised (dance edit), Hyphotised (fantasy mix), Out of Sequence (bone us 
mix)

Massive Attack / Orbital (white label)
Unfinished Symphony (Original, Paul Oakenfold mix, Paul Oakenfold 
insturmental)
Belfast, Chime

Stakker - Humanoid 92
Single edit, Maxi version, Tempus est iocundum

808 State - Bombadin
Barta mix, Original quica, Bombapella, Wakacherwaka mix, Club 12, 
Drumpella, Original 2 four pub mix

Lords of Acid - Do What You Wanna Do
Do What You Wanna Do ( Album version, DOs Pleasure and Pain, Jade and Khan 
Erotix, Carl Says Do It Boy!), I Sit on Acid 95

Moby - All That I Need is to be Loved
Vocal Dance mix, Speed Trance, Moby Dub, Flashin Dub

Moby - Drop a Beat
Drop a Beat, Electricity, Drop a Beat (Deep Mix)

Channel X
Rave the Rhythm, Double Defused, Silicon on Sapphire

Grand Theft Audio - America
Tolerance mix, DJ Lace mix

Banco de Gaia - Kincajou
Oliver Lieb mix, Here Comes the Norse Gods, Speady J mix, LP mix

Best of House Music - Volume 7 (2x12)
Loose Caboose - Electroliners, Massif - Ramjac, Burn the Elastic - Violet, 
Sweet Harmony - Liquid, Algorhithm - Mondo Scoro, The Feeling - Sugar, For 
Those Who Like To Groove - Twin Hype, Everybody Thinks Im High and I Am - 
DJ Voodoo and Liquid Method, 4 Seasons - Blue Amazon, Funk-da-fried Party - 
The DJs Project, Rhythm - DJ Who, Viva House - Me and Jack

> >>i remember sugesting to someone who was planing a party to make it 
>matrix
> >>but
> >>then we decided it was too cliche and people wouldn't like it. because a
> >>lot
> >>of people didn't like the last two movies and what not. Anyhoo, out of a
> >>string
> >>of bizare coincidences my friends and i (including Osby!) ended up
> >>attending
> >>this party. & of course we showed up in costume and got in for $10,
> >> there's
> >>no
> >>way were gonna pay $20 for that bush and van ness venue. so we show up 
>at
> >>the
> >>party, & low & behold... it actually kicked ass. The decorations were 
>bad
> >>ass, they had a projector in one chill room playing all the matrix 
>movies
> >>with
> >>sound and everything, i enjoyed that. In another room all of the walls
> >> were
> >>compleately decked up in matrix code, which was just awsome. and all the
> >>other
> >>rooms were just all black and with everyone in costume and what not they
> >>managed
> >>to give a matrix feel all night long. I'm not big into DJ's per se, i
> >> just
> >>like good music so i couldn't tell you who's sets were good that night
> >> but
> >>i do
> >>remember Tamim's set was off the hook. and it was impressive to see
> >> micheal
> >>lui
> >>once again. I have to mention that none of us ingested a single drug and
> >> we
> >>had a blast, we even went to an after party in emeryville and met a lots
> >> of
> >>cool people. I'm taking this party as a sign that the scene is back in
> >>effect.
> >>Granted, yes people do not as often come up and give you hugs and let u
> >>play
> >>with their lil fuzzy toys while they express how much they love you.
> >>Granted yes
> >>you may catch a few mean mugs from some thugs or get bumbed into by a
> >> group
> >>of
> >>rambunctious pre-teens while you're trying to dance, but all & all the
> >>music
> >>is still good, it's still fun to dance, still meeting lots of cool 
>people
> >> &
> >>we're still on the edge of something very different than what everyone
> >> else
> >>does
> >>on their fri-sat nights. i'm proud of all the old school heads i keep
> >>running
> >>into since the 90's, all the people who just keep going, who've endured
> >>through all the talk of "the scene is dying/dead" and what not.
> >> Anyways...
> >>not to
> >>keep ranting, this is just my review for the party. Good job guys...
> >>whoever
> >>threw this party i already forgot their crew's name, elektro... 
>something
> >>er
> >>other, u know who u r.
> >>      moral of the story is don't doubt a party that seems "cliche" at
> >>first
> >>because it just might actually kick ass in the end. - Jaze

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
