X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Afrika Bambaataa

--=====================_18177628==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

It's refreshing to see party reviews on this list again:)  Party on 
dancers...good for the body and the soul!!!

Those of you into old school hip hop and electro funk -- Afrika Bambaataa 
will be at Club 6 on Saturday.  Already bought my tickets.

  Afrika Bambaataa is one of the three main originators of break-beat 
deejaying, and is respectfully known as the "Grandfather" and "Godfather" 
of Hip Hop Culture as well as The Father of The Electro Funk Sound. Through 
his co-opting of the street gang the Black Spades into the music and 
culture-oriented Zulu Nation, he is responsible for spreading rap and 
hip-hop culture throughout the world. He has consistently made records 
nationally and internationally, every one to two years, spanning the 1980's 
into the next Millennium 2000.

Due to his early use of drum machines and computer sounds, Bam (as he is 
affectionately known) was instrumental in changing the way R&B and other 
forms of Black music were recorded. His creation of Electro Funk, beginning 
with his piece "Planet Rock," helped fuel the development of other musical 
genres such as Freestyle or Latin Freestyle, Miami Bass,Electronica, House, 
Hip House, and early Techno.

See you on the dance floor.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"  
--=====================_18177628==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] TRUTH ABOUT RAVES (RECOCKULOUS!!!!!!!!)

--0-1415913537-1073442770=:7663
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I'm not usually one to pitch a fit.......but.......I don't think I have ever been so disturbed....insulted....and all around offended by the thoughts and beliefs of another human being in all my life.  To be told that I am "walking in Satan's path" just because I listen to music and appreciate an art that doesn't "praise the lord" is GOD DAMN recockulous.(<-----Like my new word)  What kind of fucking religious freak could fathom the idea that art is evil, based on the fact that it is not saying "Amen......Thank you Jesus" at the end of every measure.  Now, I don't practice "mainstream" religion......I don't go to church, nor have I ever read the Bible......but this crock makes me ashamed to have  even been baptized Roman Catholic............HOLY SHIT.......(thats all I have to say about that)
RAVER 4 EVER........LET THE BEATS PLAY ON!!!!!!!!!!!!
-Graham

drop (bz, ambient mafia, sf)
dj aryn (aec, viberation, sf)
indigo (ambient mafia, sf)
dj bam (invibe.com, sf)

upon arriving, we'll escort the willing to a photo
setup where the lovely araya will capture that
auspicious, sappy moment before your makeup runs and
there's nothing left of your dignity.  there will be
punch (i highly recommend you try some) & trashy
snacks, but remember this is a BYOB affair if you need
*more* than that.  as a reminder - dress the f*ck up! 
it's fun, easy, relatively cheap, and you won't be
alone ;)  you can recreate this party to be the prom
you never went to because chad, the page-haired poet
who led debate class, didn't ask you to go, or this
can be the moment where you cry up to the 80's gods
'damn i look fine in my stone-washed hammer pants and
screw you all if you who made fun of me when i sang
along to NKOTB's 'step by step'.  ah, the
possibilities are endless :)

this event is going on for 3 reasons.  i f*cking love
the 80's (troll away), any excuse to get everyone
under one roof and have a good time is a damn fine
reason for getting out of the house, but most
importantly, we're raising money to help the epiphane
crew pay off the fine they received at their last
event.  tickets are only $5 which can be purchased via
paypal on the evite i'm sending out;  donations are
definitely encouraged if you'd like to pitch in more. 
i've already gotten some email addresses, but if you'd
like to go, email me privately so i can add you to the
roster.  this venue is limited to 150 capacity so get
on this now before we fill up!

happy new year to everyone, here's hoping you
recovered nicely ;)

calamity bombatitty

=====
ooooooooontz ooooooooontz oooooooooontz

something  i noticed when i did inspection of the berkeley area and 
dropped by primal records was that the selection of records, the number 
of flyers on the table, and the number of non-dj people have all 
decreased.  you can really tell.  now it seems like they're doing ok as 
a record store, at least i hope, and from their website it seems so, 
but that's my way of seeing that the scene has really shrunk.

irresponsible raver citations to write!

Hi Jeff,

An-ten-nae throws an excellent breaks party periodically at 550 
Barneveld.  I hear they are doing these quarterly, but who knows.  "Get 
Freaky," as the event is called, has been a big success.  As for 
progressive house, wait for a Jack Triumph announcement:)

Info at www.an-ten-nae.net

Love,

Apollo





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

>From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] Afrika Bambaataa
>Date: Tue, 06 Jan 2004 17:39:12 -0800
>
>It's refreshing to see party reviews on this list again:)  Party on 
>dancers...good for the body and the soul!!!
>
>Those of you into old school hip hop and electro funk -- Afrika Bambaataa 
>will be at Club 6 on Saturday.  Already bought my tickets.
>
>  Afrika Bambaataa is one of the three main originators of break-beat 
>deejaying, and is respectfully known as the "Grandfather" and "Godfather" 
>of Hip Hop Culture as well as The Father of The Electro Funk Sound. Through 
>his co-opting of the street gang the Black Spades into the music and 
>culture-oriented Zulu Nation, he is responsible for spreading rap and 
>hip-hop culture throughout the world. He has consistently made records 
>nationally and internationally, every one to two years, spanning the 1980's 
>into the next Millennium 2000.
>
>Due to his early use of drum machines and computer sounds, Bam (as he is 
>affectionately known) was instrumental in changing the way R&B and other 
>forms of Black music were recorded. His creation of Electro Funk, beginning 
>with his piece "Planet Rock," helped fuel the development of other musical 
>genres such as Freestyle or Latin Freestyle, Miami Bass,Electronica, House, 
>Hip House, and early Techno.
>
>See you on the dance floor.
>
>Love,
>
>Apollo

Subject: [sfraves] .: Tons of New DNB Mixsets from Dirtbox Radio :.


Yeah, so I've been slackin recently and not posting up new mixes.  Below
are listed all of the new mixes available on Dirtbox Radio since 12/07.
Checkem out, as well as many others, at dirtboxradio.com/archives.html.
At the peoples' request, I've been leaving the sets as one big file, so
you don't have to download like five million files to hear a whole set.
You'll have to cut 'em up to burn them on CD, but it's pretty easy :)

_ 12/14

Lycan (97:22)
Slick rollers, bouncy tunes, and even some mashup shizzle.
56k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/DirtboxRadio-20031214-Lycan.ram
192k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/mp3/DirtboxRadio-20031214-Lycan.mp3

Relapse (101:57)
Pure evil techy madness, straight up.
56k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/DirtboxRadio-20031214-Relapse.ram
192k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/mp3/DirtboxRadio-20031214-Relapse.mp3

_ 12/21

Jerel & ODJ (60:59)
Lotsa tech and some funk.  Boh.
56k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/DirtboxRadio-20031221-Jerel+ODJ.ram
192k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/mp3/DirtboxRadio-20031221-Jerel+ODJ.mp3

Sabin (88:55)
Warm rollers, bouncyish stuff, and some slick ragga. Fun set.
56k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/DirtboxRadio-20031221-Sabin.ram
192k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/mp3/DirtboxRadio-20031221-Sabin.mp3

Deinfamous (88:08)
Dee drops a really mean tech set.
56k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/DirtboxRadio-20031221-Deinfamous.ram
192k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/mp3/DirtboxRadio-20031221-Deinfamous.mp3

ODJ, Jerel & Davey A (146:55)
Warmer funky tracks to techstep to some good ol Ram shit.
56k:
http://www.dirtboxradio.com/DirtboxRadio-20031221-ODJ+Jerel+Davey_A.ram
192k:
http://www.dirtboxradio.com/mp3/DirtboxRadio-20031221-ODJ+Jerel+Davey_A.mp3

_ 12/28

ODJ & Jerel (116:59)
Ended off the year with some dark shit, Dirtbox style.  Was fun to play :)
56k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/DirtboxRadio-20031228-ODJ+Jerel.ram
192k: http://www.dirtboxradio.com/mp3/DirtboxRadio-20031228-ODJ+Jerel.mp3

Phil Scott, Plejik, Myatch & Deinfamous (154:28)

From: Vibe Is Alive <vibeisalive@yahoo.com>

Subject: [sfraves] **Are You Feeling It?**

--0-230962570-1073453718=:74695
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Happy Hello!
     I hope that everyone had a happy New Year. 
 
This week on Daytrippin' we join our resident DJ's Buckner and Sean Davis as we welcome:
 
Villo of Balance Record Pool, Fade Records, and ProtonRadio.com
 
Please Read his Bio below as taken from www.ProtonRadio.com
 
Villo-  Villo's first professional steps in the music world are traced back to the summer of 1988, when in company of two junior high school buddies began mixing tapes, DJing for his own classmates and eventually the majority of high school party needs for the greater metro area of Puebla City, Mexico. The earliest events Villo did were sweet 16 birthday celebrations and private parties, quickly progressing to a few Teachers' weddings and larger music venues. 

By 1992, he had built a strong reputation and in April got his first residency inaugurating Club Rokola, in the neighboring state of Guerrero. The next club to have Villo was Freeday in Puebla City, where with Miguel Campos he started playing a daily residency in the early summer of 1993. At the same time Villo also started a vinyl-only record selling company with Ger Disco's Sergio Gutierrez. By the end of the year, Villo and Miguel where also playing in D'Paradise on the weekends and for PROZOUND, their own company. Raising the service and musical quality in a town renowned for it's nightlife proved smart, soon the two were performing frequently and for crowds of up to 5000. In 1995 Villo began putting together and DJing Puebla's very first underground parties. Villo also started a residency in Club Oxigeno, the first trance/techno Club in Cholula, with guests like DJ Klang and Tini tun. 1995 was the dawn of his famed New Year's parties. 

In 1996, he made his ELECTRONLY Thursdays parties happen at Puebla's Nazty Club. It was this year that he met Freddy Ramirez, a veteran DJ and producer who was creating PROmueve, the top DJ pool in Mexico. January 1997 had Villo in Mexico City to DJ as opening/closing act for Los Druidas, as well as in the Mexican college circuit. That June he started a residency at club Indalo in Cholula; by the end of summer Villo had started Mundo Submarino, a monthly party with various venues throughout Puebla. By 1998 Villo was DJing out of state more often while playing the intense college circuit in Cholula, and Mexico City. In 1999 he kicked off the new Kiffi Cafe and continued the Thursday alternative night with sets over 8 hrs with a musical range that went through house, ambient, jungle, progressive and hip hop beats. By the summer he was doing Fridays at the Casis Club in Puebla, and gearing up for fall, he DJed as opening act for Latin pop star Aleks Syntek on the Liquid Moon National
 Tour. This year also marked the official debut of his music productions, and he released an album with six tracks under his Purple Star label. He also worked alongside Freddy Ramirez to bring DJDance'99 in November, the first dance music event in Mexico for the industry's professionals, held in Acapulco, Guerrero. New Year's 2000 event lasted three days and Villo played a special 12-hour set from 10pm to 10am. 

In early 2000 Villo moved to Orlando, where he became part of the Balance Promote Group alongside Chris Fortier and Jimmy van M, and started playing the US club circuit while taking care of the day-to-day business at the Balance Record Pool. In 2001 he launched his label, PurpleStar Records in the US, with some of his productions already being played by many of his peers and held a monthly residence at Orland's premiere club 'The Groove', where he shared the decks with DJs such as Parks and Wilson, Noel Sanger and Dave Cannalte. In 2002 his song 'Monopo' (Stereounderground) was played extensively by Jimmy Van M in the Delta Heavy national tour with Sasha and Digweed, and was selected to be in the worldwide famous Import Club (May02) series from PromoOnly ; it was bought by EMI later that year. Villo along with studio partners Beaumont Stanford and Jeffrey Organes (the trio goes by the moniker Stereounderground) completed their first full length album, Human Codition; which has been
 very well received by DJs and producers alike. November 2002 saw the launch of The Balance Record Pool Show, every Friday 6-8pm EST in NYC's www.protonradio.com where people all over the world have a chance to listen. 

2003 has been a year full of excitement so far; with a handful of remixes, Villo's sound is going further. Stereounderground's remix of Sasha's album track 'Boileroom' has been played all over the world and all the major festivals by DJs like Hernan Cattaneo, blowing up dancefloors. Villo is also part of the www.floridahousemusic.com crew, and has started a new show Saturday nights on Proton called 'L8 Night Mix', with crime and production partner Dave 'Atnarko' Ross. Their remix work on Teknology is just a taste of things to come, with other remixes already lined up for the end of the year. This summer John Digweed asked Villo for an exclusive mix for his KISS 100 weekly show, and the mix was broadcast on July 11th. Production and DJ wise, this has been a year full of new sounds, a glimpse of what's to come yet. Playing for a decade and a half, clubs, afterhours-parties and exotic exterior locations his trademark deep uplifting music, anytime and anywhere you listen to Villo on the
 decks, is guaranteed to be a memorable one. 
 
--end bio--
 
  So tune in and Get Down this Saturday to the funky-techy deep house goodliness you know and love. Tune your browser to www.pulseradio.net This and Every Saturday for the very best underground dance music. From 1-4pm EST
 
Pulseradio.net is a global internet radio station featuring 3 hour shows from all over the world! Started in Australia, the pulse crew has grown to represent shows from the U.K., the Far East, All parts of the US including shows from San Fran, New York, Orlando and Miami, South Africa, Boston, and Toronto, Canada.
 
While this email originates with the DJ's of Daytrippin which airs every Saturday from 1-4pm EST, we wish to highlight other shows as well. Here is a small list of the shows broadcast each Saturday as well as their corresponding genre of dance music. For a complete list, visit www.pulseradio.net and view the 'full schedule' for the whole week!
 
ALL TIMES EASTERN STANDARD TIME
5-8am The FatPharm playing Breaks and Bootlegs (AU-Sydney)
10am-1pm Rhythmic Jungle Punch playing Jungle/Drum 'n' Bass (US-Orlando)
1pm-4pm Daytrippin playing House, leaning toward tech and funk (US-Orlando)
4pm-7pm Gettin Smitten playing House, D 'n' B, Downtempo (US-Orlando)
7pm-10pm Euphoric Excursions playing Trance, Prog House and Breaks (US-Orlando)
10pm-1am Energy Guide playing Breaks (US-Orlando)
**Also be sure to check out Evolve from Boston on Mondays 7pm-9pm EST 4pm-6pm PST**
 
 
 
Kindest Regards,
Buckner
vibe is alive    pulseradio.net

Subject: [sfraves] SRR...love parade, the parade of love

where it's now in the negative degrees with about a
foot of snow on the ground...brrrrr...

so, anyway...i might be in europe this summer and want
to possibly check out love parade, or any other edm
type events.  i went to the detroit electronic music
festival last year, and it was great, but i'm probably
going to have to miss it if i'm abroad.  hopefully, i
can make up for it with an equally cool european
experience...

but, i have some questions.

first of all, i can't find any site that actually says
when love parade happens.  anyone have some info about
this?  i have gathered the first of july from
www.loveparade.de and my minimal knowledge of german. 
but it wasn't very clear.

second of all, has anyone been to love parade?  is it
worth it?  has anyone been to any other european
events that i should check out?  also, are there any
clubs in london, glasgow, edinburgh, leipzig, berlin,
barcelona that are good to go to?

finally, is anyone planning on going abroad this
summer?  i'm going alone (most likely) and would love
to meet up and go partying with someone.

ok, so, thanks a bunch!

*emma*

>>Those of you into old school hip hop and electro funk -- Afrika Bambaataa 
>>will be at Club 6 on Saturday.  Already bought my tickets.
>>
>>  Afrika Bambaataa is one of the three main originators of break-beat 
>> deejaying, and is respectfully known as the "Grandfather" and 
>> "Godfather" of Hip Hop Culture as well as The Father of The Electro Funk 
>> Sound. Through his co-opting of the street gang the Black Spades into 
>> the music and culture-oriented Zulu Nation, he is responsible for 
>> spreading rap and hip-hop culture throughout the world. He has 
>> consistently made records nationally and internationally, every one to 
>> two years, spanning the 1980's into the next Millennium 2000.
>>
>>Due to his early use of drum machines and computer sounds, Bam (as he is 
>>affectionately known) was instrumental in changing the way R&B and other 
>>forms of Black music were recorded. His creation of Electro Funk, 
>>beginning with his piece "Planet Rock," helped fuel the development of 
>>other musical genres such as Freestyle or Latin Freestyle, Miami 
>>Bass,Electronica, House, Hip House, and early Techno.
>>
>>See you on the dance floor.
>>
>>Love,
>>
>>Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] post-New Year's Eve wrapup: Richard Humpty Vission & Planet NY

 > We recently had a thread about whether Richard Humpty Vission

Actually, I like RHV a lot.  Last time I saw him spin, I had a really 
good time, and enjoyed his set a lot.  And I wouldn't been disappointed 
at all if he were the headliner for a NYE party I had gone to.  Thing 
is tho.... last time I saw RHV play, I saw him for $15 (presale, I 
dunno the door price).  For $15, RHV is an awesome headliner.  He'd be 
kickass.... worth every penny.  I loved to see him spin before.  I'd 
love to see him spin again.

But I'm not going to pay coolworld prices for someone I can see 
elsewhere for $15.

And that's assuming that I trusted and respected coolworld enough to go 
to their parties, which I don't.  But there's no need to get into that 
again.

And aside from RHV, the only DJs I would have had much intrest in 
seeing were local to the bay area.  And I can see them at many other 
parties, which: are much smaller, priced with a recognition that the 
dotcom boom is over, have a friendlier and more intimate 
atmosphere/vibe, are thrown by local promoters instead of a 
corporation, treat their patrons with the respect and dignity we 
deserve, and actually go on ALL NIGHT ('Cuz going home at 2am, 
ESPECIALLY on New Years Eve, is just fuken lame.).


cya,
john

http://www.truthaboutrave.com/

Religion has no place in raves.

The raves are cool because you can be religious or non-religious and still
have fun.

 I believe whoever wrote this has probably never been to a rave and is
curled up in a corner hiding behind a bible like it's some sort of shield.

Notice how it says "Pictures from a rave" and not "Pictures from a rave tha=
t
I or we have been to."

Ravers tend to accept anyone, regardless of age, race, or socioeconomic
background. (Oh shit say it aint so Billy say it ain't so!!!)=A0 This
acceptance is good.(Oh good! I was worried for as sec.) =A0 However, many
young people seeking acceptance are drawn into the Rave and end up in using
drugs, (Uh-o, people being individulaies, thinking for themselves and being
responsible for the own actions....Oh shit what is this world coming to!!!)
=A0 associating with those who use drugs, and / or getting involved in
spirituality that is demonic. (Thinking for one's self, yeah I'd say that's
at the top of my list of demonic things.)

"They believe"  (Golly gee! It sounds like I'm part of a cult.  I'm scared
please hold me.)

Under the guise of Peace and Love, the devil is using music and drugs to
deceive masses of young people just as he did in the 60's and 70's.  (I
think somebody needs a hug.)

The power propelling the Rave movement is the music. (Man, those silent
raves really blow chunks!)

All the angels and lucifer sang and shouted together for joy when God set i=
n
motion the laying of the earth's foundation. (Cool!)=A0 But regardless,
singing / music in praise to God was the chief occupation of lucifer prior
to his fall.=A0 Never forget that. (Forget what?)=A0 That's the chief occupatio=
n
of all the angels. (Ravers um my bad I mean demonic dancers dance and sing
to celebrate God, life, or whatever they want.  Gee that's just horrible!)

The Bible reveals very clearly that music is a creation of God for the
purpose of praise to God.  (Yawn...BORING!!!!!  Music was created has a
means of expression and not just for brown nosing to God.)

The biblical evidence is clear.=A0 Music was created by God for the purpose o=
f
the worship of the One (suck up!), the True (suck up!), and the Almighty
(suck up!) ( Worthy (suck up!) God (Suck up! suck up! suck up! suck up!)

Um question:  If  I worshiped myself than that would mean I was worshiping
Satan and if I'm worshiping Satan than I'm not worshiping myself.  Sence I'=
m
not worshiping myself therefor I'm not worshiping Satan, correct?

RAVES ARE FILLED WITH SPIRITUAL MUSIC LEADING MASSES IN WORSHIP...BUT IN
WORSHIP TO WHOM? (Well me of course.)

Be honest, when you're listening to music or singing, when you are done wit=
h
it, will there be any inspiration to turn to God...to worship God...to turn
to His Word. (Life is my bible and music notes are my words.)

Satan and the fallen angels now inspire music in many different styles as
they seek to divert worship from God. (If you go to Samgoody they have many
selection and each one called "Popular".   Life would be so boring with onl=
y
one type of music.  What if the one song was that Jack in the box tune when
you crank the handle.  How would you like to hear that for the rest of your
life?)

There is music for every group, every age, every taste, and every culture.
(Thank you Satan.)

(I wonder if these people even listen to music.  Do they plug their ears
when birds sing?)

Mood-altering drugs are one of the main attraction in=A0the Rave scene. The
so-called "club drug" most commonly associated with Raves is
Methylenedioxymethamphetamine, or MDMA, commonly called:=A0 Ecstasy.=A0 It is a
synthetic drug created that temporarily alters the mood and mind but may
permanently damage the brain.  (Reading too much of this crap can also ruin
ones brain, so what your point?)

Is their a danger?
Rave parties involve many dangers that promoters would like to keep
undisclosed.=A0 Because of the easy availability of illegal drugs, it is not
uncommon to hear of validated cases of:=A0
=A0   =20
*    Drug overdose
*    Dehydration
*    Heat exhaustion
*    Heat Stroke
*    Brain damage
*    Depression
*    DUI=20
*    Death

    =A0(IF you don't know how to take care of yourself than don't go to
raves.)=20

The wages of sin is death -- Romans 6:23 (Does that mean if I don't sin I
wont die?  I wish I was told that sooner.) :`-(

 I remember many times that I gave or sold someone some ecstasy to "share
the love."=A0 The reality is that I was sharing a substance that destroys the
mind of those who consume it.=A0 Is that love?  (Yes, yes it is and what they
do with it is up to them.)

The Bilble say: Do not love the world nor the things in the world.  (Love
the world and the things in it.)
IF anyone loves the world, the love of the Father is not in him. (Why is Go=
d
a male and not a female, or a (hermaphrodite?  If God created the Earth tha=
n
why is it wrong to love something which was created?)
For all that is in the world, the lust of the flesh and lust of the eyes an=
d
the boastful pride of the life, is not from the Father, but is from the
world. (I have a lust for life.  To be saved should I stand in one place
with my eyes closed for the rest my life?)
The world is passing away, and also its lusts; but the one who does the wil=
l
of God lives forever.  (The will of God, that's another way of saying
servant to God.  I'm not God's slave.)

Are Raves Spiritual?
(Quote:) "Many young people who have no previous interest or awareness of
spirituality start to develop an interest in religious matters after
attending a few raves."=A0=A0 WHY?=A0 Because Raves are a spiritual movement !!
(Wait hold on a sec.....does that mean raves are good or bad? I'm confused.=
)

People coupling drugs with music experience trance states at parties that
often will lead to an interest in spirituality. -- THIS IS WHAT HAPPENED TO
ME PERSONALLY.=A0 I stumbled onto spirituality after attending Raves. (Is thi=
s
person sarcastically promoting raves, or putting them down? Is spirituality
evil or good?)

At a rave, the DJ is a shaman, a priest, a channeller of energy- they
control the psychic voyages of the dancers through his choice in
hard-to-find music and their skill in manipulating that music, sometimes
working with just a set of beats and samples, into a tapestry of mind
bending music. A large part of the concept of raves is built upon sensory
overload - a barrage of audio and very often visual stimuli are brought
together to elevate people into an altered state of physical or
psychological existence."
(That's lovely.)

What's wrong with spirituality?
The problem with the "New Age" spirituality in the Rave movement is that it
is the work of satan ( the devil ).
(If you stumbled onto spirituality at raves then that means you worship
Satan and you are a hypocrite.)

THE SPIRITUALITY=A0 FOUND=A0 IN=A0 THE=A0 RAVE SCENE IS DEMONIC=A0 AND=A0 ALL THOSE=A0
WHO=A0 DO NOT REPENT=A0 AND=A0 PUT=A0 THEIR=A0 FAITH=A0 IN=A0 THE ONE=A0 TRUE=A0 AND=A0 LIVING=A0
GOD,=A0 WHO CREATED=A0 THE=A0 HEAVENS=A0 AND=A0 THE=A0 EARTH,=A0 ARE=A0 IN=A0 IMMINENT=A0
DANGER=A0 OF=A0 BEING ETERNALLY=A0 SEPARATED FROM GOD --=A0 IN=A0 HELL  (At least we
will go out dancing and enjoying the pleasures of life while you hide behin=
d
words that are not your own and let life pass you by.)

I became involved in "New Age" mysticism / religion.=A0 Little did I know at
the time, it was all demonic!!
(*evil laughter* Woohahahaoooohaahaha!!!!! We fooled you good!)

Salvation
When I was 25,=A0 the true God of the Universe, the Lord Jesus Christ,
intervened in my life.=A0 He showed me the reality that the New Age Religion
is a religion based on false gods.  (Just how did he show you those things?=

This website is funny because it reminds me of a heated debate i once had 
with a friend of mine who is a hardcore christian. See i always felt very 
strongly that the rave scene was this gathering of masses, in tribal spirit, the 
essense the vibe the spirituality all accumilating growing growing growing 
throughout the populance of the world, which could eventually have potential to 
overthrow the establishment and create a new utopian world (new age of aquarious 
type of deal) most ravers tho would argue that raves are supposed to be 
underground and they're supposed to take u away from the worlds proplems not fight 
against them as   a "movement". Anyways when i brought this idea up to my friend 
(the christian) he was disgusted by it. the thought of raves accumilating 
massively throughout the world, because to him, this was discribed in the bible 
like in revelations or what not. it was said that nations would unite under a 
false prophecy, and this would be a sign of the anti-christ. the drugs the 
orgies the false sense of utopia, we were supposedly warned of all of this and 
we're supposed to know it means the end is near. me i don't buy it, it sure as 
hell interests me because it's so intense, i'd like to study it more or have some 
of ya'll sfr's enlighten me if u have knowledge on this topic.... but if i 
were inclined to believe anything as of now, i'd say that christ was manifested 
in the spirit of raving because it's like setting people free. to say that god 
was disgusted by raves, sounds like a hidden agenda to me... 

--part1_11c.2a1cf03a.2d2d25ef_boundary--

http://www.truthaboutrave.com/

Religion has no place in raves.

The raves are cool because you can be religious or non-religious and still
have fun.

 I believe whoever wrote this has probably never been to a rave and is
curled up in a corner hiding behind a bible like it's some sort of shield.

Notice how it says "Pictures from a rave" and not "Pictures from a rave tha=
t
I or we have been to."

Ravers tend to accept anyone, regardless of age, race, or socioeconomic
background. (Oh shit say it aint so Billy say it ain't so!!!)=A0 This
acceptance is good.(Oh good! I was worried for as sec.) =A0 However, many
young people seeking acceptance are drawn into the Rave and end up in using
drugs, (Uh-o, people being individulaies, thinking for themselves and being
responsible for the own actions....Oh shit what is this world coming to!!!)
=A0 associating with those who use drugs, and / or getting involved in
spirituality that is demonic. (Thinking for one's self, yeah I'd say that's
at the top of my list of demonic things.)

"They believe"  (Golly gee! It sounds like I'm part of a cult.  I'm scared
please hold me.)

Under the guise of Peace and Love, the devil is using music and drugs to
deceive masses of young people just as he did in the 60's and 70's.  (I
think somebody needs a hug.)

The power propelling the Rave movement is the music. (Man, those silent
raves really blow chunks!)

All the angels and lucifer sang and shouted together for joy when God set i=
n
motion the laying of the earth's foundation. (Cool!)=A0 But regardless,
singing / music in praise to God was the chief occupation of lucifer prior
to his fall.=A0 Never forget that. (Forget what?)=A0 That's the chief occupatio=
n
of all the angels. (Ravers um my bad I mean demonic dancers dance and sing
to celebrate God, life, or whatever they want.  Gee that's just horrible!)

The Bible reveals very clearly that music is a creation of God for the
purpose of praise to God.  (Yawn...BORING!!!!!  Music was created has a
means of expression and not just for brown nosing to God.)

The biblical evidence is clear.=A0 Music was created by God for the purpose o=
f
the worship of the One (suck up!), the True (suck up!), and the Almighty
(suck up!) ( Worthy (suck up!) God (Suck up! suck up! suck up! suck up!)

Um question:  If  I worshiped myself than that would mean I was worshiping
Satan and if I'm worshiping Satan than I'm not worshiping myself.  Sence I'=
m
not worshiping myself therefor I'm not worshiping Satan, correct?

RAVES ARE FILLED WITH SPIRITUAL MUSIC LEADING MASSES IN WORSHIP...BUT IN
WORSHIP TO WHOM? (Well me of course.)

Be honest, when you're listening to music or singing, when you are done wit=
h
it, will there be any inspiration to turn to God...to worship God...to turn
to His Word. (Life is my bible and music notes are my words.)

Satan and the fallen angels now inspire music in many different styles as
they seek to divert worship from God. (If you go to Samgoody they have many
selection and each one called "Popular".   Life would be so boring with onl=
y
one type of music.  What if the one song was that Jack in the box tune when
you crank the handle.  How would you like to hear that for the rest of your
life?)

There is music for every group, every age, every taste, and every culture.
(Should I thank God for kicking Satan out of heavean, or should I thank
Satan for creating the
different styles of music?  Oh wo is me, I'm so confused!)
(I wonder if these people even listen to music.  Do they plug their ears
when birds sing?)

Mood-altering drugs are one of the main attraction in=A0the Rave scene. The
so-called "club drug" most commonly associated with Raves is
Methylenedioxymethamphetamine, or MDMA, commonly called:=A0 Ecstasy.=A0 It is a
synthetic drug created that temporarily alters the mood and mind but may
permanently damage the brain.  (Reading too much of this crap can also ruin
ones brain, so what your point?)

Is their a danger?
Rave parties involve many dangers that promoters would like to keep
undisclosed.=A0 Because of the easy availability of illegal drugs, it is not
uncommon to hear of validated cases of:=A0
=A0   =20
*    Drug overdose
*    Dehydration
*    Heat exhaustion
*    Heat Stroke
*    Brain damage
*    Depression
*    DUI=20
*    Death

    =A0(IF you don't know how to take care of yourself than don't go to
raves.)=20

The wages of sin is death -- Romans 6:23 (Does that mean if I don't sin I
wont die?  I wish I was told that sooner.) :`-(

 I remember many times that I gave or sold someone some ecstasy to "share
the love."=A0 The reality is that I was sharing a substance that destroys the
mind of those who consume it.=A0 Is that love?  (Yes, yes it is and what they
do with it is up to them.)

The Bilble say: Do not love the world nor the things in the world.  (Love
the world and the things in it.)
IF anyone loves the world, the love of the Father is not in him. (Why is Go=
d
a male and not a female, or a (hermaphrodite?  If God created the Earth tha=
n
why is it wrong to love something which was created?)
For all that is in the world, the lust of the flesh and lust of the eyes an=
d
the boastful pride of the life, is not from the Father, but is from the
world. (I have a lust for life.  To be saved should I stand in one place
with my eyes closed for the rest my life?)
The world is passing away, and also its lusts; but the one who does the wil=
l
of God lives forever.  (The will of God, that's another way of saying
servant to God.  I'm not God's slave.)

Are Raves Spiritual?
(Quote:) "Many young people who have no previous interest or awareness of
spirituality start to develop an interest in religious matters after
attending a few raves."=A0=A0 WHY?=A0 Because Raves are a spiritual movement !!
(Wait hold on a sec.....does that mean raves are good or bad? I'm confused.=
)

People coupling drugs with music experience trance states at parties that
often will lead to an interest in spirituality. -- THIS IS WHAT HAPPENED TO
ME PERSONALLY.=A0 I stumbled onto spirituality after attending Raves. (Is thi=
s
person sarcastically promoting raves, or putting them down? Is spirituality
evil or good?)

At a rave, the DJ is a shaman, a priest, a channeller of energy- they
control the psychic voyages of the dancers through his choice in
hard-to-find music and their skill in manipulating that music, sometimes
working with just a set of beats and samples, into a tapestry of mind
bending music. A large part of the concept of raves is built upon sensory
overload - a barrage of audio and very often visual stimuli are brought
together to elevate people into an altered state of physical or
psychological existence."
(That's lovely.)

What's wrong with spirituality?
The problem with the "New Age" spirituality in the Rave movement is that it
is the work of satan ( the devil ).
(If you stumbled onto spirituality at raves then that means you worship
Satan and you are a hypocrite.)

THE SPIRITUALITY=A0 FOUND=A0 IN=A0 THE=A0 RAVE SCENE IS DEMONIC=A0 AND=A0 ALL THOSE=A0
WHO=A0 DO NOT REPENT=A0 AND=A0 PUT=A0 THEIR=A0 FAITH=A0 IN=A0 THE ONE=A0 TRUE=A0 AND=A0 LIVING=A0
GOD,=A0 WHO CREATED=A0 THE=A0 HEAVENS=A0 AND=A0 THE=A0 EARTH,=A0 ARE=A0 IN=A0 IMMINENT=A0
DANGER=A0 OF=A0 BEING ETERNALLY=A0 SEPARATED FROM GOD --=A0 IN=A0 HELL  (At least we
will go out dancing and enjoying the pleasures of life while you hide behin=
d
words that are not your own and let life pass you by.)

I became involved in "New Age" mysticism / religion.=A0 Little did I know at
the time, it was all demonic!!
(*evil laughter* Woohahahaoooohaahaha!!!!! We fooled you good!)

Salvation
When I was 25,=A0 the true God of the Universe, the Lord Jesus Christ,
intervened in my life.=A0 He showed me the reality that the New Age Religion
is a religion based on false gods.  (Just how did he show you those things?=

Subject: [sfraves] KLP... Matrix Relvelry Review

KLP = Kinda Late Post
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

it was kinda wierd 'cause i was jus like chillin' @ home on Sat night... then like Jaze calls me up & says "Hey, let's go party"!  So I got ready & like we went 2 that Matrix party!!

It was hella fun man!  I mean... it wasn't as packed as that venue usually gets & I think that's what I enjoyed... it was like good size crowd, Groovy energy... met some Awesome people that night & ran in2 a few people I ain't seen in a while!!  WHAT UP TRHATTER! =)  LoL... it was hella funny 'cause like there were a few people there that said, "Osby, What are You doing here?" Hello 2Day... I was there 2 dance! =) =P

OK.. there were like mondo DJs spinning that night... but my fave sets were Michael Lui... he spun this Bad ass set like ya know... he 1st started spinning BreakBeats!!  OK... YUMMMMM!!!  LoL.. .it was actually funny 'cause I went behind the tables & picked up his head phones 'cause I wanted 2 mix the 1st record of his set... but like i soooooo didn't know where the head phone switcher thingie was on the mixer, but her, i gotta pick the 1st record though!!  It was Dope... 'cause he kept the Break beats goin on 4 a long time then ofcourse he slooooooowly went in2 his Psytrance stuff... it was a fun set!!

Ummm... Peter-Go-Zania & Leon Cook played this Groovy set... OK... from what I remember... there started out spinning a lil' Jungle @ the begining.. then I heard a ?Trancecore? track.. then they like totally went dtrait up in2 Happy Hardcore most the rest of the set!!  I LOVED IT!!  It was so fun dancing!

I also like Owl's set! She stayed like on the dark trance tip & I don't think i remember her spinning like any like industrial tracks in her trance set like she did that 1 time b4 when i saw her spin last...

But overall.. the party was fun! I had fun seein' alota familiar faces, groovin' the night away, oh oh oh, then there was a lil' after party thingie @ oh oh oh... so like there's this dude i met like @ a party mondo back in the day... lol... i didn't see him again 'til that night & it was so Dope catchin' up... so he had like this lil' get 2gether @ his pad after the party... i bought some food @ the gas station & some sour peach circle thingies... LoL... so i ended up sharin' my pizza pocket w/ people there & my sour peaches candy w/ every1!!  Oh yeah.. I also discovered that I fuckin' rock playing Mortal Combat on X Box! =) LoL

So yeah... Sat night/ Sunday morning was fun times... there was a lill' drama that kinda went on la la la & well.. I should mention that Blondie Tard only remembers me when she's like rollin 'cause when she ain't... she's kinda mean 2 me sometimes & don't remembner me... LoL... but she wasn't the major cause of drama... jus' thought i'd mention her...

OK... have a good Midweek & I shall see most of y'all on Thursday I hope.. I dunno where I"m gonna be yet... but yeah!

Good Times!

Take Care,
Peace-> ObY {8O)

--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] breaks / progressive house weeklies in SF??

Yes... what Phillip said and toss in the fact that gba hasn't even been
living here up until a few weeks ago.

I've seen plenty of breaks based events or that have a heavy breaks flavor.
First thing that comes to mind is Saturday nights at The Top in Lower Haight
(Webster@Haight). It's put on by some high quality dj's.

Progressive house - SF - Progression at 26 Mix (every 3rd sunday i think?).
There is another event in the south bay that's progressive. Look for people
like Macadio or Jack Triumph and you'll find progressive house.

first off, pay no mind to people who say 'breaks are dead'.  how can
having too many people playing it be a bad thing? just means that you
have to know where to look...

breaks lineup, strong, cheap booze, and no cover. here's the details:




Thursday, January 8th

CosmicProductions and AuraSF Present UPLIFT!

Shake your money maker to the sounds of breaks, house and broken beats.

records, refined music, viberation)

Iyad (AuraSF, hosstribe)
Koroma (AuraSF)

JC (AuraSF)

Every Second Thursday
7PM to 2AM

GO TO THIS PARTY. You can't get any closer to living out a movie like 16
Candles and starring all of your favorite 80's icons. Long Duck Dong, Yahoo
Serious, Michael Anthony Hall, and others will be in attendance. Only 150
people get to go so this will be just like that old prom from way back when
your date puked up dinner on your rented tux then proceded to get half naked
and do the Localmotion. Or was it the Roger Rabbit? Hmmm...

Basically if you're a fashion victim that's buying into the 80's revival
look and loves *electro-clash* you'll be in heaven. You'll get to see the
original clothes and hear the original music. So no matter if you were only
5 years old when the 80's hit their peak, you can turn back the clock and
get a taste of what your older siblings had. =D

Only $5??

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Calamity Jane" <scarpetta80@yahoo.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, January 06, 2004 7:25 PM
Subject: [sfraves] *bsp* forever young!


about a month ago i breathed word about an 80's party.
 mark you calendars for 01/31/04 cuz it's going down!
your chauffeurs into the den of swank, hair product
decadence, and voracious fashion statements will be:

sticky (ambient mafia, sf)
DJ R (bz, stargaze, sf)
naru (stargaze, SR, la)
shazbot (moksha tribe, newstylesound, sf)
drop (bz, ambient mafia, sf)
dj aryn (aec, viberation, sf)
indigo (ambient mafia, sf)
dj bam (invibe.com, sf)

upon arriving, we'll escort the willing to a photo
setup where the lovely araya will capture that
auspicious, sappy moment before your makeup runs and
there's nothing left of your dignity.  there will be
punch (i highly recommend you try some) & trashy
snacks, but remember this is a BYOB affair if you need
*more* than that.  as a reminder - dress the f*ck up!
it's fun, easy, relatively cheap, and you won't be
alone ;)  you can recreate this party to be the prom
you never went to because chad, the page-haired poet
who led debate class, didn't ask you to go, or this
can be the moment where you cry up to the 80's gods
'damn i look fine in my stone-washed hammer pants and
screw you all if you who made fun of me when i sang
along to NKOTB's 'step by step'.  ah, the
possibilities are endless :)

this event is going on for 3 reasons.  i f*cking love
the 80's (troll away), any excuse to get everyone
under one roof and have a good time is a damn fine
reason for getting out of the house, but most
importantly, we're raising money to help the epiphane
crew pay off the fine they received at their last
event.  tickets are only $5 which can be purchased via
paypal on the evite i'm sending out;  donations are
definitely encouraged if you'd like to pitch in more.
i've already gotten some email addresses, but if you'd
like to go, email me privately so i can add you to the
roster.  this venue is limited to 150 capacity so get
on this now before we fill up!

happy new year to everyone, here's hoping you
recovered nicely ;)

calamity bombatitty

-----Original Message-----
From: JBlaze112@aol.com [mailto:JBlaze112@aol.com]
Sent: Tuesday, January 06, 2004 3:15 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] Matrix Revelry Review


U know I have to admit, when i first got the flier to this party i had a bit
of that... *rolls eyes* feeling. like o my god matrix revelry oookkkk
because
i remember sugesting to someone who was planing a party to make it matrix
but
then we decided it was too cliche and people wouldn't like it. because a lot
of people didn't like the last two movies and what not. Anyhoo, out of a
string
of bizare coincidences my friends and i (including Osby!) ended up attending
this party. & of course we showed up in costume and got in for $10, there's
no
way were gonna pay $20 for that bush and van ness venue. so we show up at
the
party, & low & behold... it actually kicked ass. The decorations were bad
ass, they had a projector in one chill room playing all the matrix movies
with
sound and everything, i enjoyed that. In another room all of the walls were
compleately decked up in matrix code, which was just awsome. and all the
other
rooms were just all black and with everyone in costume and what not they
managed
to give a matrix feel all night long. I'm not big into DJ's per se, i just
like good music so i couldn't tell you who's sets were good that night but i
do
remember Tamim's set was off the hook. and it was impressive to see micheal
lui
once again. I have to mention that none of us ingested a single drug and we
had a blast, we even went to an after party in emeryville and met a lots of
cool people. I'm taking this party as a sign that the scene is back in
effect.
Granted, yes people do not as often come up and give you hugs and let u play
with their lil fuzzy toys while they express how much they love you. Granted
yes
you may catch a few mean mugs from some thugs or get bumbed into by a group
of
rambunctious pre-teens while you're trying to dance, but all & all the music
is still good, it's still fun to dance, still meeting lots of cool people &
we're still on the edge of something very different than what everyone else
does
on their fri-sat nights. i'm proud of all the old school heads i keep
running
into since the 90's, all the people who just keep going, who've endured
through all the talk of "the scene is dying/dead" and what not. Anyways...
not to
keep ranting, this is just my review for the party. Good job guys... whoever
threw this party i already forgot their crew's name, elektro... something er
other, u know who u r.
     moral of the story is don't doubt a party that seems "cliche" at first
because it just might actually kick ass in the end. - Jaze



---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

this is a fictional piece that we are starting this year...a weekly installation that will either change each week or continue from week to week depending on how good it gets. this week's is a brief character sketch:
 
joe weaved in and out of the crowd, hat in hand, a smile on his face, a yearning in his heart...it had started badly and ended worse, but a night out should fix that...it used to anyway. he had a burnt out lighter in his pocket that she'd given him many years ago. he knew that he needed someone, but not her this time, that was for sure. hopefully, the music would be to his liking. hopefully, he'd just blend right in. he lowered his head, and put his hat on top, tipping the brim down nice and low...:)

yo daniel,

i did "open my fucking eyes":  you've been complaining about SF
nonstop since you got here.  

tell you what:  let me know what kind of music you like, the
type of people you hope to meet, and i'll do my best to
personally take you out and show you a good time in the city.

deal?  if you don't have fun, feel free to rip on SF all you
want.  i think most of my friends will agree that i know how to
have a good time...

m

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Uhh.. Richard Humpty Vision as a headliner?

Damn...and you just can't argue with that. The man is offering to take you 
out personally...that's pretty damn cool.

I haven't been out much here, but the few times I've made it out, I've had a 
great time. Way better than back in DC as far as I'm concerned. Not to try 
and sound like I'mtaking sides or anything, but I've partied in New York a 
rack of times, and while they have some phat venues and dj's there, the 
crowds are a bunch of shitheads for the most part (unless you're talking the 
Sunday afternoon House weeklies). Any of the huge "raves" put on there are 
filled with underage dust heads and tweekers, not to mention shady ass gangs 
roving through the parties. The clubs are generally euro-trash to the nth 
degree...I don't know why anyone sweats New York....

M-

first half was not up to par with what i've heard in the past.

if you were there, you might have seen me sitting behind mr.
hawtin on the little stairs leading up to the DJ booth (on the
right).  best seat in the house.  ;)

if you want more of the stuff of that nature, then we're
totally on the same page.  i'll keep my eyes open and let you
know.  techno is strong in the bay area:  you just need to know
where to look.

m

Date: Thu, 8 Jan 2004 11:56:07 -0800 (PST)
From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040108115120.W95701@taz3.hyperreal.org>
SFRaves<-_->http: //www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: (News) Expanded surveillance powers


http://www.wired.com/news/privacy/0,1848,61792,00.html

Bush Grabs New Power for FBI

By Kim Zetter  |   Also by this reporter Page 1 of 2 next =BB

02:00 AM Jan. 06, 2004 PT

While the nation was distracted last month by images of Saddam Hussein's
spider hole and dental exam, President George W. Bush quietly signed into
law a new bill that gives the FBI increased surveillance powers and
dramatically expands the reach of the USA Patriot Act.

The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004 grants the FBI
unprecedented power to obtain records from financial institutions without
requiring permission from a judge.

Under the law, the FBI does not need to seek a court order to access such
records, nor does it need to prove just cause.

Previously, under the Patriot Act, the FBI had to submit subpoena requests
to a federal judge. Intelligence agencies and the Treasury Department,
however, could obtain some financial data from banks, credit unions and
other financial institutions without a court order or grand jury subpoena
if they had the approval of a senior government official.

The new law (see Section 374 of the act), however, lets the FBI acquire
these records through an administrative procedure whereby an FBI field
agent simply drafts a so-called national security letter stating the
information is relevant to a national security investigation.

And the law broadens the definition of "financial institution" to include
such businesses as insurance companies, travel agencies, real estate
agents, stockbrokers, the U.S. Postal Service and even jewelry stores,
casinos and car dealerships.

The law also prohibits subpoenaed businesses from revealing to anyone,
including customers who may be under investigation, that the government
has requested records of their transactions.

Bush signed the bill on Dec. 13, a Saturday, which was the same day the
U.S. military captured Saddam Hussein.

Some columnists and bloggers have accused the president of signing the
legislation on a weekend, when news organizations traditionally operate
with a reduced staff, to avoid public scrutiny and criticism. Any
attention that might have been given the bill, they say, was supplanted by
a White House announcement the next day about Hussein's capture.

James Dempsey, executive director of the Center for Democracy &
Technology, didn't see any significance to the timing of Bush's signing.
The 2004 fiscal year began Oct. 1 and the Senate passed the bill in
November. He said there was pressure to pass the legislation to free up
intelligence spending.

However, Dempsey called the inclusion of the financial provision "an
intentional end-run" by the administration to expand the administration's
power without proper review.

Critics like Dempsey say the government is trying to pass legislation that
was shot down prior to the U.S. invasion of Iraq, when the Bush
administration drafted a bill to expand the powers of the Patriot Act.

The so-called Patriot Act II was discovered by the Center for Public
Integrity last year, which exposed the draft legislation and initiated a
public outcry that forced the government to back down on its plans.

But critics say the government didn't abandon its goals after the uproar;
it simply extracted the most controversial provisions from Patriot Act II
and slipped them surreptitiously into other bills, such as the
Intelligence Authorization Act, to avoid raising alarm.

Dempsey said the Intelligence Authorization Act is a favorite vehicle of
politicians for expanding government powers without careful scrutiny. The
bill, because of its sensitive nature, is generally drafted in relative
secrecy and approved without extensive debate because it is viewed as a
"must-pass" piece of legislation. The act provides funding for
intelligence agencies.

"It's hard for the average member to vote against it," said Dempsey, "so
it makes the perfect vehicle for getting what you want without too much
fuss."

The provision granting increased power was little more than a single line
of legislation. But Dempsey said it was written in such a cryptic manner
that no one noticed its significance until it was too late.

"We were the first to notice it outside of Congress," he said, "but we
only noticed it in September after it had already passed in the House."

Rep. Porter Goss (R-Florida), chairman of the House Intelligence Committee
that reviewed the bill, introduced the legislation into the House last
year on June 11, where it passed two weeks later by a vote of 410-9. The
Senate passed the bill by unanimous consent on July 31.

Goss's staff said he was out of the country and unavailable for comment.
But Goss told the House last year that he believed the financial
institution provision in the bill brought the intelligence community up to
date with the reality of the financial industry.

"This bill will allow those tracking terrorists and spies to 'follow the
money' more effectively and thereby protect the people of the United
States more effectively," he said.

But Rep. Betty McCollum (D-Minnesota), who opposed the legislation, told
the House, "It is clear the Republican leadership and the administration
would rather expand on the USA Patriot Act through deception and secrecy
than debate such provisions in an open forum."

Despite her remarks, however, McCollum voted in favor of the legislation.

A number of other representatives expressed concern that the financial
provision was slipped into the Intelligence Act at the 11th hour with no
time for public debate and against objections from members the Senate
Judiciary Committee, which normally has jurisdiction over the FBI. Sen.
Patrick Leahy (D-Vermont), the minority leader of the Senate Judiciary
Committee, along with five other members of the Judiciary Committee, sent
a letter to the Intelligence Committee requesting that their committee be
given time to review the bill. But the provision had already passed by the
time their letter went out.

"In our fight to protect America and our people, to make our world a safer
place, we must never turn our backs on our freedoms," said Rep. C.L.
"Butch" Otter (R-Idaho) in a November press release. "Expanding the use of
administrative subpoenas and threatening our system of checks and balances
is a step in the wrong direction."

Otter, however, also voted in favor of the bill.

Charlie Mitchell, legislative counsel for the American Civil Liberties
Union, said many legislators failed to recognize the significance of the
legislation until it was too late. But he said the fact that 15
Republicans and over 100 Democrats voted against the Conference Report of
the bill indicated that, had there been more time, there probably would
have been sufficient opposition to remove the provision.

"To have that many people vote against it, based on just that one
provision without discussion beforehand, signifies there is strong
opposition to new Patriot Act II powers," Mitchell said.

He said legislators are now on the lookout for other Patriot Act II
provisions being tucked into new legislation.

"All things considered, this was a loss for civil liberties," he said. But
on a brighter note, "this was the only provision of Patriot II that made
it through this year. Members are hearing from their constituents. I
really think we have the ability to stop much of this Patriot Act II
legislation in the future."

**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

Subject: [sfraves] n.r.r. -- adventures in trying to get employed still....

ok.. so like on Monday i had this interview 4 this Toy Company & well... everything seemed Groovy & the boss guy ceo dude really liked me & told me he wanted me 2 start working on Weds. so come in2 orientation on Tues... which i did... he told me school wasn't gonna be a problem, i made a perfect fit in the company, he was really impressed w/ my past work history, la la la la la... I mean... I answered an ad in the paper for a toy company looking 4 toy testers which is what i thought i was applying for....

So i went 2 orientation on like Tuesday & like well... i walked in the deo dude's office after they had their morning cheerleading circle thingie behind closed doors & EVERYTHING he told me the day b4 during the interview he totally contradicted everything he said 2 me @ that moment.. it was soooooo dumb... he's dumb... lame lame lame X 10000000...

he told me that my school & study group hours would interfere w/ my work hours so he basically was encouraging me 2 drop out of school like most of his lackies have done & some1 i talk 2 did... yeah... it was depressing...

so since i was in San Leandro & kinda depressed... i ate brunch @ La Pinata #2 while reading my people magazine & called Aryck... so him & I spent most the whole day 2gether & well... I got pierced again YAAAAAAAAAY & kinda enhanced my other piercing!!! Hey AK.. Thanks 4 bein' there 4 me yet again!! 

So yeah... what a fuckin' week it's been so far & man.. i still gotta do homework b4 i go 2 class 2night... lol...

but yeah... i'm confident i'm gonna start working soon.... Jaze is gonna help me w/ something...

Have a Groovy Day & well.. I still dunno where i'm going 2night but hopefully C some of U there... Lol =)

Sorry 4 the rant.. buti wanted 2 tell y'all about my new poke! =) LoL

hmmmmmmmmm

Take Care,

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I am up here in Portland OR and pretty much stranded. I am sure my
neighbors are laughing at me as I try to get my cheap ass cable chains
on my tires. What's worse is when I get them on drive half a block and
lose one and don't realize it until I pull into the gas station that
sucked. I went back and could here a neighbor outside chuckling. Damn I
grew up in AZ and I really have no idea about chains. When I lived in
the bay I never went to the slopes so I never had to worry about chains.
And what's worse is with cable chains you cannot go faster than 30 mph
which you really don't realize how slow that is until you are stuck
doing it. Well just thought I would share my snow experiences with you
all. We had 5 inches of snow on Tuesday and then freezing rain all
yesterday and last night. It looks like the area should thaw tonight and
tomorrow. Peace

 

Jason

hello, just a reminder for the new readers that this is soley a fictional read here. for fun and hopefully, less boring times, we are introducing a weekly fictional column here. this week's read has been a brief character sketch...kind of an interesting fellow, so we might stretch out his life through next week, depending  on how the creator(s) feel about it:

the club was filled with purple light and an echoing magnetic haze of sound fused with sweat and movement. joe slumped low in the corner at his favorite table. things began to look up in his world just momentarily and then moved back down into darkness. strange. this release he felt. he couldn't stop thinking about the theme to "the crying game" either. secretly, it was one of his favorites. he'd always kept that to himself. :)

Subject: [sfraves] SFLNC News for the New Year

--=====================_17312243==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::

::The Birth of the Entertainment Commission:::::

Last July, we saw the reality of the Entertainment Commission that we 
helped to conceive and create. Yes, you CAN change City Hall, and the 
Entertainment Commission is proof. The seven-person EC (whose president is 
our chairperson Terrance Alan) reviews entertainment permit applications 
the first and third Tuesday each month.

The public is welcome to attend as this panel representing neighborhoods, 
police, planning, medical services and the entertainment industry considers 
how to permit entertainment businesses and events and keep neighborhoods 
safe and secure. This new system is much more responsive and broad-based 
than the old process, and though procedures are still being created, it's 
clearly a good idea.

To learn more, and for upcoming meeting schedules and agendas, as well as 
minutes of past meetings, visit their website at 
http://sfgov.org/site/entertainment_index.asp. Better still, make the time 
to see the EC in action by attending a meeting. This new structure is a 
great thing for our city, and we hope it will become a model for other 
cities as well.


::Advocates for Nightlife and Entertainment at City Hall and in Sacramento:::::

Our Legislative Director, John Wood, works to represent the interests and 
perspective of the nightlife community at City Hall. This year, successes 
include:

- Castro Halloween - We worked in conjunction with the Entertainment 
Commission and Supervisor Bevan Dufty to transform what had become an 
unruly and often dangerous event into an organized, peaceful and fun 
San-Francisco-style party again. It was a beautiful thing, and many 
volunteer organizations participated, raising funds to benefit many 
nonprofit organizations in the city.

- Loudspeaker Permits - It may seem a small thing, but it was only fair; we 
pushed for a re-interpretation of permit fees so that free non-commercial 
events now pay the reduced non-profit fee rates for Loudspeaker permits.

- One-Night Permits - This has been a high priority for us because many 
great entertainment events happen in venues that aren't regularly used for 
entertainment, such as galleries or safe warehouse spaces. We helped 
develop rules and regulations to allow the issuance of one-night 
entertainment event permits for these kinds of venues.

- Ins and Outs - The SFPD had routinely been inserting "no ins and outs" 
stipulations into extended hours permits, and we successfully argued 
against this policy. The Entertainment Commission has adopted a policy of 
allowing ins and outs unless there is a clear need to restrict them for a 
specific venue.

- 18-and-over Venues
We worked with the San Francisco Youth Commission to create legislation 
that will all venues licensed for 18-and-over to apply for extended hours 
permits. Supervisor Bevan Dufty has introduced this legislation to the 
Board of Supervisors, and there will be public hearings in January. Visit 
www.sfgov.org/site/youth_commission_index.asp to learn more about the Youth 
Commission.


::Changing Last Call for California:::::

Many of the major destination cities in the U.S. allow alcohol sales after 
2am, including New York City, Miami, Chicago and New Orleans. We want 
California's major cities (San Francisco, Los Angeles, San Diego and San 
Jose) to be competitive in attracting more tourism to the city, and there 
are statistics that indicate a later last call is much safer on the roads 
as well. We have developed a proposal to allow these cities to choose to 
extend "last call" for on-site alcohol sales. Check out 
www.sfbg.com/38/13/x_sonic_reducer.html to see what the Bay Guardian has to 
say about it.


::Club Summit:::::

We've begun planning a "Club Summit" for the spring where entertainment 
permit holders, promoters, nightlife employees and clubgoers can learn 
about recent changes in entertainment policy, meet Entertainment 
Commissioners and other city officials, and work together to transform San 
Francisco back into a world-class entertainment city. If you want to make 
sure to be in the invite list for this event, send an email to 
leslie@sflnc.com and we'll put you on the list.


::For Your Benefit::::

We'll keep working to build our membership, from individuals and 
businesses, and through other means -- whatever it takes. Part of this is 
because we need to raise money to keep going - and one of the most fun ways 
to do that is to ask promoters to do benefits for the SFLNC. We'll be 
contacting you to invite you to participate in a month-long event to raise 
awareness and money for the SFLNC and our work. But you can beat the crowd 
-- send an email to leslie@sflnc.com if you'd like to designate one of your 
club nights or events as a fundraiser for the SFLNC. It's a great way to 
participate in our work.

And if you're someone with a website or email list dedicated to 
entertainment and nightlife, we'll be asking you to link to our site as 
well -- the more we can spread the word, the more we can accomplish.


::A Membership Organization:::::

We became a member-based organization in 2003, and we want you to join. 
It's an easy and affordable way to keep us going -- since we're YOUR 
political action committee. Just visit http://sflnc.com/index/donate/ and 
join today. Yes, every member does make a difference!


Made it this far? Thanks for reading, and for your continued support of the 
SFLNC. See you on the dancefloor in 2004!




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

needed break from the stress that has been dealt with lately.

But on that note, I want to send huge amounts of negativity to the
person that tonite thought it was cute to steak the yellow and black
knitted hat of my girlfriend.

DON'T YOU KNOW IT WAS HER HAT SHE KNITTED HERSELF TO HIDE THE FACT THAT
SHE IS A CANCER PATIENT???

I hope you feel a huge amount of shame as you gaze at it with no sense
of connection to it in the morning -- I mean seriously, what kind of
stupid excuse do YOU have for stealing it from a goddamn cancer
patient?! 

I hope you think long and hard about what you did and that you have the
moral integrity to return it. 

Thanks.

-tim.

would have liked. I guess that happens when you catch a ride with someone
else.

Great place, almost scary basement, lol and was awesome to see Will, Andy,
JC, Joey Frisco, my man Ossby, DJ Bam and that crazy dancing cat Jeff whom I
met from Seattle. Got to meet a lot of new friends...There is a definite
feeling of family at this event and everyone is welcomed very warmly.
Looking forward to next week, great event guys. I will be sure to drive
myself so I can stay longer. Good tunes; everything from breaks to jungle to
progressive, all bangin on a nice sound system.

lady. I don't think it is a bad thing to show your anger tim....it is a
really screwed up situation, especially considering and all. Without hate,
you cannot have love. Even if the person in question didn't realize the
circumstances, that is no excuse for stealing regardless..not real sure I
follow your point Danny. Stealing is never explainable, or excusable. It
ain't cool to be a jive turkey so close to Christmas.

Anyway, in closing, I hope the hat is returned, and I have give this event
big thumbs up.
