MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Request: Mix Tapes (specific artists) 

This might be a long shot, but along with my CD and Waxx collection, I
also still listen to mixtapes (there's still a tape deck in my car
too baby)

I am looking for the following mix tapes (*willing to
purchase/trade)

Carlos,Powerhouse: High energy house with some dj tricks.

Carlos,Illusion: House and ravey techno/house, scratching.

Carlos,MDMA: Very nice house, vocal yet energetic.

Carlos,Love is the Law: side one is house and acid trance, side two is
smooth house, dj tricks include equalization manipulation.

Carlos, Deep: As the title suggests this is not a scratching high energy
Carlos, this is a sensitive warm tape.with no cover.

Dan,Live Mixes: Double pack from Organic, Funky Techno Tribe and
Come/Unity. Big hits; high energy house and some acidy stuff + vocals. 2
for$16.

Dan,Double pack1&2: One tape is a tribute to James Brown, funky with
tracks and mixes using JB. The live tape is more ravey funky techno
bits-o-breaks. 2 for $16.

Dan,Doublepack 3&4: This one is high energy Dan, not hardcore but not that
housey. 2 for $16

Dan,Jolly House Jams: Big flavorful house !

Dan, Funky Green Project: Perhaps one of the strangest tapes I have ever
heard. House and ravey techno and back again , alot happens in this 90
min. of high energy.

Dan,S.F.Housing Project:

Dan,House the Discoteque:

Dan,Wicked Burning Frenzy: In his own opinion , the best hardcore tape he
ever made, Breakbeat hardcore techno.

Dan-Ron D Core,DX2 #1: "the Anthem" and other harcore rave hits and wistle
blowing madness.

Dan-Ron D Core,DX2 #2: Tape includes original release by Dan and X-pando.
Both sides hardcore techno, Dan has more breakbeat.

Dan-Ron D Core,DX2 #3:

Doran, 2010: Pretty trance of the kind that might get played at the 2010
olympics.

Doran, Innocence: Pretty trance with spine tingly moments of bliss!

Doran,Paradigms: Trance this time a bit dryer and more serious.

Doran, Eternity: This is a step further than the pretty trance he usually
mixes. This is an excursion into Nu-energy Mount Olympus Style Ambrosia!

DRC,the Jungle:from '92 tribal house with an edge.

DRC,Psychotropical: This has more trance and less house and very tribal
with some exotica flavor.

DRC,Irontale:The hardest yet. Hard tribal techno with an industrial flair,
moments of breakbeat, cyborg on cover sez it all.

DRC,Ritual Addiction:tribal-trance with an exotica flavor . Some house
too.

DRC,Eargasmika: Tribal trance/house deep not sappy , intricate yet not
manic.

DRC, In Between Worlds: Trancey German sounds with an anti-heroin theme.

DRC, Programed: Drc said this was stuff she has been playing for the last
year. It is banging acid trance with some high-energy flavor near the end.

Dutch,Escapades in Trance:Limited Double Pack of trance/progressive house
hits of '93. Nice package and coloured tapes.

Dutch,The Funky Void:Trancey ravey tape. Sounds of the good 'ol days.

Dutch,Aphrodisiac: House side and acid side both deep yet not swishy.

Dutch,Burning Chrome: Acid techno and trance , thankfuly not progressive
more quality electronica.

Dutch, Panopticon: This is a mixed Goa Trance tape (a rare thing). TIP
influenced. One side is "prettier" than the other.

Dutch, Area 51 Live

Evil Eddie Richards, A Private Party: Tech-House with energy yet smooth. A
live tape from "By the People" with cover art by Owen.

Garth,Skunk Funk: Percusive, non-vocal high energy tribal house.

Garth,EZ Skankin: Vocal house mixed into psycedelic bouncey trip.

Garth,Share: Smooth mature blends of UMMish house.

Garth, Come Down Massive: Morning tribal. Relaxed yet intense percusive
journey.

Garth,Break it Down: hard fast funky house, lots of flavor and energy.

Garth,Smokin: House,deep and acidy ,not much vocals. Incredible mixing
makes it so you can never again hear one song with out thinking of the
next.

Garth, Feel the Love:

Garth, Feel the Vibe:

Garth, House Nation:

Garth, No Rest For the Wicked: Cd of good moovin funky disco tribal acid
house.

Garth, Gangster Groove 3: Bootlegged at Pure Space this one was good
enough to be put out more than a year (maybe 2) after the recording was
made. Acid House with some classics.

Garth, Discover: Live at Come/Unity upbeat funky house with other flavors
mixed in.

Garth, Superjams: Sunrise session Wicked '96. House with Disco and Funk
flavors lots of guitar, horn, keybord musical stuff. And it's Phat too!

Garth , Live in LA: From a wicked in LA , more funky house .this one's
kind of heavy.

Garth, Live Come/Unity 10/2/96: This is the Garth you either hate or you
love. Starting with Guitar based House with trippy sound effects and
ending in Disco-Pop. Garth tweaks the mix on side 2 and makes disco go
mental.

Graeme, Live at FUTUR: Ultra trippy cosmic wizard acid house.

Graeme, Live at Simon's: We have heard so frequently that Simon's in
Florida goes off... This is definately the best Graeme tape I have heard.
Techno-trance with guts and grace and wierdness.

Graeme, Spectrum: Organic techno-trance with some tribal acid House flair.
Super cool.

Gavin Hardkiss, 1st Glimpse:

Goa Gil, Alpha,Beta,Delta,Theta,Omega: The Summer 5 tape set as usual is
ordered with a theme and purpose theoretically designed to reflect a full
evening of Goa trance and all the states one may achieve. $15 per tape.
$75.00 total.

Ghost / Frank Nitty, Funky Enough?: These are the main DJ's of the East
Bay circle dancing festivals. They know what flys and they know whats
Phat. Major props to these guys for hanging tight and providing the toons
to a dangerous generation. Breaks, Funky Acid, Hella Tight!!

Jeno,Inside the Mind: The tape many say is the proof that San Francisco
rules all. Thoughtful, psychadelic, deep and groovy. Acid house.

Jeno,Bang the drum: Less acid more rythm this tape will never give you a
headache.

Jeno,We Are Phuture: Acid house full of acid hits. Electric.

Jeno, Energy:

Jeno, Rise:

Jeno, House Reality:

Jeno, Soul Creation: After 3 live releases some thought this home tape
might never be made. Acid House starting with some vocal tracks and
getting mental yet groovy.

Jeno, Come-Unity 5 year: Groovy yet mental, This tape is one you could
listen to forever.

Jeno, CU live 7/3/96: This one has some house flavors but is a bit harder
than any "official" tape by Jeno. Acid House at a sweaty full on night at
1015.

Jeno, Live at the Deep: The Deep was a party in Santa Cruz this was the
last night. It is a chugging make you dance House tape with even a small
break in there, John Madden sample. A Must have for any fan of the S.F.
sound.

John Howard,Movin' On: Deep house,vocals, almost acid jazz live Aug. 27th

John Howard,Below Low:

John Howard,Nite Jungle:

John Howard, Live in Dallas w/15 min o'Mark Farina: Cop Show House, Funky
chase scene soundtrack.

John Howard, Live at the Jungle, Hawaii: Magnum PI has got nothing on John
Howard! Funky breaky cop show chase with electro interludes. Some one
bumped the table so this one has a boo-boo but its $10 cause John loves
you baby!

John Howard, Live at Sunset: Fun House from Sunset (Pacific's free summer
outdoor weekly) I think during one of the boat parties. Nobody plays funky
house like John.

John Howard, The John Howard Sound Experience: Cop Show chase scene and
deep funky house. Butt Wiglin' Fat Ass John Howard -Yes!

Josh, The Gathering: I suppose this was the December 1996 Gathering at
Home Base in Oakland, CA. 1st one I missed but now I got a tape. Josh used
to play last and play morning music, but this is more middle of the party
Progressive Funky Stuff.

Mark Farina, House Construction: Understated but not minimal this is a
house tape you can listen to over and over and there never occurs a moment
which makes you think you should change the tape.

Moonpup, Beets 4 Freaks: CD mixed Triphop - The Pup is Back!

Polywog, This is the Shit: The lady who invented ecclectic, Jungle
.childrens music, Dub..

Polywog, In Tha Mood: Jungle and Seventies Rock.

Polywog, This is the Shit: The lady who invented ecclectic, Jungle
.childrens music, Dub..

Polywog, In Tha Mood: Jungle and Seventies Rock.

Rick Preston, Helix: House grooves with a Chicago track or two, Deep
non-vocal and solid.

Ron D. Core,Acid Test 2: Its a double with packaging , candy, 1 tape is
old acid-good stuff but not ron -like. tape 2 is new acid !

Ron D. Core,No Doz:

Ron D. Core,Acid Test:

Ron D. Core,Born in the South:

Ron D. Core,Psychotic Episodes:

Ron D. Core, Robin,Possessed:

Ron D. Core, Louis Love, Vynil Meltdown:

Ron D. Core, Louis Love, Mental Genocide:

Ron D. Core, Funny Farm:

Ron D. Core and friends,CALIFORNIIA PROJECT: 8djs 16tapes 24hrs of
music,ron,simply jeff,drc,jon bishop,dj dan,vitamin d,dj trance,theo; this
is the ultimate rave present at $120.00 ,200 only, very nice and fun
package.

Ron D Core, Cluster Fuck: A two tape set - this baby has a nasty cover and
is hard fast techno with lots of tricks and astoundingly offensive
hardcore. $24.00

Robbie Hardkiss, Live at Pure Space: The ultimate hardkiss experience with
Scott on the sampler its a funky progressive piece of majic.

Simon, Song to the Siren:

Simon, Hands of Time:

Simon, Narcotic:

Simon, CU live 4/3/96: This tape is Progressive acid House and some
breaks. Really well rounded tape and as usual Simon played a set that
people talked about all the next day.

Spaz, Bass Travellers: Original techno on a Jungle tip from the most
underground SF crew $10. Just back from tour.

Spun,Live at Stanford: Rocking spacy house with lot o bass.

Spun,G12: Stoner house, hip-hop,raggae dub.

Spun,Whatever: Long intro turns into bassy acid house.

Spun,What We Do Is Secret: Bassy trip-hop house super phat!.

Spun,Ho Ho Ho: LTD mellow house from pure space.

Spun, If You Turn On: CD this is the way to hear deep spun bass.

Spun, Orange Sunshine: This is an old tape and starts with some talk about
LSD then goes to the bass-heavy House and Breaks.

Spun, Out 1+2, 3+4: Two tapes from a long End Up set. The End Up is a
great place to hear Spun The tweaky crowd gets some grounding as well as
some sexy fun.

Spun, Big Bambu: The last Spun tape was House and this one takes off from
there but gets more complicated and thoughtful. Intelligent House?

Tony, the Dream:

Tony,Vision:

Tony,Rising High:

Tony,The Gathering:

Tracy, Live at Tribal Future: It was cold and tribal that night.she plays
hard house and acid to keep your blood warm and groovy.


thanks to the Big List for titles and list information.

Thank you,

Karina

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

From: "Karina" <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; <sfraves-calendar@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, January 09, 2004 12:33 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Request: Mix Tapes (specific artists)


> This might be a long shot, but along with my CD and Waxx collection, I
> also still listen to mixtapes (there's still a tape deck in my car
> too baby)
>
> I am looking for the following mix tapes (*willing to
> purchase/trade)
>
> Carlos,Powerhouse: High energy house with some dj tricks.
>
> Carlos,Illusion: House and ravey techno/house, scratching.
>
> Carlos,MDMA: Very nice house, vocal yet energetic.
>
> Carlos,Love is the Law: side one is house and acid trance, side two is
> smooth house, dj tricks include equalization manipulation.
>
> Carlos, Deep: As the title suggests this is not a scratching high energy
> Carlos, this is a sensitive warm tape.with no cover.
>
> Dan,Live Mixes: Double pack from Organic, Funky Techno Tribe and
> Come/Unity. Big hits; high energy house and some acidy stuff + vocals. 2
> for$16.
>
> Dan,Double pack1&2: One tape is a tribute to James Brown, funky with
> tracks and mixes using JB. The live tape is more ravey funky techno
> bits-o-breaks. 2 for $16.
>
> Dan,Doublepack 3&4: This one is high energy Dan, not hardcore but not that
> housey. 2 for $16
>
> Dan,Jolly House Jams: Big flavorful house !
>
> Dan, Funky Green Project: Perhaps one of the strangest tapes I have ever
> heard. House and ravey techno and back again , alot happens in this 90
> min. of high energy.
>
> Dan,S.F.Housing Project:
>
> Dan,House the Discoteque:
>
> Dan,Wicked Burning Frenzy: In his own opinion , the best hardcore tape he
> ever made, Breakbeat hardcore techno.
>
> Dan-Ron D Core,DX2 #1: "the Anthem" and other harcore rave hits and wistle
> blowing madness.
>
> Dan-Ron D Core,DX2 #2: Tape includes original release by Dan and X-pando.
> Both sides hardcore techno, Dan has more breakbeat.
>
> Dan-Ron D Core,DX2 #3:
>
> Doran, 2010: Pretty trance of the kind that might get played at the 2010
> olympics.
>
> Doran, Innocence: Pretty trance with spine tingly moments of bliss!
>
> Doran,Paradigms: Trance this time a bit dryer and more serious.
>
> Doran, Eternity: This is a step further than the pretty trance he usually
> mixes. This is an excursion into Nu-energy Mount Olympus Style Ambrosia!
>
> DRC,the Jungle:from '92 tribal house with an edge.
>
> DRC,Psychotropical: This has more trance and less house and very tribal
> with some exotica flavor.
>
> DRC,Irontale:The hardest yet. Hard tribal techno with an industrial flair,
> moments of breakbeat, cyborg on cover sez it all.

Subject: [sfraves] Getting rid of Classic WaX?


If you are getting rid / selling / throwing away any classic Waxx traxx
from 1980-1999, please contact me, I may have an interested buyer.

House: Progressive, Acid, Techno Dance, Synthtron, Garage, Tribal, Epic,
Deep, Speed Garage, Tech House, Booty House, Funky House, Freestyle House.

Trance: Psychedelic, Psytekk, Goa, Dark trance, Symphonic, Break trance,
tech trance, deep trance, hard acid trance, hard trance, acid trance, hard
trance.

Techno: Detroit techno, german techno, swedish techno, bangin techno,
tribal techno, acid techno, minimal techno, experimental techno.

Breakbeats: Electro funk, freestyle, Electro, turntablism, tribal, acid
breaks, 2-step, Nu-Skool breaks, dark breaks, progressive breaks, ghetto
tech, funky breaks.

Jungle: hardstep, techstep, darkstep, experimental, glitch, IDM,
neurofunk, drumnbass, ragga, breakcore.

hardcore: speedbass, terrorcore, noizecore, gabber.

A track listing/wax list would suffice... Thank you!

continued from yesterday and before...a fictional piece:
 
joe always wanted to know what it was like to be someone else, but then he realized that it would not be possible for him to ever be anyone other than himself. it is not that he ever wanted to be her, but he always felt that if he were her for at least a day, maybe he would have understood better, and then maybe this wouldn't be happening now, but as well, he couldn't say that he was sorry to be where he was at this time, and that meant that things were changing for the better inside of him. :)

too.

	boundary="=====================_11345323==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Chicago Suburb Seeks to Ban Glow Sticks from All-Ages Clubs

--=====================_11345323==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Newsbrief: Chicago Suburb Seeks to Ban Glow Sticks from All-Ages Clubs 1/9/04

Last month, the city council in the Chicago suburb of Elgin gave 
preliminary approval to a local ordinance that would ban pacifiers, glow 
sticks, and other "drug paraphernalia" from clubs in the city that cater do 
an under-21 crowd. The measure must pass another vote at the council this 
month.

The measure is an effort to rein in Ecstasy use. The move arises out of the 
city's experience with The Mission, a club the city allowed to hold 
alcohol-free parties for 17-to-21-year-olds for a limited time last year. 
Patrons had to become club members to enter. Police arrested eight people 
for Ecstasy or look-alike drug sales during that period.

"Obviously, not everyone that has these items is on Ecstasy, but it would 
be helpful to keep these things out of the club," Rick Kozal, Elgin's 
assistant city attorney, told the council before it voted initial approval 
by a 5-1 margin on December 17. Glowsticks and pacifiers are drug 
paraphernalia, Kozal claimed.

The proposed ordinance is probably unconstitutional, Graham Boyd, head of 
the ACLU's Drug Policy Litigation Project, told the Chicago Tribune. "It's 
one thing if the venue's operators decide to ban certain legal items on 
their own," Boyd said. "It's another thing when the government is calling 
for such a ban." Boyd successfully argued a suit in New Orleans overturning 
a judge's ruling that such items must be banned as part of a settlement in 
a rave club case there.

But at least one Elgin council member didn't see any government imposition. 
"If you want to come to the club, you have to be a member," said John 
Walters. "If you want to be a member, you have to agree not to bring these 
items to the club. If you don't want to do it, no one is going to stop you 
from sitting at home and waving a glow stick in front of your face."

The next vote is scheduled for January 14.

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) R.I.P. Mail trains

R.I.P. Mail trains

Story from BBC NEWS:
http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/3382141.stm


MAIL TRAINS have reached the end of the line. No more the night mail,=20
crossing the border, bringing no cheque nor postal order.

After more than 160 years of service, the Travelling Post Office -=20
where post is sorted en route on special train services - has finally=20
gone to the sidings.

Summed up memorably by WH Auden in his verse Night Mail, cruelly=20
misquoted above, the TPO made its first journey in 1838 from London to=20=

the Midlands. By the First World War more than 130 services were in=20
use.

By the end of the Second World War only 43 services remained and the=20
1980s saw further cuts.

The decision to finally bring about the end of the line for TPOs was=20
greeted with much sadness.

Staff members past and present, together with enthusiasts, see the=20
death of the service as the real Great Train Robbery, as guestbook=20
tributes lovingly left on TPO fan websites show.

The Great Train Robbery proper did, of course, offer the TPO's most=20
infamous hour when a 15-strong gang made off with about =A32.3m after=20
holding up a train.

While 3,000 letters an hour were being sorted on the overnight trains,=20=

Royal Mail says automated equipment is now capable of a 30,000 per hour=20=

turnover.

The decision to transport post solely by air and road means the end to=20=

the "Victorian solution to a Victorian problem" of moving post around=20
the country.

The move will save Royal Mail =A310m a year (a third of the sum lost in=20=

the Great Train Robbery, in today's prices).

No flowers.

Your tributes:

No wreaths either, they might get leaves on the line.
S Murray, Chester

My tribute is in the post.
Howard M, Finland

This is the last post train. A later collection will be made at....
Simon Holt, UK

Here comes the night mail crossing the border, in a 7.5 tonne DAF=20
truck.... How romantic is that?
Robin Hull, UK

The last post.
Gail, UK



Published: 2004/01/09 12:31:13 GMT

=A9 BBC MMIV

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) R.I.P. Mail trains

-------------------------------1073690707
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I'm into trains ... I'm surprised they kept mail trains going in the UK for 
so long. The US stopped sorting mail on trains in the early 1970s. (I remember 
having to write "Via Air Mail" if you wanted mail to go by air instead of the 
default, by rail.)  A great deal of mail in the US does actually move by rail, 
but it's merely carried in sealed cars and not sorted en route. 

Despite the fast, modern transportation we enjoy today, I understand that 
until sometime in the 1950s (?), most parts of the US received two mail 
deliveries a day! On the other hand, now we communicate so much via e-mail and fax that 
there would probably never be a need again to deliver more than once a day. 
lol Imagine SF Raves as a literal mailing list ... getting copies of letters in 
the mail from people on the list, mailing in replies, and waiting to see if 
anybody responds! 

hey ... everybody have a safe weekend!  
JonnyR

-------------------------------1073690707--

Date: Fri, 9 Jan 2004 17:22:48 -0800 (PST)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
cc: DJBigDaddyG@aol.com, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-F38tSgcOrBLSAQ000143d3@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0401091710110.15907-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves]  [Looking For Booty House records]


Belle Isle Tech is *classic* ghetto tech.  Right up there with the first
couple "the bomb" series from DJ Godfather and some of the on air mixes
from WJLB's Gary Chandler.  It's NOT booty house, booty house is more like
DJ Funk does.

Booty house sounds like *gasp* house.  Swingy funky house, often with that
hard house kick and overall Chicago sound.  Think older UC, Dance Mania,
coming in at 120 to 140 bpm.

Ghetto tech (or Accelerated Funk as DJ Assault likes to call it) is
faster on vinyl, and often played on pitched up turntables.  Pressed at
140 -155 bpm, in practice it's often fast enough to mix in some jungle,
or split the beat with some 80 bpm hip hop.  Databass, booty bar,
ElectroFunk labels are all strong leaders in this genre.

For a set mixing both genres a bit (as well as some electro and miami bass
and of course old school rave and children's records) and examples of some
of the genre mashing described in teh GT example, check out this live mix
from a campout two years ago (and keep any technical complaints to
yourself... suffice to say I woke up nowhere near my tent eaten alive by
ants and had a limited recollection of the evening):

http://saturn5.com/andy/mp3/andyw-booty_at_oode.mp3

Lately, people have been also using the booty house name to describe the
work of artists like Peaches... but the music is neither house nor ghetto
tech and sorta creates it's own genre on the edge of the electroclash
movement.

I'll shut up now.
andyw

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [Looking For Booty House records]

Well...alot of Belle Isle Tech is ghettotech, but there're definately some 
booty house tracks on there too, because there are some straight up house 
tracks in the set. "Sex On The Beach" being the track that most obviously 
comes to mind. But even "Ass & Titties" is a much housier track than 
something like "Don't Try To Play Me Homie". Either way, it's a nice comp.

Subject: [sfraves] SFR Calendar: 01.09.04

Dreams are postcards from our subconscious, inner self to outer self,
right brain trying to cross that moat to the left. Too often they come
back unread: "return to sender, addressee unknown." That's a shame because
it's a whole other world out there--or in here depending on your point of
view.
    Dennis Koenig and Jordan Budde, Northern Exposure, Roots, 1991

He felt that his whole life was some kind of dream and he sometimes
wondered whose it was and whether they were enjoying it.
    Douglas Adams (1952 - 2001), "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy"

Those who dream by day are cognizant of many things which escape those who
dream only by night.
    Edgar Allan Poe (1809 - 1849), "Eleonora"

--=20

Saturday, January 10, 2004 ** Capricorn presented by Elektrosorcery **

Capricorn, whose constellation is known as Capricornus, is one of the oldes=
t of the astrological interpretations. Ruled by Saturn, its symbol is the g=
oat. This is sometimes depicted as a sea borne hybrid or Dolphin. The image=
 is often an animal with the body of a goat and the tail of a fish. In one =
tradition the image represents the god Pan transforming into a sea creature=
=2E A representation, perhaps, of the extremities found within this Astrolo=
gical sign. The Capricornian is generally a serious character possessing a =
wry sense of humor. Independent, steady as a rock, Capricorn reflects earth=
y qualities that range from clever to vacuous. Mostly cautious, confident, =
strong willed, reasonable and hard working, Capricorns are a rock upon whic=
h to build.They are capable of great endurance; a whatever it takes, for as=
 long as it takes persistence. Reliable in any profession they undertake, b=
ut lacking in originality, they usually excel in following up on what someo=
ne else has started. With Capricorn DJs: DYLOOT, UPHONIC, COVERT, SUNDANCE =
KID, and more to be announced. $10 presale $15 at the door.
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1013
SF Bay California, USA

Saturday, January 17, 2004 ** Cold Phusion Winter Music Festival by BR Prod=
uctions, Next Level Promotions, and KCRH 89.9FM **

 he COLD PHUSION Winter Music Festival! Line-up TEASER!!! COLD PHUSION will=
 feature over 40+ Artists performing on 4 MASSIVE stages of sound! THE WARP=
 BROS: The legendary Warp Brothers - DJ's Oliver Goedicke and J=FCrgen Dohr=
=2E It did not take a long time and their first single Phatt Bass hit the G=
erman market and made it to the top 3 in the dance charts! Shortly after th=
is they entered the Sales-Charts Europe wide up to the #2! No wonder that t=
hey draw the music business attention, with placing a solid techno-track in=
 the sales-charts.Shortly after their uplifting style flooded Europe, the w=
ave swept over to the US, Canada, Australia and Japan. You might somehow co=
mpare the style of the Warp Brothers to Prodigy or Chemical Brothers but th=
e truth is that they created their own creative and unique sound, like you =
can read in an article of the Face magazine. Although the Warp Brothers are=
 friendly people - they are in possession of a lethal weapon, which is call=
ed Harder House. Remarkable is their success in the UK sales-charts #9 and =
Top 10 positions in several Sales -Charts.In Denmark they were rewarded wit=
h gold. Undoubted the Warpies as they are keenly called by their fans turn =
it up on stage! DJ DRC: San Francisco's Pioneer DJ DRC has relocated to New=
 York City and is geared up to take the Electronic Music Industry by storm.=
 With her Mixed Album "UNDEFINED" in the works and a list of releases on IM=
IX, Vision Music, Off World, Merge, Twin Soul and her own label Undefined M=
usik, DRC equivocates the expeditious pace of her new stomping grounds. Her=
 original music is also featured in two movies, "Vision of Vibe" with Carl =
Cox and "Intellect" being released this February 2003, featuring Paul Van D=
yk and many others. DRC's latest single SEEKER can be heard on the SPANKEE =
clothing line websight. With all this under her belt and more, it is obviou=
s DRC has already had her finger on the pulse of the Big Apple/ Manhattan. =

pro=B7gres=B7sion n. The process of progressing; progress.
Movement from one member of a continuous series to the next.
A continuous series; a sequence.

ogression'. This is an exclusive Sunday experience that will entail some se=
rious tribal/progressive madness rocking the decks at one of the best, most=

o join our party, a temporal community where an attitude of acceptance, com=

Friday, January 23, 2004 ** SOMA Sessions w/Marcus Intalex **

SOMA Sessions
Fourth Fridays @ AsiaSF

For the inaugural session we bring you, all the way from Manchester UK, the=
 sounds of:

MARCUS INTALEX (Soul:r, MIST - UK)
Marcus Intalex is known across the globe for his infectious, smooth style o=
f Drum 'n Bass. Only a few years after his first production efforts in 1995=
 on Flex and his own Intalex Productions imprint came anthems such as "How =
You Make Me Feel," "Love & Happiness" and "Universe," which firmly position=
ed Marcus as one of the world's top D&B personalities. Today, Marcus and lo=
ngtime studio partner, S.T. Files continue to blaze trails as M.I.S.T. with=
 their wildly popular Soul:r label. With over a decade of experience on the=
 decks, SOMA Sessions is proud to welcome back to San Francisco one of the =
UK's most in-demand Drum 'n Bass DJs.

METHOD ONE (Cov.Ops, method-one.com)
By 1994 Method One was both an acclaimed DJ and and experienced rave promot=
er in Philly. By 1996 he was also an established producer. Recording with p=
artner Kaos as Atlantiq, Method One signed tunes to labels like Good Lookin=
g and True Intent while holding down DJ residencies at Konkrete Jungle and =
Dieselboy's Platinum. Since relocating to the Bay, Jason continues to wreck=
 dancefloors with his diverse DJ sets and release top-shelf tunes on labels=
 such as ASC's Covert Operations.

Resident Support:
DJ M
SOUND:BOY

10:30pm - 3am

e true. Surreal Entertainment (Known for their yearly Earthdance,Liquid lot=
us festival,Refliections and their Club Further) branching out all the way =
from Arizona to join forces with SF's newest and quickly growing production=
 company SFBang!, they brought
you GhettoTechnoSuperCaliExtraBootyLicious and if you attended that you kno=
w the vibe and you know the rukus and a rocking time to look forward to!

WINTER is going to be SF's First EVER snow party!
dance the night away in the falling snowflakes with 2 brand new artificial =
snow machines! You all are encouraged to wear stylish winter themed costume=
s. The Surreal girls will be there in full effect dressed as sexy snow bunn=
ies and snow angels!!! Feel free to join them on the fun!

This party will have somthing for everyone including House, Trance, Breaks,=
 Drum and Bass, and some good old fashioned HARDCORE!

Friday, February 6, 2004 ** *Oneiromancy* presented by Oneiromancy **

Doing things different from other crews, admission to this event will be fr=
ee of charge. We are working on the lineup, but as with all our events, we =
want to extend a special invite to all the new DJs who have never played an=
 event. We are setting aside a number of timeslots, in various genres, so i=
f you are dying to get out there to play, email me at wavelength_sf@yahoo.c=
om, with the subject "Oneiromancy" Be sure to include contact info, links t=
o demos (if you have one), and genre. I know everyone plays every genre, bu=
t if you could limit it to one, that would help. I'm going to randomly draw=
 names to play for each genre, so DJs who play a genre that is under-repres=
ented will have a better shot. Its all random: I dont care if we are friend=
s, enemies, whatever. I'll post the list the day after christmas, so thats =
the deadline. Oh yes, and unlike other times, hardcore DJs will definatly g=
et slots at this party. Hope to see you guys there. (look for the full line=
up the day after christmas. ) More info TBA.
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1017

Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or
sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Originating-IP: [67.127.70.44]
X-Originating-Email: [invibe@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: invibe@hotmail.com
From: "Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com>
To: electrofunk138@hotmail.com, hakthedj@hotmail.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Sat, 10 Jan 2004 13:27:32 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Law10-F95Kggpiqkpst00048d81@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 10 Jan 2004 21:27:32.0727 (UTC) FILETIME=[8EE06870:01C3D7C0]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] that madame mercury (JCF) commercial

this was posted on bayraves and written by DJ Oops, a friend of Sherry's and 
one of the people that made the PSA.

"greetings everyone... my name is Paul and I am one of the persons that was 
responsible for the creation of the "Follow your bliss" PSA. Public Service 
Announcement. I was the camera man and also assistant prodcer.
I would like to say that it feels very disheartening to hear that some 
people think that Madame Mercury has sold out.
When the concept of the "Follow your bliss" was created it was after 
learning that Madame Mercury after a hiatus from DJ'n dropped almost 
everything in her life at that time and put all her energy back into Dj'n. 
Back into sharing her energy and music with the community that showed it to 
her from the begnining. Essentially she "followed her bliss". She did what 
made her happy. After realizing so, my friends and I did the same. We all 
made life altering changes in life that will hopefully bring us happiness. 
If you're going to do something. Do something you love, right?
So... my friends and myself got the notion to put something in motion. Being 
as my friends and I are invloved in media(i.e. some are editores, camera 
men, director of photography). The editor worked on the "Burnt" PSA and was 
excited to do another with his own style. So we brainstormed and came up 
with the idea of a PSA and you all know the theme. Well.. we presented the 
idea to Madame Mercury and she gave us the go ahead. We filmed, we edited. 
Then it was time to find a Non-profit organization that would sponsor us. We 
tried and tried but to no avail we didn't find one. Then the editor in a 
last attempt wrote a letter to the Joseph Campbell foundation telling them 
about our PSA. They liked it, they sponsored us and now we are talking about 
it. This was all done from the heart. No one got paid. No one is asking you 
to join anything. We just want to share the notion of "following your bliss" 
.. do what you love... no matter what it may be.
So thank you for taking your time in reading my thoughts and take care.
-Paul"



-------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.invibe.com/bam

Subject: Re: [sfraves] that madame mercury (JCF) commercial

I never even saw the commercial, but I heard about the madam mercury and
"follow your bliss" part. . .

sometimes the message isn't as complicated as others might think. . .

I figured, shes a longtime dj, in a commercial mentioning following your
bliss. . .
it was on dharma n greg the other day, dharma wanted greg to follow his
bliss so greg quit being a lawyer to be a chef, etc etc. . .

just basically a public service announcement sorta thing, like the be cool
stay in school stuff using someone who's done that and also has a
recognizable name amongst their target audience. . .

but the dr. pepper commercials. . . those really don't make sense. . . did
you know that dr pepper used to contain prune juice, and was recommended for
keeping someone "regular". . .
I think an old teacher of mine told me that, but then again he also sang
this "starkle starkle lil twink" song a lot. . .

aK

even though it was the weekend, it wasn't in joe's world. as a matter of fact, he couldn't remember the last time he had the kind of weekend that people talk about when they mean "weekend"...maybe those people were lying too when they'd tell him what a great time they'd had and what he'd missed. maybe she wasn't ever that special in the first place. he lifted his drink and filled his mouth with sweet sugary juice and some sort of alcohol. where did this one come from? couldn't remember for the life of him. joe had all sorts of friends and acquaintances. :)

On Jan 10, 2004, at 1:27 PM, Brandon S. wrote:

> this was posted on bayraves and written by DJ Oops, a friend of 
> Sherry's and one of the people that made the PSA.
>
> "greetings everyone... my name is Paul and I am one of the persons 
> that was responsible for the creation of the "Follow your bliss" PSA. 
> Public Service Announcement. I was the camera man and also assistant 
> prodcer.
> I would like to say that it feels very disheartening to hear that some 
> people think that Madame Mercury has sold out.
> When the concept of the "Follow your bliss" was created it was after 
> learning that Madame Mercury after a hiatus from DJ'n dropped almost 
> everything in her life at that time and put all her energy back into 
> Dj'n. Back into sharing her energy and music with the community that 
> showed it to her from the begnining. Essentially she "followed her 
> bliss". She did what made her happy. After realizing so, my friends 
> and I did the same. We all made life altering changes in life that 
> will hopefully bring us happiness. If you're going to do something. Do 
> something you love, right?
> So... my friends and myself got the notion to put something in motion. 
> Being as my friends and I are invloved in media(i.e. some are 
> editores, camera men, director of photography). The editor worked on 
> the "Burnt" PSA and was excited to do another with his own style. So 
> we brainstormed and came up with the idea of a PSA and you all know 
> the theme. Well.. we presented the idea to Madame Mercury and she gave 
> us the go ahead. We filmed, we edited. Then it was time to find a 
> Non-profit organization that would sponsor us. We tried and tried but 
> to no avail we didn't find one. Then the editor in a last attempt 
> wrote a letter to the Joseph Campbell foundation telling them about 
> our PSA. They liked it, they sponsored us and now we are talking about 
> it. This was all done from the heart. No one got paid. No one is 
> asking you to join anything. We just want to share the notion of 
> "following your bliss" .. do what you love... no matter what it may 
> be.
> So thank you for taking your time in reading my thoughts and take care.
> -Paul"
>
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] UPLIFT WAS SO DOPE!

OK... Hello 2day... 1st off... i felt guilty 4 not goin' 2 Bad Kitty... but like well..  it was Thursday, my school is literally 2 minutes away from sublounge... so i went there!!  Seraphim, girl, U know I'll C U soon! =)

Anywaze... i had the time of my life on Thursday night @ uplift... i mean... seriously it kinda felt like an extension of New Years @ Wish almost 'cause alota people I huumg out w/ @ Wish was there!!  So yeah... it was totally family oriented that night & well... gosh it was fun!

Music was Awesome... when I got there.. Kinkers was playin' this Awesome Strait Breakbeats set!!  Loved it!!  B4 like I went 2 school that evening... I saw Britney Spears on VH1 & I was kinda thinkin' about her new song all throughout class & well.. during Konker's set... I felt like I had 2 dance like I was in 1 of her videos 'cause I had like all this mondo energy... Fun Fun.. oh yeah... him & I were slow dancing during Ambers set btw... fun fun =P

Then I oh oh ohoh oh... I finally officially kicked it Joey Fiasco!!!  Love That Dude!!! You got Awesome energy man!!! =)  But the whole night was pretty much filled w/ alota Fam like I said & U all know who U were ;)

Then Turquiose,er, I mean, Magenta, no no no... I mean... Indigo jumps on the decks & totally get's off playin' this Awesome Breakbeats set!!  YUUUUM!!  Then he popped in some hoip hop tunes toeards the end of his set & ok... i noticed he played like a remix remix remix of this old 80's rap song.. but well.. i dunno... i can't explain it 'cause well... he didn't get it when i tried asking him about it.. la la la... Hello 2Day Indigo =)

What trip me out the most was Andy's set... he was spinning Tech House like ummm... Wow... it was Awesome!!!  OK... the most trippy thing was well... downstairs in the basement... they were spinning like proggy house most the whole night... then there was this track that the DJ down there spun of this well Andy & the DJ downstair spun the same song @ the same time & it was fuckin' trippy as hell! I mean... it was jus' like this mondo surreal experience... Anywaze... Hello 2Day... Andy's set did get yummier as he went on.. he mixed in some break beakbeats & by the time his set ended... he was spinning some Ghetto tek!!  Loved it!

OK... now Amber's set was Crazy... she had a bag fulla fun tracks!! I mean... she was pretty light on the acid that night... but ooooh mt goodness man... Hello 2day... she totally got the floor when she spun 80's music!!  Hello 2day... Here comes the rain again!!! Loved it!!!  Oh my goodness man... 

JC was spinning the same time & well... he told me prior 2 his set that he had a bunch of yummy trance & techno records... but everytime I went down there.. all i was groovin' 2 was trance... i didn't hear any techno =(  Groovy set non the less!!

Like i said it was a bad ass night!!!  I'm Glad U got your hat back Eva!!!  Oh yeah... that night i got invited 2 join a cult.. loooooong story!!  LoL...

Good times! =)  I <3 U all! Have a mondo safe weekend... ok? =)

X-HotPOP: -----------------------------------------------
                   Sent By HotPOP.com FREE Email
             Get your FREE POP email at www.HotPOP.com
          -----------------------------------------------
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Changes, (was (Review) Anon Salon)

Sorry if I respond to this thread a little late.

I'd like to add that change is the very essence of our scene. UDM grew 
out of the desire to change music as we know it, from timbres, to 
structures to textures. But we're human, we grow to attach to what 
become familiar and reliable to us (whether you're a househead, junglist 
or trancewhore). We tend to go to the same parties regularly because 
we're going to have a good time. As a person become a regular at certain 
parties/events/genres, they also become detached to everything else 
there is out there.

It's up to us, the participants, to look for new music, throw new 
parties, and represent. This is particularly true for newbies, who are 
typically enthuiastic and open-minded. The "scene" to them usually is 
MUCH BIGGER than for us the old-skoolers, who usually limit ourselves to 
a certain niche.

If you're tired of the same people and cirlces, then go out and look for 
something new. There are plenty of ppl faithly throwing 
weeklies/monthlies regularly, waiting for you to discover them.  :)  
Make new friends, hear new music. That's what the scene is about.

The scene do run in cycles. There's also the 5-yr swinging popularity 
cycle b/w clubs and one-offs. I've only been to SF for a few days, but 
it seems that the club scene here is shrinking, while there seems to be 
a small momentum towards one-offs, monthlies and mid-week weeklies.

The scene nationally has been on a steady downturn since 2001, so I 
expect there will be another explosion again soon. It'll probably take a 
new genre (or a diversion of a trusted genre) to set the scene off 
again. There's a steady momentum behind nu-skool breaks, and the d'n'b 
scene is finally moving away from the tired techstep formula, and 
progressive tribal has the potential of reviving the progressive house 
scene by introucing a new focus to rhythm.

Keep an open mind, and support the music and the parties and the people 
that you love. As long as we all do our parts, the rest will happen in 
due time.  :)


Pz.,

 - Jeff


Apollo wrote:

> At 02:54 PM 1/5/2004, innocentchild wrote:
>
>
>> Do you get the feeling that a lot of us are just tired of our same 
>> circles
>> and the same people? Seems that a lot of people are going seperate 
>> ways and
>> looking for something new. The scene that a lot of us knew is gone 
>> and a lot
>> of the faces with its passing.
>>
>> :: r ::
>
>
> I felt much personal loss when the old school house community I loved 
> pretty much disappeared in the last couple of years.  Come-Unity was 
> an island of sanity and comfort for me each month and a place where I 
> could see people I've known for ten years.  The Gathering is gone.  
> Wicked, it seems to me, is on its last beats as a collective.
>
> Change is inevitable, however.  I've been around for a long time in 
> the dance community and I've observed death and rebirth every five or 
> so years.  Thus I've learned not to be too attached to any scene or 
> genre, and really try to keep my mind open to the new and the flow of 
> life.
>
> If nothing would ever change we would all be bored as hell.  When 
> change comes it may initially make us uncomfortable or sad.  People do 
> leave.  Music changes.  But the underlying vibe, I think, has been 
> pretty consistent over the years.  Dancers from each generation, I've 
> found, are lovely people:)
>
> It is a new year, and there are new people and energies in the 
> community:  a time to meet new friends;  explore diverse dance 
> scenes;  and fall in love with the community once again.
>
> Love,
>
> Apollo
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor 
> do the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger 
> is no safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a 
> daring adventure or nothing."
> -Helen Keller
>
> "Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
> integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
> -Aldous Huxley, Island
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of 
> the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will 
> gradually become visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] Skills

NOT the rekkid store.  BUT, tonight I was at an event, and I finally
decided to watch the "headliner" and I was less than impressed with
their skills (thus the subject line.)  I mean, waiting for the breakdown
in a song and then mixing the next track in, often not on beat, in less
than eight measures?????  What's up with that??

I mean you know me.  I like to sit there for a couple of minutes plus
playing around with a combination of songs.  And I'm sitting here
watching that.  How dissappointing!  I'm kinda left to wonder if it's a
genre thing.

I won't say any more, for fear of spilling the beans.  But.......

-- 
What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] .: Dirtbox Radio 1/11 | DJ Twist | Hooligan :.


Y'all know whatchu need?  Some Dirtbox Radio.

How do you get this Dirtbox Radio?

Easy, you tune into Destroyer.net or Jungletrain.net tonight (and every
Sunday night) from 7pm 'til 12am+ EST.

This week we've got a little bit of breaks in with your DNB, brought forth
by DJ Twist, in his first appearance on Dirtbox.  Dude mashed up twice at
ALIAS battles, and has been gettin airplay in a good number of spots
around here, so rest assured he'll throw down.

Also comin' out tonight is one of the original Dirtbox Kru members:
Hooligan.  It's been a while since he's been out on the show, but no worry
- Hooligan always comes correct with the nasty dark techstep with a
sprinkle sprinkle here and there of something off the wall.

Timeslots:
07-08pm EST - Intro Hour w/ ODJ
08-09:30pm EST - DJ Twist
09:30-11pm EST - Hooligan
11-12am+ EST - Outro Hour w/ ODJ

No Jerel here this week, as he's up in PA takin care of some shit.  He
should be back next week.

Audio, Video, and Chat links for the show are always available at
http://dirtboxradio.com/listen.html

Make sure to check out the new webcam.  This one's actually legible :)

Here's a sneak peak at our upcoming guest slots (some dates may change,
check website for updated slots):
Jan 18: Bizar, Haaps
Feb 01: Akasha, Shade
Feb 08: 2Charming Crew
Feb 15: RsonisT, Ransom
Feb 22: Cam One, Psykofly
Feb 29: Taysty, Simetra

If you'd like to play on Dirtbox Radio, or have us air a mixset or track
of yours, just send an email to myself (odj@dirtboxradio.com) or Jerel
(jerel@baked.net), and we'll sort ya out.

Aight then, I'll see you cats at 7pm.  Take it easy!

Jackson aka ODJ

Partners in Crime, www.DirtboxRadio.com, Trividual Productions, ALIAS

following link:

http://magnatune.com/artists/version

Regards,
New Blues Music
Los Angeles
audiomekhanik@hotmail.com

X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] joe's tale...continued...:) nrr

okay. . .

well I gotta critique ya just a lil here. . .
I've been reading these, and I always got a's on my book reports I'd make up
in english. . . so I figure I qualify sort of. . .

first, telling a story (well a good story). . . isn't just "telling" a
story. It's more like capturing the entire experience of the event with
words, so to bring the events feelings, thoughts, actions n such to life for
the audience.
You need to be more descriptive. Don't jump from scene to scene, but slowly
flow thru them. Is Joe naked with his hat on ?  Howd he get dressed ?
Your story is missing a lot of important information. Especially from day to
day. . .

Whats the point of the story ? Usually near the beginning of the book you
can somewhere read pieces that somewhat hint as to the point of the journey,
etc. . .
Is this the day to day life of JOE ? Surely he eats, slipps in the bathroom,
has neighbors, made toast and caught his house on fire. . . maybe joe needs
a gay stripper roomate who always comes home with drama. . .

I think one of the major reasons people get annoyed with stories like these,
because it seems like "off the topp of my head" 5 seconds of thought when it
comes out so short and not really thought thru. Take more time to develop
your story and then write it. Don't be afraid to describe EVERYTHING. . . in
fact, thats always more interesting. . .

and I guess all of this only applies if you're NOT writing a childrens book.
But then still. . .joe could be this sly party squirrel or something like
that.

put some effort into it mann. . . from reading your writings for years, I'm
totally confident that you have a good mind for creating stories n such. . .
you just need to develop em more and flow thru better. . .

make it fun for us too. . .

: )

aK
----- Original Message -----

beamed in from the crack in her shades...it wasn't the her he was used to
though...she was long gone...it was a new her, and he was happy, because he
knew a long time ago that this was going to be totally worth it...:)
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] joe's tale...continued...:) nrr

Well said, and good advice.  Here's a bit from the beginning of perhaps the
best 1st chapter ever written, as an example:

The Deliverator belongs to an elite order, a hallowed subcategory.  He's got
esprit up to here.  Right now, he is preparing
to carry out his third mission of the night.  His uniform is black as
activated charcoal, filtering the very light out of the air.
A bullet will bounce off its arachnofiber weave like a wren hitting a patio
door, but excess perspiration wafts through it like
a breeze through a freshly napalmed forest.  Where his body has bony
extremeties, the suit has sintered armorgel: feels like
gritty jello, protects like a sack of telephone books.
    When they gave him the job, they gave him a gun.  The Deliverator never
deals in cash, but someone might come after
him anyway--might want his car, or his cargo.  The gun is tiny, aero-styled,
lightweight, the kind of gun a fashion designer
would carry; it fires teensy darts that fly at five times the velocity of an
SR-71 spy plane, and when you get done using it,
you have to plug it into the cigarette lighter, because it runs on
electricity.
    ....
    The Deliverator's car has enough potential energy packed into its
batteries to fire a pound of bacon into the Asteroid
Belt.  Unlike a bimbo box or a Burb beater, the Deliverator's car unloads
that power through gaping, gleaming, polished
sphincters.  When the Deliverator puts the hammer down, shit happens.  You
want to talk contact patches?  Your car's
tires have tiny contact patches, talk to the asphalt in four places the size
of your tongue.  The Deliverator's car hsa big
sticky tires with contact patches the size of a fat lady's thighs.  The
Deliverator is in touch with the road, starts like a bad
day, stops on a peseta.

----- Original Message -----
From: "aK" <aK@hard-grooves.com>
To: "Geri Dahl" <eeelips@yahoo.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Sunday, January 11, 2004 1:25 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] joe's tale...continued...:) nrr


> okay. . .
>
> well I gotta critique ya just a lil here. . .
> I've been reading these, and I always got a's on my book reports I'd make
up
> in english. . . so I figure I qualify sort of. . .
>
> first, telling a story (well a good story). . . isn't just "telling" a
> story. It's more like capturing the entire experience of the event with
> words, so to bring the events feelings, thoughts, actions n such to life
for
> the audience.
> You need to be more descriptive. Don't jump from scene to scene, but
slowly
> flow thru them. Is Joe naked with his hat on ?  Howd he get dressed ?
> Your story is missing a lot of important information. Especially from day
to
> day. . .
>
> Whats the point of the story ? Usually near the beginning of the book you
> can somewhere read pieces that somewhat hint as to the point of the
journey,
> etc. . .
> Is this the day to day life of JOE ? Surely he eats, slipps in the
bathroom,
> has neighbors, made toast and caught his house on fire. . . maybe joe
needs
> a gay stripper roomate who always comes home with drama. . .
>
> I think one of the major reasons people get annoyed with stories like
these,
> because it seems like "off the topp of my head" 5 seconds of thought when
it
> comes out so short and not really thought thru. Take more time to develop
> your story and then write it. Don't be afraid to describe EVERYTHING. . .
in
> fact, thats always more interesting. . .
>
> and I guess all of this only applies if you're NOT writing a childrens
book.
> But then still. . .joe could be this sly party squirrel or something like
> that.
>
> put some effort into it mann. . . from reading your writings for years,
I'm
> totally confident that you have a good mind for creating stories n such. .
.
> you just need to develop em more and flow thru better. . .
>
> make it fun for us too. . .
>
> : )
>
> aK
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Geri Dahl" <eeelips@yahoo.com>
> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Sunday, January 11, 2004 12:29 PM
> Subject: [sfraves] joe's tale...continued...:) nrr
>
>
> > need i explain...this is a continuation of a fictional piece we are
> working on here, soley for pleasure and creativity:
> >
> > joe woke up with a start...where was he? the glare of a yellowish light
> beamed in from the crack in her shades...it wasn't the her he was used to
> though...she was long gone...it was a new her, and he was happy, because
he
> knew a long time ago that this was going to be totally worth it...:)
> >
> >

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v609)

Date: Mon, 12 Jan 2004 17:43:01 -0500
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.609)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) a very strange dream last night ... 

ok, ok, ok, so i had this really *weird* dream last night.  first of 
all, i set my alarm for 5:30, intending to get up early and have 
breakfast before work.  well, i stayed up late and it turned out i just 
hit the alarm clock off button, and went back to sleep.  and that's 
when i had the weird dream ...

i was starring in a tv show with leonard nimoy, you know, mr. spock?  
well he wasn't mr. spock, or so i thought, he was playing, i guess some 
normal dude, and god only know what i was doing there.  then all of a 
sudden, he said, "curious.  i have surmised that we are actually in a 
star trek episode ... i looked at him like what the hell is he talking 
about ... then all of a sudden, we all changed into vulcans!  i 
remember there was someone else there, and i had to give them a little 
counseling, like saying "you know, i think he may be on to something, 
he may be right, we really are in a star trek episode ... but it'll be 
ok."

and then the dream was over, i was woken up by the second alarm at 6am.

i think there's two reasons i had this dream, one i watched enterprise 
last night, which i haven't in a while, and i went to a friend's house 
who has a sega dreamcast, and he has a *really* strange game called 
Seaman, where you grow this fish looking thing into a life form that 
crawls out of the water, presumably like our ancestors did, i guess.  
anyway, that game had leonard nimoy's voice in the beginning.  has 
anyone played that?  how bizarre, huh?  any dream interpreters in da 
house?

anyway, it's 50 degrees today, but it should be dropping down to 20 and 
snowing by thursday.

-d

Subject: Re: [sfraves]Technics: How would you ship them?

I'd use the original boxes as they were designed for exactly that purpose.
If you decide not to use the boxes, make sure you pack the platter seperately
from the rest of the deck.  If you ship it on the spindle you can really
end up horking the spindle.

-Erik

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]Technics: How would you ship them?

heya

I've shipped like civic parts n stuff to japan and dealt with australia,
canada, europe. . .
You can do the stuff online att like www.ups.com or www.usps.com

overseas shipments cost almost twice the price with UPS rather than USPS
since it has to be 2 nd day air or faster

usps to japan for about 50 or so pound was like $71, and he recieved it in
around 2 weeks. .  .
UPS was $186. ..

To pack em,
first I'd get some good bubblewrap and a good box that fit both of em,
level, sort of on top of eachother.Put both tables in some type of plastic
bag for dust n such, then wrap both tables (with covers I assume, put the
carts in their cases or something, and secure everything) in the bubble wrap
covering all sides. Then padd the bottom of the box a lil and drop it in.
Put some more bubble wrap on top of that and then use a square sheet of
cardboard the same size as the box (lXw). . .on that, make sure the table
fits snug yknow. . .add some packing something or other to take up the
space. . .
So with the other table, put a lil bubbleshit on the carboard sheet. . . and
drop the other table in. . . pack as necessary. . . if you have ortofons or
something just put them in the cases and somewhere in the box. . . pack it
really tight, like so you shake the box and nothing moves. . .

then tape the hell out of it, but not so as to attract suspicion of
terrorism or anything like that. . .

Theres a company, THARCO, that makes "corrugated shipping containers". Its
like a couple blocks from where I live.I cant find their catalog but just
call 411 and get their number. It's in San Lorenzo. They're open 24hrs, and
accept small orders of just a couple boxes to bundles. . . if you want a
really strong box use the doublewall ones they have.
figure,
a single Technic, is what , like

  a.. Width: 17-13/16"
  b.. Height: 6-5/8"
  c.. Depth: 14-1/4"
  d.. Weight: 26.4 lbs
So get one box thats like 22x18x18, and a sheet of semi-thick 22x18" sheet
of cardboard. . .
guess like total weight of around 54lbs. . .
the cardboard will cost like $3-4, n all sorts of places have bubblewrap and
tharco prolly also has all sorts of packing materials. . .

you can get shipping quotes on both the ups and usps website.
be sure to insure it for like 8-900 or so. . .
Theres post offices and ups stores everywhere too. . . you'll probably have
to fill out all sorts of forms n such. . . you can prolly do it all for less
than $95.

but you can skip most of that if you just go to your local friendly audio
shoppe and beg them to give you two boxes from demos or something like that.
. .

: )

aK

From sfraves-return-109461-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Jan 13 03:36:45 2004

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 90184 invoked from network); 13 Jan 2004 03:36:45 -0000
Message-Id: <6.0.1.1.2.20040112183206.01ef7430@mail.speakeasy.net>
X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.net
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.0.1.1
Date: Mon, 12 Jan 2004 19:36:39 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_27185540==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Bam!!!

--=====================_27185540==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I haven't seen Afrika Bambaataa perform for some time, and having Bam come 
to the intimate environment of Club 6 was a very big deal for me.  Angel 
has been doing wonderful things with that venue:  the Legends of House 
series; quality hip hop and turntablist parties; and a variety of other 
musical styles, both old school and new, that make 6 a place where many 
things are coming together musically.

This was one of the best-attended parties I've ever been to at 6.  Dancers 
were jammed onto that hot, sweaty floor.  A few rather aggressive types 
near the turntables, but for the most part the crowd was respectful...and 
enthusiastic.

It has been some time since I've been to a dance event where people were 
waving their arms, screaming as each new track was laid down, and singing 
to lyrics.  Yep...lyrics:  some going back more than twenty years.  The 
often disco infused hip hop, breaks and electro were so refreshing.   Music 
that people really dance to.  Funky.  Soulful.

Bam comes from the same roots that I do:  that maelstrom of musical 
innovation that was NYC in the seventies.  Hip hip and disco leveraged off 
of the same musical roots, as did house music later on, and there was much 
intermixing of black R&B and the like on all underground seventies dance 
floors.  Larry Levin, myself and some friends often went to sound system 
and MC battles in the Bronx where Bam and his Zulu Nation crew would go off 
against other now famous hip hop artists.  At one point he promoted a party 
as I recall with Kool Herc.

Hearing Bam again, and seeing the reaction of the crowd, was, as I told a 
friend on the ride home, like Paul being struck off his horse on the way to 
Tarsus.  I have been becoming progressively bored and disenchanted with the 
direction most "progressive" dance music is taking lately.  Much of it is, 
yes, technically solid as are the performers but it seems as though soul 
has been replaced with an icy intellectualization of the whole dance floor 
ecology.  As one producer in Boston wrote on another list recently:  "I 
hate dancing.  I like to rave."  He writes and produces "dance" music.

This personal epiphany has been building over the past few months.  I go to 
"Get Freaky" and see displaced psytrance people dancing wildly to Adam 
Freeland who is spinning...well...can one really say "breaks?"  That set 
was all over the place, and at the same party was a hip hop room.  Kids 
digging Jesse Saunders and singing along to "I Want Your Body."  The new 
Steve Lawler release has remixes of stuff I haven't heard for years.

So I'm going back to my roots again.  As with most musically innovative 
times, those who wish to move forward build on the past.  Only one being is 
alleged to have made something from nothing.  In the beginning there were 
no genres.  Time for me, at least, to start seriously looking at the music 
that made and makes people shout and dance.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"  
--=====================_27185540==.ALT--

oh yeah,

in order not to hork the spindle. . . you should remove the platters and
wrap them seperately. . .I forgot the'yre not screwed on. . .
buy a couple more single sheets and pack them in between those. . . make the
box a lil taller. . .

yknow I horked my knee a couple times. . . I have a video of one of em. . .

shit, if ya want, just give me like $45 + shipping, and drop the tables off
to me. . . I'll ship em and supply you with the tracking info n such. . .

aK
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "aK" <aK@hard-grooves.com>
To: "_ fable _" <fable4our@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, January 12, 2004 7:25 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves]Technics: How would you ship them?


> heya
>
> I've shipped like civic parts n stuff to japan and dealt with australia,
> canada, europe. . .
> You can do the stuff online att like www.ups.com or www.usps.com
>
> overseas shipments cost almost twice the price with UPS rather than USPS
> since it has to be 2 nd day air or faster
>
> usps to japan for about 50 or so pound was like $71, and he recieved it in
> around 2 weeks. .  .
> UPS was $186. ..
>
> To pack em,
> first I'd get some good bubblewrap and a good box that fit both of em,
> level, sort of on top of eachother.Put both tables in some type of plastic
> bag for dust n such, then wrap both tables (with covers I assume, put the
> carts in their cases or something, and secure everything) in the bubble
wrap
> covering all sides. Then padd the bottom of the box a lil and drop it in.
> Put some more bubble wrap on top of that and then use a square sheet of
> cardboard the same size as the box (lXw). . .on that, make sure the table
> fits snug yknow. . .add some packing something or other to take up the
> space. . .
> So with the other table, put a lil bubbleshit on the carboard sheet. . .
and
> drop the other table in. . . pack as necessary. . . if you have ortofons
or
> something just put them in the cases and somewhere in the box. . . pack it
> really tight, like so you shake the box and nothing moves. . .
>
> then tape the hell out of it, but not so as to attract suspicion of
> terrorism or anything like that. . .
>
> Theres a company, THARCO, that makes "corrugated shipping containers". Its
> like a couple blocks from where I live.I cant find their catalog but just
> call 411 and get their number. It's in San Lorenzo. They're open 24hrs,
and
> accept small orders of just a couple boxes to bundles. . . if you want a
> really strong box use the doublewall ones they have.
> figure,
> a single Technic, is what , like
>
>   a.. Width: 17-13/16"
>   b.. Height: 6-5/8"
>   c.. Depth: 14-1/4"
>   d.. Weight: 26.4 lbs
> So get one box thats like 22x18x18, and a sheet of semi-thick 22x18" sheet
> of cardboard. . .
> guess like total weight of around 54lbs. . .
> the cardboard will cost like $3-4, n all sorts of places have bubblewrap
and
> tharco prolly also has all sorts of packing materials. . .
>
> you can get shipping quotes on both the ups and usps website.
> be sure to insure it for like 8-900 or so. . .
> Theres post offices and ups stores everywhere too. . . you'll probably
have
> to fill out all sorts of forms n such. . . you can prolly do it all for
less
> than $95.
>
> but you can skip most of that if you just go to your local friendly audio
> shoppe and beg them to give you two boxes from demos or something like
that.
> . .
>
> : )
>
> aK
>

of you SF-Ravers will I see or run into? I am looking foward to this big 
massive enet it shall be a rolling good time :-) oh baby just think all the music 
all the big tall speakers pumping out bass at your body. Gosh this shall be 
something to remember.

much fun i will have images on my website of this event as well as planet new 
years event. :-)

From sfraves-return-109465-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Jan 13 05:12:35 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-109465-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 19266 invoked by uid 1103); 13 Jan 2004 05:12:34 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 19252 invoked from network); 13 Jan 2004 05:12:34 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [24.4.202.125]
X-Originating-Email: [electrofunk138@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: electrofunk138@hotmail.com
From: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: apollo@speakeasy.org, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Mon, 12 Jan 2004 21:12:29 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY8-F125xxcQrIaXt70001bc89@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 13 Jan 2004 05:12:30.0127 (UTC) FILETIME=[D7D953F0:01C3D993]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Bam!!!

Good to hear he had that effect on the crowd and yourself...Bam has that way 
about him, he just melds everything into dancefloor funk and gets people 
moving. I'm happy to see alot of producers now are shedding the "genre" skin 
and playing with different sounds, because (at least all the music I've been 
buying lately) is more funk oriented, and made to move asses and 
dancefloors. Everything from breaks ot house, and even progressive has a 
much more gritty and sexy sound...made for that primal energy.

Gotta love that....

M-

>From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] Bam!!!
>Date: Mon, 12 Jan 2004 19:36:39 -0800
>
>I haven't seen Afrika Bambaataa perform for some time, and having Bam come 
>to the intimate environment of Club 6 was a very big deal for me.  Angel 
>has been doing wonderful things with that venue:  the Legends of House 
>series; quality hip hop and turntablist parties; and a variety of other 
>musical styles, both old school and new, that make 6 a place where many 
>things are coming together musically.
>
>This was one of the best-attended parties I've ever been to at 6.  Dancers 
>were jammed onto that hot, sweaty floor.  A few rather aggressive types 
>near the turntables, but for the most part the crowd was respectful...and 
>enthusiastic.
>
>It has been some time since I've been to a dance event where people were 
>waving their arms, screaming as each new track was laid down, and singing 
>to lyrics.  Yep...lyrics:  some going back more than twenty years.  The 
>often disco infused hip hop, breaks and electro were so refreshing.   Music 
>that people really dance to.  Funky.  Soulful.
>
>Bam comes from the same roots that I do:  that maelstrom of musical 
>innovation that was NYC in the seventies.  Hip hip and disco leveraged off 
>of the same musical roots, as did house music later on, and there was much 
>intermixing of black R&B and the like on all underground seventies dance 
>floors.  Larry Levin, myself and some friends often went to sound system 
>and MC battles in the Bronx where Bam and his Zulu Nation crew would go off 
>against other now famous hip hop artists.  At one point he promoted a party 
>as I recall with Kool Herc.
>
>Hearing Bam again, and seeing the reaction of the crowd, was, as I told a 
>friend on the ride home, like Paul being struck off his horse on the way to 
>Tarsus.  I have been becoming progressively bored and disenchanted with the 
>direction most "progressive" dance music is taking lately.  Much of it is, 
>yes, technically solid as are the performers but it seems as though soul 
>has been replaced with an icy intellectualization of the whole dance floor 
>ecology.  As one producer in Boston wrote on another list recently:  "I 
>hate dancing.  I like to rave."  He writes and produces "dance" music.
>
>This personal epiphany has been building over the past few months.  I go to 
>"Get Freaky" and see displaced psytrance people dancing wildly to Adam 
>Freeland who is spinning...well...can one really say "breaks?"  That set 
>was all over the place, and at the same party was a hip hop room.  Kids 
>digging Jesse Saunders and singing along to "I Want Your Body."  The new 
>Steve Lawler release has remixes of stuff I haven't heard for years.
>
>So I'm going back to my roots again.  As with most musically innovative 
>times, those who wish to move forward build on the past.  Only one being is 
>alleged to have made something from nothing.  In the beginning there were 
>no genres.  Time for me, at least, to start seriously looking at the music 
>that made and makes people shout and dance.
>
>Love,
>
>Apollo
>
>Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
>
>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
>the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
>safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
>adventure or nothing."
>-Helen Keller
>
>"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
>integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
>-Aldous Huxley, Island
>
>"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
>rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
>visible."
>-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [Roll Call] California's Premier Winter Music Festival

i think it's pretty funny that this is being billed as a "premier festival" 
when the only headliners that i can recognize as not being local (or from 
LA) are the Warp Brothers.  atleast 2/3 of the DJs listed have played one or 
more times at a local party in the last month.  so what will make this a 
festival?

i mean, i'm sure people will have fun...but will it really be that much 
bigger or better than any of the other events that go on in the bay all the 
time?

>----- Original Message -----
>From: "aK" <aK@hard-grooves.com>
>To: "_ fable _" <fable4our@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Sent: Monday, January 12, 2004 7:25 PM
>Subject: Re: [sfraves]Technics: How would you ship them?
>
>
> > heya
> >
> > I've shipped like civic parts n stuff to japan and dealt with australia,
> > canada, europe. . .
> > You can do the stuff online att like www.ups.com or www.usps.com
> >
> > overseas shipments cost almost twice the price with UPS rather than USPS
> > since it has to be 2 nd day air or faster
> >
> > usps to japan for about 50 or so pound was like $71, and he recieved it 
>in
> > around 2 weeks. .  .
> > UPS was $186. ..
> >
> > To pack em,
> > first I'd get some good bubblewrap and a good box that fit both of em,
> > level, sort of on top of eachother.Put both tables in some type of 
>plastic
> > bag for dust n such, then wrap both tables (with covers I assume, put 
>the
> > carts in their cases or something, and secure everything) in the bubble
>wrap
> > covering all sides. Then padd the bottom of the box a lil and drop it 
>in.
> > Put some more bubble wrap on top of that and then use a square sheet of
> > cardboard the same size as the box (lXw). . .on that, make sure the 
>table
> > fits snug yknow. . .add some packing something or other to take up the
> > space. . .
> > So with the other table, put a lil bubbleshit on the carboard sheet. . .
>and
> > drop the other table in. . . pack as necessary. . . if you have ortofons
>or
> > something just put them in the cases and somewhere in the box. . . pack 
>it
> > really tight, like so you shake the box and nothing moves. . .
> >
> > then tape the hell out of it, but not so as to attract suspicion of
> > terrorism or anything like that. . .
> >
> > Theres a company, THARCO, that makes "corrugated shipping containers". 
>Its
> > like a couple blocks from where I live.I cant find their catalog but 
>just
> > call 411 and get their number. It's in San Lorenzo. They're open 24hrs,
>and
> > accept small orders of just a couple boxes to bundles. . . if you want a
> > really strong box use the doublewall ones they have.
> > figure,
> > a single Technic, is what , like
> >
> >   a.. Width: 17-13/16"
> >   b.. Height: 6-5/8"
> >   c.. Depth: 14-1/4"
> >   d.. Weight: 26.4 lbs
> > So get one box thats like 22x18x18, and a sheet of semi-thick 22x18" 
>sheet
> > of cardboard. . .
> > guess like total weight of around 54lbs. . .
> > the cardboard will cost like $3-4, n all sorts of places have bubblewrap
>and
> > tharco prolly also has all sorts of packing materials. . .
> >
> > you can get shipping quotes on both the ups and usps website.
> > be sure to insure it for like 8-900 or so. . .
