Subject: [sfraves] GWBush and the real state of the Union

-------------------------------1074649867
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Courtesy of the Independent.  (http://www.independent.co.uk)  More than a
little informative



George W Bush and the real state of the Union

Today the President gives his annual address. As the election battle begins,
how does his first term add up?

20 January 2004

232: Number of American combat deaths in Iraq between May 2003 and January
2004

501: Number of American servicemen to die in Iraq from the beginning of the
war - so far

0: Number of American combat deaths in Germany after the Nazi surrender to
the Allies in May 1945

0: Number of coffins of dead soldiers returning home from Iraq that the Bush
administration has allowed to be photographed

0: Number of funerals or memorials that President Bush has attended for
soldiers killed in Iraq

100: Number of fund-raisers attended by Bush or Vice-President Dick Cheney
in 2003

13: Number of meetings between Bush and Tony Blair since he became President

10 million: Estimated number of people worldwide who took to the streets in
opposition to the invasion of Iraq, setting an all-time record for
simultaneous protest

2: Number of nations that Bush has attacked and taken over since coming into
the White House

9.2: Average number of American soldiers wounded in Iraq each day since the
invasion in March last year

1.6: Average number of American soldiers killed in Iraq per day since
hostilities began

16,000: Approximate number of Iraqis killed since the start of war

10,000: Approximate number of Iraqi cililians killed since the beginning of
the conflict

$100 billion: Estimated cost of the war in Iraq to American citizens by the
end of 2003

$13 billion: Amount other countries have committed towards rebuilding Iraq
(much of it in loans) as of 24 October

36%: Increase in the number of desertions from the US army since 1999

92%: Percentage of Iraq's urban areas that had access to drinkable water a
year ago

60%: Percentage of Iraq's urban areas that have access to drinkable water
today

32%: Percentage of the bombs dropped on Iraq this year that were not
precision-guided

1983: The year in which Donald Rumsfeld gave Saddam Hussein a pair of golden
spurs

45%: Percentage of Americans who believed in early March 2003 that Saddam
Hussein was involved in the 11 September attacks on the US

$127 billion: Amount of US budget surplus in the year that Bush became
President in 2001

$374 billion: Amount of US budget deficit in the fiscal year for 2003

1st: This year's deficit is on course to be the biggest in United States
history

$1.58 billion: Average amount by which the US national debt increases each
day

$23,920: Amount of each US citizen's share of the national debt as of 19
January 2004

1st: The record for the most bankruptcies filed in a single year (1.57
million) was set in 2002

10: Number of solo press conferences that Bush has held since beginning his
term. His father had managed 61 at this point in his administration, and
Bill Clinton 33

1st: Rank of the US worldwide in terms of greenhouse gas emissions per
capita

$113 million: Total sum raised by the Bush-Cheney 2000 campaign, setting a
record in American electoral history

$130 million: Amount raised for Bush's re-election campaign so far

$200m: Amount that the Bush-Cheney campaign is expected to raise in 2004

$40m: Amount that Howard Dean, the top fund-raiser among the nine Democratic
presidential hopefuls, amassed in 2003

28: Number of days holiday that Bush took last August, the second longest
holiday of any president in US history (Recordholder: Richard Nixon)

13: Number of vacation days the average American worker receives each year

3: Number of children convicted of capital offences executed in the US in
2002. America is only country openly to acknowledge executing children

1st: As Governor of Texas, George Bush executed more prisoners (152) than
any governor in modern US history

2.4 million: Number of Americans who have lost their jobs during the three
years of the Bush administration

221,000: Number of jobs per month created since Bush's tax cuts took effect.
He promised the measure would add 306,000

1,000: Number of new jobs created in the entire country in December.
Analysts had expected a gain of 130,000

1st: This administration is on its way to becoming the first since 1929
(Herbert Hoover) to preside over an overall loss of jobs during its complete
term in office

9 million: Number of US workers unemployed in September 2003

80%: Percentage of the Iraqi workforce now unemployed

55%: Percentage of the Iraqi workforce unemployed before the war

43.6 million: Number of Americans without health insurance in 2002

130: Number of countries (out of total of 191 recognised by the United
Nations) with an American military presence

40%: Percentage of the world's military spending for which the US is
responsible

$10.9 million: Average wealth of the members of Bush's original 16-person
cabinet

88%: Percentage of American citizens who will save less than $100 on their
2006 federal taxes as a result of 2003 cut in capital gains and dividends
taxes

$42,000: Average savings members of Bush's cabinet are expected to enjoy
this year as a result in the cuts in capital gains and dividends taxes

$42,228: Median household income in the US in 2001

$116,000: Amount Vice-President Cheney is expected to save each year in
taxes

44%: Percentage of Americans who believe the President's economic growth
plan will mostly benefit the wealthy

700: Number of people from around the world the US has incarcerated in
Guantanamo Bay, Cuba

1st: George W Bush became the first American president to ignore the Geneva
Conventions by refusing to allow inspectors access to US-held prisoners of
war

+6%: Percentage change since 2001 in the number of US families in poverty

1951: Last year in which a quarterly rise in US military spending was
greater than the one the previous spring

54%: Percentage of US citizens who believe Bush was legitimately elected to
his post

1st: First president to execute a federal prisoner in the past 40 years.
Executions are typically ordered by separate states and not at federal level

9: Number of members of Bush's defence policy board who also sit on the
corporate board of, or advise, at least one defence contractor

35: Number of countries to which US has suspended military assistance after
they failed to sign agreements giving Americans immunity from prosecution
before the International Criminal Court

$300 million: Amount cut from the federal programme that provides subsidies
to poor families so they can heat their homes

$1 billion: Amount of new US military aid promised Israel in April 2003 to
offset the "burdens" of the US war on Iraq

58 million: Number of acres of public lands Bush has opened to road
building, logging and drilling

200: Number of public-health and environmental laws Bush has attempted to
downgrade or weaken

29,000: Number of American troops - which is close to the total of a whole
army division - to have either been killed, wounded, injured or become so
ill as to require evacuation from Iraq, according to the Pentagon

90%: Percentage of American citizens who said they approved of the way
George Bush was handling his job as president when asked on 26 September,
2001

53%: Percentage of American citizens who approved of the way Bush was
handling his job as president when asked on 16 January, 2004

-------------------------------1074649867--

-- 
What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] WMC 2004

Is it just me, or WMC is getting more commerical and more retarded every 
year?

I remembered Ultra 2000 as if it was yesterday. I'd never seen so much 
excitement, and it was surreal to be dancing on the beach, with the sun 
shining over the beautiful Alantic.

Then when I went to Ultra 2002, it was like every other SoCal massive: 
confusing, aggravating, and a lot of standing around. Like any SoCal 
massive, it took half an hour to get from one stage to another.... The 
crowd no longer had any passion whatsoever, it was replaced with pure daze.

In any case, the afternoon pool parties were the best, chill and 
laid-back. I still like to talk about how John Digweed walked into the 
11th St Diner when I was there having breakfast @ 6am, or that time I 
ran into Peter Rauhofer on the street.... It might be more of a 
hit-or-miss nowadays, but WMC is still probably the most unique 
experience second to Burning Man.

I've been debating if I wanna go to WMC this year. If anything, it's a 
good excuse to catch up with my old friends @ BeatCamp.

Hope u'll have good time down there.

- Jeff

Hi, I made a photo album on Yahoo with some pics from Cold Phusion. My Yahoo 
address isn't on SFR so I forwarded it to this address. For some reason there 
are links on the page that don't work, so just click on the picture to get to 
the album. 
It wasn't the greatest party in the world, as you've probably heard by now. I 
still had fun though. The 3x6 sets were good because of the interaction 
between DJs. It was cool to see a live singer (Carrie) performing to James Dub's 
beats. Also, it was a nice change of pace to see live bands, but it was cold 
outside and I didn't stay out there very long. Tek Threat and RayD8 scratched in 
between the band performances, and they were good. Sound wasn't so hot inside 
-- like Osby said, it bounced around a lot. It would have been better with 
more people, for sure. Despite the hype on Bayraves, the event was not very well 
attended. Having more people there would have helped the vibe. 
I also went to the after party in Oakland -- just the downstairs of a 
familiar venue -- and that was fun. Went until about 5 am. Got some pictures of that, 
too, in the album. 
Jonnyr

-------------------------------1074709584

X-Originating-IP: [67.127.70.44]
X-Originating-Email: [invibe@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: invibe@hotmail.com
From: "Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Wed, 21 Jan 2004 11:57:39 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Law10-F214Low7XudCA00012291@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 21 Jan 2004 19:57:39.0819 (UTC) FILETIME=[D2FF33B0:01C3E058]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] nrr:  RIAA sues 532 more people

Record industry files 532 'John Doe' suits against music downloaders
TED BRIDIS, AP Technology Writer
Wednesday, January 21, 2004
2004 Associated Press

URL: sfgate.com/article.cgi?file=/news/a/2004/01/21/national1225EST0557.DTL

(01-21) 09:38 PST WASHINGTON (AP) --

The recording industry on Wednesday sued 532 computer users it said were 
illegally distributing songs over the Internet, the first lawsuits since a 
federal appeals court blocked the use of special copyright subpoenas to 
identify those being targeted.

The action represents the largest number of lawsuits filed at one time since 
the trade group for the largest music labels, the Recording Industry 
Association of America, launched its controversial legal campaign last 
summer to cripple Internet music piracy.

Music lawyers filed the newest cases against "John Doe" defendants -- 
identified only by their numeric Internet protocol addresses -- and expected 
to work through the courts to learn their names and where they live.

The recording association said each person was illegally distributing an 
average of more than 800 songs online. Each defendant faces potential civil 
penalties or settlements that could cost them thousands of dollars.

The resumed legal campaign was intended to discourage music fans emboldened 
by last month's federal appeals court decision, which dramatically increased 
the cost and effort to track computer users swapping songs online and sue 
them.

"Our campaign against illegal file sharers is not missing a beat," said Cary 
Sherman, president of the recording association. "The message to illegal 
file sharers should be as clear as ever."

All 532 lawsuits were filed in Washington and New York -- home to Verizon 
Internet Services Inc. and Time Warner Inc. and a few other prominent 
Internet providers -- although the recording association said it expects to 
discover through traditional subpoenas that these defendants live across the 
United States.

The RIAA said that after its lawyers discover the identity of each 
defendant, they will contact each person to negotiate a financial settlement 
before amending the lawsuit to formally name the defendant and, if 
necessary, transfer the case to the proper courthouse.

Verizon had successfully challenged the industry's use of copyright 
subpoenas, one of its most effective tools to track illegal downloaders. The 
U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled last month that the 
recording industry can't use the subpoenas to force Internet providers to 
identify music downloaders without filing a lawsuit.

The court said that copyright subpoenas available under the 1998 Digital 
Millennium Copyright Act "betrays no awareness whatsoever that Internet 
users might be able directly to exchange files containing copyrighted 
works."

>** AA Meeting Part 2 **
>Brought to you by Amenti Music, Aroma Records & Odds & Ends Music.
>Sunday March 7th 2004 @ The Marlin Hotel - 1200 Collins Ave, Miami Beach.
>>From 1pm to 7pm
>
>Featuring Tag Team sets and heavy drinking by:
>
>Swirl People
>East Coast Boogiemen
>LawnChair Generals
>Olivier Desmet
>Demarkus Lewis
>Spettro
>Chuck Diesel
>Michelle Mai
>DJ Decode
>
>+ very special headlining guests to be announced soon...

>this
> > year...up to and including Crobar. I shall try and get the full list of
> > clubs that are closed if I can...
> >
> > WMC is gonna hug a root this year.
> >
> > M-
> >
> >
> >
> > >From: Jeffrey Chan <goofrider@hotpop.com>
> > >To: s e r a p h i m <djseraphim@yahoo.com>
> > >CC: sfbreaks@topica.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > >Subject: Re: [sfraves] WMC 2004
> > >Date: Tue, 20 Jan 2004 23:21:37 -0800
> > >
> > >Is it just me, or WMC is getting more commerical and more retarded 
>every
> > >year?
> > >
> > >I remembered Ultra 2000 as if it was yesterday. I'd never seen so much
> > >excitement, and it was surreal to be dancing on the beach, with the sun
> > >shining over the beautiful Alantic.
> > >
> > >Then when I went to Ultra 2002, it was like every other SoCal massive:
> > >confusing, aggravating, and a lot of standing around. Like any SoCal
> > >massive, it took half an hour to get from one stage to another.... The
> > >crowd no longer had any passion whatsoever, it was replaced with pure
>daze.
> > >
> > >In any case, the afternoon pool parties were the best, chill and
>laid-back.
> > >I still like to talk about how John Digweed walked into the 11th St 
>Diner
> > >when I was there having breakfast @ 6am, or that time I ran into Peter
> > >Rauhofer on the street.... It might be more of a hit-or-miss nowadays,
>but
> > >WMC is still probably the most unique experience second to Burning Man.
> > >
> > >I've been debating if I wanna go to WMC this year. If anything, it's a
>good
> > >excuse to catch up with my old friends @ BeatCamp.
> > >
> > >Hope u'll have good time down there.
> > >
> > >- Jeff
> > >
> > >
> > >s e r a p h i m wrote:
> > >
> > >>Its March 6th - 10th.
> > >>http://www.wintermusicconference.com
> > >>

> > >>in this so I thought I'd see what's up :)
> > >>
> > >>I'm getting ready for WMC again this year, planning the Sisters
> > >>Unite IV Showcase, the Sister International Annual Meeting, and a few
> > >>other things. I think this year is going to be a lot of fun!

>Level (Mansion) has been gutted out and is in a pre construction halt after
>being busted by the City of Miami Beach for doing demolition and
>constructing without permits. All construction has been ceased pending work
>permits. Will it be ready for WMC 2004? Don't bet your vinyl collection on
>it.

>OPIUM AND NIKKY BEACH
>
>
>  . <http://ccprod.roving.com/roving/images/letters/spacer.gif>

>
>   <http://www.miamiclubs.com/menupgs/images/opium_logo.jpg> Opium is being
>forced to shut down and will be moving its operations to Mission (Level) 
>due
>to new even stricter City of Miami Beach Noise (Level) Ordinances.
>
>Nikky Beach is beachless. The City has taken back all beach and sand areas
>and will not allow Nikki to play any music above easy listening levels.
>
>
>
>

On Wed, Jan 21, 2004 at 11:57:39AM -0800, Brandon S. wrote:
> Record industry files 532 'John Doe' suits against music downloaders
> TED BRIDIS, AP Technology Writer
> Wednesday, January 21, 2004
> 2004 Associated Press
> 
> URL: sfgate.com/article.cgi?file=/news/a/2004/01/21/national1225EST0557.DTL
> 
> (01-21) 09:38 PST WASHINGTON (AP) --
> 
> The recording industry on Wednesday sued 532 computer users it said were 
> illegally distributing songs over the Internet, the first lawsuits since a 
> federal appeals court blocked the use of special copyright subpoenas to 
> identify those being targeted.
> 
> The action represents the largest number of lawsuits filed at one time 
> since the trade group for the largest music labels, the Recording Industry 
> Association of America, launched its controversial legal campaign last 
> summer to cripple Internet music piracy.
> 
> Music lawyers filed the newest cases against "John Doe" defendants -- 
> identified only by their numeric Internet protocol addresses -- and 
> expected to work through the courts to learn their names and where they 
> live.
> 
> The recording association said each person was illegally distributing an 
> average of more than 800 songs online. Each defendant faces potential civil 
> penalties or settlements that could cost them thousands of dollars.
> 
> The resumed legal campaign was intended to discourage music fans emboldened 
> by last month's federal appeals court decision, which dramatically 
> increased the cost and effort to track computer users swapping songs online 
> and sue them.
> 
> "Our campaign against illegal file sharers is not missing a beat," said 
> Cary Sherman, president of the recording association. "The message to 
> illegal file sharers should be as clear as ever."
> 
> All 532 lawsuits were filed in Washington and New York -- home to Verizon 
> Internet Services Inc. and Time Warner Inc. and a few other prominent 
> Internet providers -- although the recording association said it expects to 
> discover through traditional subpoenas that these defendants live across 
> the United States.
> 
> The RIAA said that after its lawyers discover the identity of each 
> defendant, they will contact each person to negotiate a financial 
> settlement before amending the lawsuit to formally name the defendant and, 
> if necessary, transfer the case to the proper courthouse.
> 
> Verizon had successfully challenged the industry's use of copyright 
> subpoenas, one of its most effective tools to track illegal downloaders. 
> The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled last month 
> that the recording industry can't use the subpoenas to force Internet 
> providers to identify music downloaders without filing a lawsuit.
> 
> The court said that copyright subpoenas available under the 1998 Digital 
> Millennium Copyright Act "betrays no awareness whatsoever that Internet 
> users might be able directly to exchange files containing copyrighted 
> works."
> 
> 
> 
> 
> -------------
> < Brandon / DJ Bam >
> 
> DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
> http://www.invibe.com/bam
> 
> Download the new mix online!

Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2004 08:18:35 -0800
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

	sfraves@hyperreal.org

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <d0.4412a4e4.2d40f7b7@aol.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Good Records 2 Buy?

quoth DJBigDaddyG@aol.com:
> 1.) what dose (radio edit) mean

A "radio edit" is typically shorter, and usually lacks a breakdown.

> 2.) what dose (club edit) mean

A "club edit" usually includes lots of filters and cheesy, over-used
disco samples. The kick is typically emphasized over other elements to
make it more "dance-friendly".

> 3.) what dose (dub edit) mean?

There's no general rule to describe the "dub edit". Back in the 80's
every song had a dub edit, and most of them were just really long
versions of the original with less vocals, more delay and reverb, and a
variety of "dub" percussion samples thrown in at opportune moments. More
modern dub edits tend to be less literal, and more true to the mantra of
real dub music: stripping the song down to its most basic elements, and
giving it atmosphere, depth, and "space".

> What are 5 good records for 2004 late 2003 that people will most
> likely groove out to in the clubs or in an event?

I be damned if I know what people want to "groove out to" at clubs these
days...

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Organization: The Gospel According to Jack
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <BAY8-DAV24Sr0fVwcdZ000009f7@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 22 Jan 2004 17:35:20.0169 (UTC) FILETIME=[1B61C590:01C3E10E]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Good Records 2 Buy?

1 - Usually the shortest of all 'edits' meant for play on radio...I can't
say I would never, but I have never played a radio edit while at a gig
(maybe just my inability) Most of the songs with these 'edit's' originated
on the radio, example; Monica 'get it off' - That kid chris edit...typically
heavy on vocals and not much else...if they made it tooo intricate, the
poppy peeps just might not get it. lol.

2 - I would take 'club' edit to usually dictate the major remix of the
'radio edit', umm como se dice Paul Oakenfold?...to be honest the only time
I see these edits are for people like Madonna and Pink, 50 cent, etc. Club
edit, to me, derives from a popular song that they want to cross over to the
dance floors and they will throw in, like Shaun said, as many bells,
whistles, scream's, etc and just annihilate the song...Again, at least for
the style of tunes I buy, probably not the strongest mix on the record.

3 - Ahhh the dub, now we are getting into some good stuff...Not sure about
the history of the dub, but to me it usually means the heavy bass,
subliminal driving mix. Subtle changes and strong drive

As far as what people are gonna groove to, dude that's your job. lol...I
guess it would depend on the event and style of music that the crowd is
looking for...Being a progressive dj, some tunes that have worked for me as
of late:
1. Wyatt Earp & Jonas Temple "Frequency"
2. Trafik "Your Light" Luke Chable Remix
3. Van Bellan & Greed "City Lights" Mathew DeKay Remix
4. Maquai "Get It On" Original Mix
5. Scrambler "Free" LoStep's Class of 95 Remix

.and as for the 'shiny disco balls', you can have my copy...it's only
function these days is as a bookend. take care.

The last thing I would recommend is not to search out these 'radio', 'club'
edits, but to find producers who's remixes you like and search for other
things they do and there own original productions...this will start you off
on a 'kevin bacon 7th theory' type deal and you will discover a lot of new
people once you start developing your style.

--
DJ Jack Triumph
Minister of Infinite Progressive Onslaught

"I saw an Angel in the Marble,
and carved until I set him free"
- Michelangelo

jack@jacktriumph.com
www.jacktriumph.com

MSN: jacktriumph@hotmail.com

Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2004 10:13:09 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY8-F22tqFZfMHisvb0000ef52@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 22 Jan 2004 18:13:10.0153 (UTC) FILETIME=[6465D790:01C3E113]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Good Records 2 Buy?

Dude...the best advice I can give you is, grab stacks of vinyl, sit at a 
listening station, and listen to shit until you hear records you like. You 
might want to imagine how they'd sound with other records you already have, 
but all in all, you should just buy what you like or what you think you'd 
like to spin. The rest comes with time. Who cares what tracks are hot, and 
which aren't....it should be 1st and foremost about what makes YOU wanna 
groove. Most likely that will come across to whomever you play for. If a dj 
hates his vinyl, bnut it's "dancefloor friendly" chances are the only people 
that will like it at all are people you don't want at your party, lol.

Marc(O)

Upcoming appearances:
2/12/04 UPLIFT @ SUBLOUNGE (An AuraSF prod.) w/ Jack Triumph & guests TBA
2/27/04 PROGRESSION @ 26 Mix w/Jack Triumph, Macadio, Illiaster & Floorcraft

>From: "Jack Triumph" <jacktriumph@hotmail.com>
>Reply-To: "Jack Triumph" <jacktriumph@hotmail.com>
>To: <DJBigDaddyG@aol.com>
>CC: "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Good Records 2 Buy?
>Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2004 09:35:18 -0800
>
>1 - Usually the shortest of all 'edits' meant for play on radio...I can't
>say I would never, but I have never played a radio edit while at a gig
>(maybe just my inability) Most of the songs with these 'edit's' originated
>on the radio, example; Monica 'get it off' - That kid chris 
>edit...typically
>heavy on vocals and not much else...if they made it tooo intricate, the
>poppy peeps just might not get it. lol.
>
>2 - I would take 'club' edit to usually dictate the major remix of the
>'radio edit', umm como se dice Paul Oakenfold?...to be honest the only time
>I see these edits are for people like Madonna and Pink, 50 cent, etc. Club
>edit, to me, derives from a popular song that they want to cross over to 
>the
>dance floors and they will throw in, like Shaun said, as many bells,
>whistles, scream's, etc and just annihilate the song...Again, at least for
>the style of tunes I buy, probably not the strongest mix on the record.
>
>3 - Ahhh the dub, now we are getting into some good stuff...Not sure about
>the history of the dub, but to me it usually means the heavy bass,
>subliminal driving mix. Subtle changes and strong drive
>
>As far as what people are gonna groove to, dude that's your job. lol...I
>guess it would depend on the event and style of music that the crowd is
>looking for...Being a progressive dj, some tunes that have worked for me as
>of late:
>1. Wyatt Earp & Jonas Temple "Frequency"
>2. Trafik "Your Light" Luke Chable Remix
>3. Van Bellan & Greed "City Lights" Mathew DeKay Remix
>4. Maquai "Get It On" Original Mix
>5. Scrambler "Free" LoStep's Class of 95 Remix
>
>.and as for the 'shiny disco balls', you can have my copy...it's only
>function these days is as a bookend. take care.
>
>The last thing I would recommend is not to search out these 'radio', 'club'
>edits, but to find producers who's remixes you like and search for other
>things they do and there own original productions...this will start you off
>on a 'kevin bacon 7th theory' type deal and you will discover a lot of new
>people once you start developing your style.
>
>--
>DJ Jack Triumph
>Minister of Infinite Progressive Onslaught
>_____________________________________
>"I saw an Angel in the Marble,
>and carved until I set him free"
>- Michelangelo

>jack@jacktriumph.com
>www.jacktriumph.com

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

The record lables that put out dnace music will force the RIAA to ceace. If 
this goes far enough, deejays will backlash and just stop playing the labels 
who support the RIAA crack-down.

It's hard enough for most EDM labels to stay afloat these days. Even a 
minute drop in record sales will drive most of them under.

However, I bet this has a lot more to do with Funkmaster Flex wannabees than 
EDM jocks. It's probably the hip hop labels that want to smash the mix CD's. 
Because these days, they no longer rely on an underground to stay viable.

AUDi,
Gavin

Don't worry about it if you're not selling them.

And don't worry about it if all of the tracks on your cd are from
independent dance labels.  They aren't part of the RIAA...usually these
roundups apply to hip hop DJ mix CDs with lots of major label radio tracks
on them...

Received: (qmail 47785 invoked by uid 1103); 22 Jan 2004 19:06:47 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 47771 invoked from network); 22 Jan 2004 19:06:47 -0000
Message-ID: <20040122190643.73338.qmail@web13906.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2004 11:06:43 -0800 (PST)
From: Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com>
To: Jason <djjasonphilips@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <FEBF87D36F006D4AA2C33FB21ADA0DBE01F414DC@US-TRILLIUM.columbia.csc>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

Do you really think that's fair to the producers who
actually *made* the music that you play?

In my mind it works like this:

My track on your promo/free mix CD + tracklisting = OK

My track on your promo/free mix CD + NO TRACKLISTING =
NOT OK

My track on your for-profit mix CD without my
permission = NOT OK

By not listing the tracks and giving credit to those
that made them, you're really doing a disservice to
the people who keep you in business...

(JMHO BTW)

From sfraves-return-109671-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jan 22 19:40:22 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-109671-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 61901 invoked by uid 1103); 22 Jan 2004 19:40:21 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 61886 invoked from network); 22 Jan 2004 19:40:21 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [12.103.245.108]
X-Originating-Email: [blooshaman@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: blooshaman@hotmail.com
From: "Danny Picard" <blooshaman@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2004 11:40:17 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Sea2-F65mzMLV5dlR1800055456@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 22 Jan 2004 19:40:17.0679 (UTC) FILETIME=[903F01F0:01C3E11F]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

I do not make demos for profit, shit I rarely make demos anyway, I know that 
there are certain things that are okay to do and not okay to do regarding 
duplication of tracks, and demos.  That is very apparent.
The thing that bugs me is the freedom, (which I have been told this country 
has been all about) has slowly been taken away...from not being able to 
dance at certain place, to not even be able to get married to someone you 
love depending on sexual preference, to not being able pee in the forest off 
a highway without getting a fine of 700$ freely, it is just a long list of 
subtle dissapointments that make me upset.  I am  looking at the bigger 
picture.
If I were producing tracks, I would love that other people sought after them 
as a valuable creation of mine, however I was unaware of the politics 
concerning that there are *certain* groups or labels that belong to the 
RIAA, and not all of them...
hope that clarifies where I am coming from...
(I am sure someone will now misread the whole "freedom" thing that I said 
and turn it into a lame "this country" tangent on the list.  Please don't.  
Reread what I wrote
with love and concern,
Danny Picard


"der tis moodle in der noggin tu smacken der ouchey und vinger-slingers ur 
to smacken-backen und fix de morkin, yobetcha! "
-The Swedish Chef

From sfraves-return-109672-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jan 22 19:44:40 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-109672-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 64076 invoked from network); 22 Jan 2004 19:44:39 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [12.103.245.108]
X-Originating-Email: [blooshaman@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: blooshaman@hotmail.com
From: "Danny Picard" <blooshaman@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2004 11:44:36 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Sea2-F12wQQg2aaGut000008009@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 22 Jan 2004 19:44:36.0938 (UTC) FILETIME=[2AC6CAA0:01C3E120]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] fwd re: Dj'vs RIAA

>From AndyW--
I think unlicensed for profit mix cds suck, and that's what this
'crackdown' is all about.  Don't kid yourselves, the product we are
talking about here are mix cds, made of other people's music, with little
going on in the way of mixing (tracks played almost in their entirety),
often pulling $16-$20 at the register... with the bulk of that money going
to someone who spent a few hours banging it together.  Compared to the
tens/hundreds of hours in making a good track, I just think it's not fair
unless the original artists/labels approve (and there is a mechanism
people use for this referred to as clearing or licensing and it's existed
for almost as long as Djing and sampling have been recognized as an
artform).

As a producer, the gloves come off when I see a cd in a store where
someone else is charging for a track I made.  That's when DJs step outside
the realm of fair use with the interntion of promoting themselves and get
into fucking me out of my own track's success to the clanging of cash
registers.

The real question here is fair use, and I don't think unlicensed cds sold
for profit at stores should fall into that category.  If someone is giving
away a mix that contains my song in an effort to express what it is they
play, I'm ok with that.  Hell, it's kinda fun to type "mutor threshold" as
a google search and see where my last EP pops up in a top ten, or a track
listing for some aspiring DJ in Japan.

The problem with a lot of this is that people are stating how greedy the
RIAA is without realizing that there is a lot less return for them doing
this than for the DJs who charge for other people's music without making
any effort to compensate the original artists.  This isn't the borg suing
IP addresses, it's actually the kind of stuff they're supposed to be
doing.

I don't wanna put Moonpup in jail for selling me a couple mixtapes behind
the Acme for $5 a piece in 1996, but many record stores actually see far
more profit from mix cd sales and rave ticket sales than actual vinyl
sales these days... and if those mix cds aren't taking care of the
original artists there's a problem (a lot of people argue that labels
don't give enough money to artists when it's their own album so
conventional logic dictates this must be even worse, right?).  Cause as
much as you might love your favorite DJ, without people making original
tracks we'd get really bored pretty quick.

andyw





"der tis moodle in der noggin tu smacken der ouchey und vinger-slingers ur 
to smacken-backen und fix de morkin, yobetcha! "
-The Swedish Chef

Subject: [sfraves] SOMA Sessions - D&B Fri 1/23 @ AsiaSF - Marcus Intalex

SOMA Sessions
Drum & Bass Fourth Fridays @ AsiaSF

Friday January 23, 2004 - Opening night!

MARCUS INTALEX (Soul:r, MIST - UK) 
Marcus Intalex is known across the globe for his
infectious, smooth style of Drum 'n Bass. Only a few
years after his first production efforts in 1995 on
Flex and his own Intalex Productions imprint came
anthems such as "How You Make Me Feel," "Love &
Happiness" and "Universe," which firmly positioned
Marcus as one of the world's top D&B personalities.
Today, Marcus Intalex and longtime studio partner,
S.T. Files continue to blaze trails as M.I.S.T. with
their wildly popular Soul:r label. With over a decade
of experience on the decks, SOMA Sessions is proud to
welcome back to San Francisco one of the UK's most
in-demand Drum 'n Bass DJs. 

METHOD ONE (Cov.Ops, method-one.com) 
By 1994 Method One was both an acclaimed DJ and and
experienced rave promoter in Philly. By 1996 he was
also an established producer. Recording with partner
Kaos as Atlantiq, Method One signed tunes to labels
like Good Looking and True Intent while holding down
DJ residencies at Konkrete Jungle and Dieselboy's
Platinum. Since relocating to the Bay, Jason continues
to wreck dancefloors with his diverse DJ sets and
release top-shelf tunes on labels such as ASC's Covert
Operations. 

Resident support:

DJ M

SOUND:BOY


To buy presale tickets or to join our mailing list,
visit http://somasessions.com

Hours:
 10:30pm - 3am
 
Entry:
 21 and over with ID
 
Tickets:
 $10 presale, $15 door 
  
Wed 1/21 10:30pm:  Please note that presale tickets
are now SOLD OUT for this event. 

For those of you who have bought presale tickets, your
name will be held at the AsiaSF ticket booth- simply
show up on the night of the event with a photo ID. For
additional security, print and bring a copy of your
PayPal receipt. 
 

AsiaSF 
201 Ninth Street at Howard St 
San Francisco, California 94103 
415.255.ASIA(2742) 


Next month - Feb 27, 2004
- NOOKIE (Good Looking - UK)
- UltraViolet (Sleeveless, SF Agency)
Presale tickets available 1/24...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

dont foprget that although the label that put out that track your spinning
may be small and somewhat underground, but the original track that for
instance the vocals might have come from may belong to some company that
DOES belong to the RIAA.... or maybe its a remix of an old track  and the
remixer never actually got a license to remix it....

so although you may only play tracks from independent dance labels; you may
not be as unaffected by this as you intially thought.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Nathan Seven" <scosol@yahoo.com>
To: "Jason" <djjasonphilips@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, January 22, 2004 11:06 AM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)


> Do you really think that's fair to the producers who
> actually *made* the music that you play?
>
> In my mind it works like this:
>
> My track on your promo/free mix CD + tracklisting = OK
>
> My track on your promo/free mix CD + NO TRACKLISTING =
> NOT OK
>
> My track on your for-profit mix CD without my
> permission = NOT OK
>
> By not listing the tracks and giving credit to those
> that made them, you're really doing a disservice to
> the people who keep you in business...
>
> (JMHO BTW)
>

Message-ID: <BAY99-DAV5NJ5p9p61O0000cf86@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 22 Jan 2004 22:08:46.0166 (UTC) FILETIME=[4E1E3F60:01C3E134]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

I don't think this is an issue the riaa should be getting involved
with.......unless a record company complains about someone profitting
directly from the sale of mix with their copyrighted material on it.

Because electronic music isn't completely mainstream where else would people
gain access to the tracks that are being produced?  DJ mixes!!!!!  This is
like free promotion for both the producer and the dj!

And yes, I agree tracklistings should be provided.  But even when someone
gets a hold of a mix of mine that didn't have the tracklisting on the actual
cd they email me and ask what the song is.  If thats not good promotion then
i don't know what is......

Another thing that doesn't make any sense is that a lot of these record
companies are producing tracks utilizing copyrighted melodies and samples
WITHOUT gaining permission......so its hard to imagine that the dj would be
held responsible when it the record company releasing and profiting from the
sale of the track.

I think the riaa is just fucking bored, all they have been doing lately is
trying to find ways to restrict what people do on the net and in the
entertainment industry.  I don't think it would be that bad for musicians
and actors to make a little less money, isn't it true that once you become a
celebrity you get free things constantly?  So they obviously don't need that
much money and should just let it be....=P

~Molly
HCFTP / RaveNBeats
http://MollyMush.com

Importance: Normal
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 22 Jan 2004 22:21:14.0540 (UTC) FILETIME=[0C2F0EC0:01C3E136]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

The major labels I am sure are complaining that their sales are dipping
due to the smaller labels taking sales. Dance music not being mainstream
is a problem because the majors have no control and cannot exploit many
of the artists like they can with other more mainstream music. So in
turn they lose money. If the artists signed to major labels learn that
they can escape contracts that defy physics then they will leave the
majors for greener pastures. The RIAA is not funded by small labels that
are barely afloat. They are funded either directly or indirectly through
major labels. So when your paycheck is scared what do you do but protect
it. The RIAA is attacking djs because the major labels see the dj
culture as a threat to their livelihood. That is just my opinion but you
know I really could be wrong. 


One question I have is this. For all artists on SFRaves if you are
signed to a label that you have no stake in financially what percentage
of each record sold ends up in your pocket. I really want to know. 

Jason Philips
Compos-Mentis
Problematic Beats

Because electronic music isn't completely mainstream where else would
people
gain access to the tracks that are being produced?  DJ mixes!!!!!  This
is
like free promotion for both the producer and the dj!

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.609)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

in short, there is sort of an artificial market limit. i'd say anywhere 
from 750-2000 copies sold of a record in the UG dance scene is a 'hit'. 
you'd probably make anywhere from 250-2000$ for it. it's better to own 
the label; if you don't you probably aren't getting any sort of 
royalties on numbers sold.
it's an extremely volatile market. it's better to blow your wad on a 
nice rmx or track from an established artist in order to position your 
label better with the distro's and record stores; which translates in 
more records sold to punters. it's just like the dj scene in this 
sense. the top 5 percent are making the money and making the beats. 
there is a lot of room for other artist and labels, it's just really 
hard to get your label out there and doing healthy from month to month. 
most label owners have daytime jobs. unless your the owner of 
metalheadz, or NRK, or TidyTraxx you are hustling doing something else.
the real money as an artist is getting your track signed for a mix cd 
from some huge dj. then you can cop a large amount or start talking 
percents and points.
your miles will vary of course for everything....
im agree with andyW, but i also agree with the fact that it sells more 
records in the long run. if you can afford to get a glass master done 
and nice graphics, then you can afford to pay for the tracks. if your 
burining 25 cd's at home with your colour printer making DIY and 
selling them for a few bucks for cost of materials or giving them out; 
may the force be with you...

hak

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

This is the same fight that's been happening for decades  with the record
companies/'recording industry' associations. The RIAA or its equivilant is
always agonizing over every little penny it can get its hands on when the
economy is tight. They used to shit themselves over records  being played
in public venues.

don't worry. the RIAA is becoming passe. Pretty soon those greedy old
bastards will be replaced by new greedy bastards. ;) The smart ones among
us will become those new greedy bastards and the rest of us will despair,
and the next generation of kids will shake their fists at those greedy
rave-generation profiteering gluttons... :b

Subject: [sfraves] RE: Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

I'm just wondering WTF these labels/producers were thinking when they 
put their tracks out on vinyl, in the first place, if they're going to 
get all lawsuit-happy over DJs mixing and playing them.  It seems 
pretty obvious to me....

I mean...  who the hell buys vinyl just to sit at home and listen to it 
alone and in private on a single record player and no mixer?!?!?  
(Though I'm sure SOMEONE will point out that they do so, just to prove 
me wrong....)  For that, we have CDs and MP3s!

Isn't the whole POINT of vinyl that DJs are going to mix it together, 
and play it out at a party?  And if they're not getting gigs yet, damn 
straight they're handing out mix tapes/CDs to anyone who'll take them.  
Why the hell ELSE, other than the DJ-and-1200-friendly user interface, 
WOULD you release your tracks on a low-fi, analog (ugh!), 
degrades-every-time-you-play-it, ruined by moderate heat, easy to 
break, more expensive to make than CD, and less space efficent, format 
like vinyl?!?!?


cya,
john

At 02:21 PM 1/22/2004, Jason wrote:


>One question I have is this. For all artists on SFRaves if you are
>signed to a label that you have no stake in financially what percentage
>of each record sold ends up in your pocket. I really want to know.
>
>Jason Philips
>Compos-Mentis
>Problematic Beats
>

Tom Morello (formerly "Rage Against the Machine" and now "Audioslave") on 
the recording industry:


"Explain how the basic record deal is not artist friendly.

Today if you sign a record deal with any of the majors or indies, this is 
what happens. They give a budget to make your record. Say it's $100,000, 
which they lend you. You make your album. You spend some of the money on 
guitars, and some of it on a recording engineer. Now your record contract 
says, for the sake of argument, you get ten cents on the dollar  which is 
not an unusual amount  and the record company gets ninety cents on the 
dollar. Now that $100,000 they gave you to make that record, you owe them 
back. You pay them back with your ten cents on the dollar. So they're in 
the black long before you've broken even. You might sell half a million 
records and be in debt to your record company. Unless you reach a certain 
threshold where you can increase that ten cents, artists are just dicked 
all the way around.

Prior to Rage Against the Machine I was in a band called Lock Up on Geffen 
records. We had the exact same deal that I just told you about. I'd go back 
to Libertyville, and people would think I was a millionaire, and I could 
not afford Ramen. I was on a $7 a week food budget with my big record deal."

Rock in a Hard Place
Elizabeth DiNovella, The Progressive
Former Rage Against the Machine guitarist Tom Morello
speaks out on conservative suburbs, unionizing musicians,
and how to be both subversive and patriotic.
http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=17603


Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Message-ID: <20040123173744.13817.qmail@web60301.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 23 Jan 2004 09:37:44 -0800 (PST)
From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: Jason <djjasonphilips@hotmail.com>, "'John B.'" <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>,
  sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <FEBF87D36F006D4AA2C33FB21ADA0DBE01F414F1@US-TRILLIUM.columbia.csc>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] RE: Bullshit!!! (Dj's vs. RIAA)

Well, in audiophile circles, vinyl is oftentimes considered far
superior to CD in its sound quality.  That's why these fools are paying
$5,000 for their home turntables!  Transient response is faster than
any digital medium, or even analog tape, for one.  A well-cut vinyl
record can sound a lot more alive, big, and in-your-face than a cd-r'ed
track, unless some serious work goes into the mix/mastering to bring
some of that color into the sound.

So yes, they do wear down and are fragile and all, but there are
tangible reasons why people like to hear them- I always get the cold
sweats fantasizing about what one of my tracks is going to sound like
when it gets back from the vinyl pressing plant- it always adds
something. :)

On the RIAA thing, I agree with an earlier poster- go ahead and use my
tracks on a free promo mix if I'm credited, but if you're going to sell
the thing than forget it- the originators of the wax you spin need to
get their due.  The $1.50 I make on a record (that I put out myself!)
doesn't compensate for the thousands a big dj pulls in for a commercial
mix cd, sorry.

My tuppence,
George C.
newstylesound recordings
www.newstylesound.com

Gay Marriage Poll Gets Annulled

By <http://www.wired.com/news/feedback/mail/1,2330,769,00.html>Daniel 
Terdiman<http://www.wired.com/news/feedback/mail/1,2330,769,00.html>
1190e5.jpg


Story location: 
<http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,61982,00.html>http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,61982,00.html

02:00 AM Jan. 22, 2004 PT

When the American Family Association posted an online poll last month 
asking its constituents their position on gay marriage, it thought it was 
engaging in a straightforward exercise.

The conservative organization supports a constitutional amendment defining 
marriage as strictly between a man and a woman, and it planned to forward 
to Congress the results of 
<http://www.afa.net/petitions/marriagepoll.asp>the poll, which it expected 
would support its position, as evidence of Americans' opposition to gay 
marriage.

But the <http://www.afa.net/>AFA never counted on the power of the 
Internet. And once the URL to the poll escaped its intended audience, 
everything went haywire. As of Jan. 19, 60 percent of respondents -- more 
than 508,000 voters -- said, "I favor legalization of homosexual marriage." 
With an additional 7.89 percent -- or 66,732 voters -- replying, "I favor a 
'civil union' with the full benefits of marriage except for the name," the 
AFA's chosen position, "I oppose legalization of homosexual marriage and 
'civil unions,'" was being defeated by a 2-1 ratio.

"We're very concerned that the traditional state of marriage is under 
threat in our country by homosexual activists," said AFA representative 
Buddy Smith. "It just so happens that homosexual activist groups around the 
country got a hold of the poll -- it was forwarded to them -- and they 
decided to have a little fun, and turn their organizations around the 
country (onto) the poll to try to cause it to represent something other 
than what we wanted it to. And so far, they succeeded with that."

Of course, no such poll can be said to represent an accurate picture of 
popular opinion. But, clearly, the AFA had hoped Congress would take the 
numbers it planned to produce as exactly that kind of evidence.

Now, Smith says, his organization has had to abandon its goal of taking the 
poll to Capitol Hill.

"We made the decision early on not to do that," Smith admitted, "because of 
how, as I say, the homosexual activists around the country have done their 
number on it."

So what happened?

Against the wishes of the AFA and its members, the poll leaked to the 
outside. And soon, people like Gabe Anderson began posting it to blogs, 
social-networking sites such as 
<http://www.friendster.com/index.jsp>Friendster and sundry e-mail lists. 
When Anderson 
<http://gabeanderson.com/life/2003/12/18/marriage_poll.php>posted it to his 
blog on Dec. 18, 2003, the anti-gay-marriage position was leading, with 
51.45 percent of respondents opposing gay marriage or civil unions.

But with his posting, in which he alerted his readers to the poll, Anderson 
-- and many like him -- began to unleash the democratic power that the 
Internet promises, and which organizations like the AFA must have 
forgotten: the ability to bring people together to fight for, or against, a 
cause.

"I definitely think that if an organization like the AFA wants to conduct a 
poll like this, they open up themselves to more than they expected," said 
Anderson. "I think it's a great example that the Internet can effect change 
and have an influence if there is a cause."

Surely, by now, with the rise of organizations like 
<http://www.moveon.org>MoveOn.org and Internet-fueled political campaigns 
like Howard Dean's, such results should surprise no one.

But the AFA seems to have been caught by surprise, and is now trying to 
gain new currency from the outcome.

"Hopefully the results of the poll will be a wake-up call," said Smith, "to 
realize the need for us to get more focused and organized and to do what we 
need to do."

But in the meantime, the AFA and organizations like it will have to get 
used to the idea that if they want to use the Internet as a tool, they had 
better understand how it works.

"I think it's pretty cool," said Anderson. "It's empowering that the 
Internet can have this kind of effect. As an individual, your first 
reaction is, 'I don't know if I can make a difference.' This is a good 
example of helping people who are historically apathetic (to say), 'Maybe 
my vote will matter, too.'"



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

<h1><b>Gay Marriage Poll Gets Annulled&nbsp; </b></h1><font size=3>By
<a href="http://www.wired.com/news/feedback/mail/1,2330,769,00.html">Daniel
Terdiman</a><a href="http://www.wired.com/news/feedback/mail/1,2330,769,00.html"><img src="cid:6.0.1.1.2.20040123113459.02123ac8@mail.speakeasy.net.0" width=15 height=13 alt="1190e5.jpg"></a>
<br><br>
<b>Story location:</b>
<a href="http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,61982,00.html">http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,61982,00.html</a><br><br>
<i>02:00 AM Jan. 22, 2004 PT<br><br>
</i>When the American Family Association posted an online poll last month asking its constituents their position on gay marriage, it thought it was engaging in a straightforward exercise. <br><br>
The conservative organization supports a constitutional amendment defining marriage as strictly between a man and a woman, and it planned to forward to Congress the results of <a href="http://www.afa.net/petitions/marriagepoll.asp">the poll</a>, which it expected would support its position, as evidence of Americans' opposition to gay marriage. <br><br>
But the <a href="http://www.afa.net/">AFA</a> never counted on the power of the Internet. And once the URL to the poll escaped its intended audience, everything went haywire. As of Jan. 19, 60 percent of respondents -- more than 508,000 voters -- said, &quot;I favor legalization of homosexual marriage.&quot; With an additional 7.89 percent -- or 66,732 voters -- replying, &quot;I favor a 'civil union' with the full benefits of marriage except for the name,&quot; the AFA's chosen position, &quot;I oppose legalization of homosexual marriage and 'civil unions,'&quot; was being defeated by a 2-1 ratio. <br><br>
&quot;We're very concerned that the traditional state of marriage is under threat in our country by homosexual activists,&quot; said AFA representative Buddy Smith. &quot;It just so happens that homosexual activist groups around the country got a hold of the poll -- it was forwarded to them -- and they decided to have a little fun, and turn their organizations around the country (onto) the poll to try to cause it to represent something other than what we wanted it to. And so far, they succeeded with that.&quot; <br><br>
Of course, no such poll can be said to represent an accurate picture of popular opinion. But, clearly, the AFA had hoped Congress would take the numbers it planned to produce as exactly that kind of evidence. <br><br>
Now, Smith says, his organization has had to abandon its goal of taking the poll to Capitol Hill. <br><br>
&quot;We made the decision early on not to do that,&quot; Smith admitted, &quot;because of how, as I say, the homosexual activists around the country have done their number on it.&quot; <br><br>
So what happened? <br><br>
Against the wishes of the AFA and its members, the poll leaked to the outside. And soon, people like Gabe Anderson began posting it to blogs, social-networking sites such as <a href="http://www.friendster.com/index.jsp">Friendster</a> and sundry e-mail lists. When Anderson <a href="http://gabeanderson.com/life/2003/12/18/marriage_poll.php">posted</a> it to his blog on Dec. 18, 2003, the anti-gay-marriage position was leading, with 51.45 percent of respondents opposing gay marriage or civil unions. <br><br>
But with his posting, in which he alerted his readers to the poll, Anderson -- and many like him -- began to unleash the democratic power that the Internet promises, and which organizations like the AFA must have forgotten: the ability to bring people together to fight for, or against, a cause. <br><br>
&quot;I definitely think that if an organization like the AFA wants to conduct a poll like this, they open up themselves to more than they expected,&quot; said Anderson. &quot;I think it's a great example that the Internet can effect change and have an influence if there is a cause.&quot; <br><br>
Surely, by now, with the rise of organizations like <a href="http://www.moveon.org">MoveOn.org</a> and Internet-fueled political campaigns like Howard Dean's, such results should surprise no one. <br><br>
But the AFA seems to have been caught by surprise, and is now trying to gain new currency from the outcome. <br><br>
&quot;Hopefully the results of the poll will be a wake-up call,&quot; said Smith, &quot;to realize the need for us to get more focused and organized and to do what we need to do.&quot; <br><br>
But in the meantime, the AFA and organizations like it will have to get used to the idea that if they want to use the Internet as a tool, they had better understand how it works. <br><br>
&quot;I think it's pretty cool,&quot; said Anderson. &quot;It's empowering that the Internet can have this kind of effect. As an individual, your first reaction is, 'I don't know if I can make a difference.' This is a good example of helping people who are historically apathetic (to say), 'Maybe my vote will matter, too.'&quot; <br><br>

-- 
What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

From sfraves-return-109706-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Jan 23 22:52:35 2004

Message-ID: <20040123225232.47469.qmail@web14310.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 23 Jan 2004 14:52:32 -0800 (PST)
From: DJ Tao <djtao530@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-226701229-1074898352=:46844"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Help The Environment! Please Read!

--0-226701229-1074898352=:46844
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Dear NRDC BioGems Defender,

Over the next few weeks, President Bush and his congressional allies 
will try once again to ram their disastrous energy bill through the U.S. Senate. 
They fell only two votes short in November and they've vowed to make passage 
of the bill their top priority now that Congress has returned from recess. 

This bill may be the worst piece of legislation you and I will see in 
our lifetimes. It would pick your pocket, despoil your natural heritage, 
endanger your family's health and smother your hope for a more secure energy 
future. We ignore this bill at our own peril.

Let me tell you our simple plan for thwarting this shameless attack on 
our environment and pocketbooks. If millions of Americans each took one 
minute to protest this bill, it would cause every senator who is tempted to vote 
for it to think twice about doing so.

You can make this happen within the next few hours by doing two things:

First, go to http://www.savebiogems.org/takeaction.asp?src=RR0401
and send your two senators an email or fax, telling them to vote 
against this pro-polluter energy bill. Then, forward my email to at least four of 
your friends, family members or colleagues.

I am emailing this message to 500,000 BioGems Defenders and other NRDC
activists. If each one forwards this message to just four more people, 
we will generate a national tidal wave of opposition before this day is over.

And that won't be a moment too soon. This disgraceful bill would pick 
our pockets to hand out billions of dollars in taxpayer subsidies to the 
oil, coal and nuclear industries. That's their long-awaited reward for making 
big-time contributions to the Bush-Cheney campaign. They profit while the rest 
of us pay the price -- in tax dollars and environmental degradation.

This bill gives the energy giants a free pass to drill their way 
through our last wild places, burn more dirty coal, build a new generation of risky 
nuclear power plants and dramatically increase air pollution that would sicken 
the vulnerable -- especially children and seniors -- for decades to come.

It would establish oil and gas development as the dominant use of our 
federal public lands, open national parks to the construction of electricity
transmission lines, exempt polluters from core provisions of our clean 
air and water laws and waive liability for the producers of the toxic gasoline 
additive MTBE -- even though it has contaminated at least 1,500 public water 
supplies in all 50 American states.

You'd be hard-pressed to come up with a more backward-looking, wasteful 
and self-defeating energy "plan" than this one. At a time when the federal 
deficit is soaring and we're going to war in the Persian Gulf oilfields, the 
White House wants to stick us with the tab for prolonging our destructive 
dependence on fossil fuels, foreign oil and dangerous nuclear technology.

This is not a national energy policy. This is corporate welfare, pure 
and simple. Estimates of the bill's corporate tax breaks range from $23 
billion to well over $100 billion with loan guarantees included. No surprise 
there. Big energy companies cooked up this raid on the federal treasury during 
hundreds of secret meetings with Vice President Cheney's energy task force and 
their allies on Capitol Hill.

It's one thing to gouge taxpayers. But to claim this rip-off is in the 
national interest, as the White House would have us believe, is a slap in the 
face to every working American.

Poll after poll shows that the vast majority of voters -- of both 
parties -- understand that we simply must reduce our out-of-control appetite for 
fossil fuels if we ever are to secure energy independence. That means turning 
American rooftops into the Persian Gulf of solar energy. It means producing cars 
that get 40 miles per gallon. It means constructing efficient buildings that 
use half the energy of the average American office without sacrificing 
comfort.

Making this transformation to a super-efficient, low-pollution economy 
would save consumers upwards of a trillion dollars, spare our last wild 
places from destruction, improve our health, slow global warming and reduce our 
dependence on undemocratic regimes overseas. It's a no-brainer to anyone living 
outside the White House.

But unless millions of Americans speak out right now, the enactment of 
the president's energy bill will doom us to an apocalyptic future of 
blighted wilderness, poisonous air pollution, devastating climate change and 
endless wars over fossil fuels.

Please make your voice heard. Go to
http://www.savebiogems.org/takeaction.asp?src=RR0401
and tell your senators to obey the will of the American people, *not* 
the dictates of giant energy corporations! Call on Congress to create a 
sustainable and affordable energy path.

And please be sure to forward this message to at least four other 
people. Believe me, millions of Americans are just waiting for a simple way to 
stop this madness and lend their support to a sane and hopeful energy 
future.

Sincerely yours,

Robert Redford
Board of Trustees
Natural Resources Defense Council

. . .

BioGems: Saving Endangered Wild Places
A project of the Natural Resources Defense Council
http://www.savebiogems.org

Note: We appreciate the opportunity to communicate with you and other 
NRDC BioGems Defenders, but if you would prefer not to receive BioGems 
updates or hear from BioGems activists in the field, you can send an email message 
to biogemsdefenders@savebiogems.org with "Please remove my name" in the 
subject line.

> had too many "incidents" with my stuff going in the cargo holds. I prefer to

-- 
What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Friday, January 23, 2004 ** DJ Revolution of the World Famous Wake Up Show =
**

DJ Revolution | BIO

Revolution began his career at the age of 13 on some dusty, old, mismatched=
, beltdriven turntables his grandfather pulled out of the attic.

After hooking them up to a mixer ol' grandad built from scrap metal in his =
garage,
he started selling Top 40 and rock mix tapes to his sixth grade class. When
he first heard The Adventures of Grandmaster Flash on The Wheels of Steel w=
hich
had already been out a few years - his whole idea of what a DJ was turned u=
pside
down.
Since then DJ Revolution has spent 15 years perfecting his craft on the 120=
0's.
You'd be amazed at how much one can do with records in 15 years, and Revolu=
tions
has done just about everything you can think of. Spun 'em, scratched 'em, j=
uggled
'em, sampled 'em, collected 'em, produced 'em, sold 'em, distributed 'em, p=
romoted
'em and so on. But in 1996, after sending an outdated mixtape to King Tech,
he could add one more item to the list of things he's done with records; pl=
ayed
'em on the Wake up Show.
Two weeks after Tech contacted DJ Revolution, Rev was on the show doing reg=
ular
guest spots. In 97', when a friend and crewmember Prince Ice left the show,
Rev took over the wheels, and has been holding 'em down ever since
A side from his duties on the air he has lent his now infamous scratch tech=
niques
to countless records and his production skills to many established artists.
Revolution jhas also released 2 of his own Full Length LP's (In 12's we tru=
st/R2K)
and 1 with his partners Sway &amp; Tech (This or That).
He now owns and operates his label Millenia Music, on which he will continu=
e
to make classic contributions to the hp hop world thru the material it puts
out.
However, no matter how involved in the business of Hip Hop DJ Revolution be=
comes
he will always be most comfortable standing behind two 1200's

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1075
Sacramento California, USA

Friday, January 23, 2004 ** SOMA Sessions w/Marcus Intalex **

SOMA Sessions
Fourth Fridays @ AsiaSF

For the inaugural session we bring you, all the way from Manchester UK, the=
 sounds of:

MARCUS INTALEX (Soul:r, MIST - UK)
Marcus Intalex is known across the globe for his infectious, smooth style o=
f Drum 'n Bass. Only a few years after his first production efforts in 1995=
 on Flex and his own Intalex Productions imprint came anthems such as "How =
You Make Me Feel," "Love & Happiness" and "Universe," which firmly position=
ed Marcus as one of the world's top D&B personalities. Today, Marcus and lo=
ngtime studio partner, S.T. Files continue to blaze trails as M.I.S.T. with=
 their wildly popular Soul:r label. With over a decade of experience on the=
 decks, SOMA Sessions is proud to welcome back to San Francisco one of the =
UK's most in-demand Drum 'n Bass DJs.

METHOD ONE (Cov.Ops, method-one.com)
By 1994 Method One was both an acclaimed DJ and and experienced rave promot=
er in Philly. By 1996 he was also an established producer. Recording with p=
artner Kaos as Atlantiq, Method One signed tunes to labels like Good Lookin=
g and True Intent while holding down DJ residencies at Konkrete Jungle and =
Dieselboy's Platinum. Since relocating to the Bay, Jason continues to wreck=
 dancefloors with his diverse DJ sets and release top-shelf tunes on labels=
 such as ASC's Covert Operations.

Resident Support:
DJ M
SOUND:BOY

Saturday, January 24, 2004 ** Dan Brake benefit **

Vibe Rite presents...
the DAN BRAKE BENEFIT

On Thursday, January 8th, a fire destroyed the home of one our scene=92s mo=
st beloved members, Dan Brake of Preserve.  Fortunately, no one was hurt, i=
ncluding their dog. However, Dan and his roommates lost just about everythi=
ng they owned and suddenly found themselves homeless. They are now dealing =
with the emotional devastation and loss of personal items which can never b=
e replaced.

Dan has given so much to our scene and now, it=92s time for us to give back=
 and help him rebuild what the fire took away.

VibeRite and Audio Metamorphosis will be hosting a benefit party on Saturda=
y, January 24. We=92re asking for at least a $5 donation at the door. 100% =
of all proceedes will go directly to Dan. Just as important as the financia=
l donations is the emotional support we can all give Dan right now.  So, le=
t=92s get together and party for a good cause. Don=92t forget, this is a pa=
rty, and we=92re gonna have fun!

Dan Brake Benefit Party

Saturday, Jan. 24

BBQ starts at 4pm and the party continues until we fall over on Sunday

$5 (or more) donation at the door

djs:
ACHILLES (D&A Music)
ALEKS (Audio Metamorphosis)

is together.

Yes, Fat Bird will be there, however, we=92ll try our best to keep him unde=
r control. But, ya=92ll know how he gets=85.

Saturday, January 24, 2004 ** Charles Feelgood - "CD Release Party" **

Charles Feelgood | BIO

Legendary for his role in the birth of the electronic music scene in the Ba=
ltimore/Washington DC area, Charles Feelgood has built a solid reputation a=
s a DJ in the international dance music community through his ingenious rem=
ix skills and dynamic brand of funky disco house.

Cultivating a fascination with music since childhood, Charles Fields grew u=
p listening to Motown, disco and funk, genres that heavily influenced his p=
ersonal style as an artist.

"I used to stay up late listening to my dad play records and decided that w=
as what I wanted to do," says Feelgood. His first foray into the world of d=
ance music was in the late '80s, throwing small-scale parties under the nam=
e "House of Fields".

An integral part of the Baltimore/DC style since day one, Feelgood is often=
 credited with putting the scene on the house music map. In 1992 he joined =
forces with fellow DJ Scott Henry to launch Fever, a club event that introd=
uced the sounds of electronic music to his hometown. The first event of its=
 kind in that region, the night exploded in popularity almost immediately, =
attracting upwards of 25,000 people. Featuring such top-notch, internationa=
lly renowned talent as Paul Van Dyk and Carl Cox, the biweekly event ran th=
rough May 2001.

Maintaining a seven-year residency at Fever helped springboard Feelgood's e=
minently danceable brand of bangin' hard house to widespread exposure acros=
s the East Coast. His popularity quickly bloomed thanks in part to his lege=
ndary series of mixed tapes, "Time to Get Ill." He soon developed a club-he=
avy touring schedule that regularly took him to famed clubs such as Sound F=
actory, Spundae, Shampoo, and Cro Bar, along with numerous other venues on =
the West Coast, Canada, Europe, Asia and South America.

In 1993, Feelgood launched his own label, Charm City Recordings, to create =
an outlet for his original material. His releases on the label found modera=
te success, but ultimately, launching his own label proved to be a crucial =
stepping stone for exposing his material to more famous imprints.

Following a successful mixed CD release in 2000 on Warner Bros. offshoot F-=
111, Feelgood joined forces with North America's premier electronic music l=
abel in 2001 to release the well-received "Can You Feel It," followed later=
 that year by an installment in the djmixed.com series.

According to Feelgood, the secret to a great mix CD is recreating the club =
experience on vinyl. But despite the immense popularity and critical acclai=
m his mixed CD's have received, he still prefers to produce original record=
s for the artistic freedom it allows.

Constantly in demand all over the world for his ability to light up dance f=
loors with his disco-flavored sets of funk-drenched house, Feelgood has rec=
eived numerous accolades in his thirteen-year career. These include being n=
amed Baltimore's Best DJ, and being included in the top 40 of BPM Magazine'=
s 2002 top 50 DJ list.

Acclaimed for his ability to seamlessly transition between club and rave at=
mospheres, Feelgood notes "I definitely try and take the listeners on a mus=
ical journey - I like to start out slow and funky and push for a harder end=
ing, a continuous rise."

"I'm far from a purist," he adds. "I incorporate many styles into a single =
set. I play everything from disco-influenced house to a capella tracks and =
tech house, and I especially love bootlegs."

Looking to expand more into the realm of production, Feelgood has retreated=
 into the cut hut studios to concentrate full force on producing original m=
aterial. Look for a slew of released in 2002, with his highly anticipated f=
ull-length studio album to be released in summer 2004. Charles next mix alb=
um "Across America" will be in stores May 05, 2003 on the 611/System Record=
ings Imprint.

The consummated dance floor rocker, Feelgood sums up his musical mission in=
 one sentence: "I just want the name implies, to make people have a good ti=
me and go home with a great feeling."

PEACE&RESPECT,
BIGFLOOR Events

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1074

Friday, February 6, 2004 ** *Oneiromancy* presented by Oneiromancy **

Doing things different from other crews, admission to this event will be fr=
ee of charge. We are working on the lineup, but as with all our events, we =
want to extend a special invite to all the new DJs who have never played an=
 event. We are setting aside a number of timeslots, in various genres, so i=
f you are dying to get out there to play, email me at wavelength_sf@yahoo.c=
om, with the subject "Oneiromancy" Be sure to include contact info, links t=
o demos (if you have one), and genre. I know everyone plays every genre, bu=
t if you could limit it to one, that would help. I'm going to randomly draw=
 names to play for each genre, so DJs who play a genre that is under-repres=
ented will have a better shot. Its all random: I dont care if we are friend=
s, enemies, whatever. I'll post the list the day after christmas, so thats =
the deadline. Oh yes, and unlike other times, hardcore DJs will definatly g=
et slots at this party. Hope to see you guys there. (look for the full line=
up the day after christmas. ) More info TBA.
